questions.text: A researcher is conducting experiments to know the site of expression of the enzyme glucokinase in the body. Which of the following techniques would be the most useful for this study?

choices.text: Western blot analysis to detect RNA
Northern blot analysis to detect RNA
Southern blot analysis to detect DNA
Northern blot analysis to detect DNA

questions.solution: Expression analysis of an enzyme or protein involves the detection of the corresponding mRNA of that enzyme. A very basic technique to do that is called Northern blot analysis. In this technique, RNA is detected by hybridization to a complementary labeled DNA to form a (DNA-RNA hybridization). In this example, detection of glucokinase mRNA from the liver and other tissue samples would demonstrate which cells in addition to liver cells are expressing glucokinase. A DNA probe for glucokinase will simply be a small part of the genetic DNA sequence of the glucokinase enzyme labeled with a fluorescent dye/radioactive bases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man on drug therapy with a potent oxidizing agent has a self-limiting episode of hemolysis, back pain, and jaundice. The peripheral blood smear reveals non-spherocytic and normocytic anemia; Heinz's bodies are seen in some of his erythrocytes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his anemia?

choices.text: A lowered concentration of oxidized glutathione
A lowered concentration of reduced glutathione
A reduction of hydrogen peroxide levels

questions.solution:
Option B: A lowered concentration of reduced glutathione

  • The patient has glucose 6-P dehydrogenase deficiency and cannot generate NADPH from glucose 6-P. In the red blood cells lacking mitochondria, this is the only pathway through which NADPH can be generated.
  • In the absence of NADPH, the molecule which protects against oxidative damage (glutathione) is oxidized preferentially to protect membrane lipids and proteins.
  • There is only limited glutathione in the membrane, so once it is oxidized, it needs to be converted back to reduced glutathione (the protective form).
  • The enzyme that does this, glutathione reductase, requires NADPH to supply the electrons to reduce the oxidized glutathione.

  • In the absence of NADPH, the glutathione cannot be reduced, and the protection offered by reduced glutathione is eliminated, leading to membrane damage and cell lysis.

Option A: A lowered concentration of oxidized glutathione

This is the wrong choice because:

  • Patients with glucose 6-P dehydrogenase deficiency cannot generate NADPH from glucose 6-P.
  • In the absence of NADPH, glutathione cannot be reduced.
  • The oxidized form of glutathione is increased.

Option C: Increased production of NADPH

  • Patients with glucose 6-P dehydrogenase deficiency cannot generate NADPH from glucose 6-P.
  • As the HMP is the major pathway for the production of NADPH, So cell will  have a lower levels of NADPH.

Option D: A reduction of hydrogen peroxide levels

  • H2O2 is a reactive oxygen spec responsible for free radical damage of cell membranes.
  • In the absence of G6PD, H2O2 neutralization will be reduced, so there should be a rise in hydrogen peroxide levels.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male comes to the E.N.T department with the complaint of ear discharge fever, bilateral facial nerve paralysis, and bilateral profound hearing loss. The patient has a history of abdominal tuberculosis. On otoscopic, the patient is found to have multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Tubercular otitis media

Tubercular otitis media

  • The above given is a case of tubercular otitis media.
  • Tuberculosis of the middle ear is usually unilateral.
  • It's characterized by non-painful otorrhoea that doesn't react to antimicrobial therapy.
  • Watery otorrhea is a non-painful condition. Perforations in the tympanic membrane can be single or numerous.
  • Multiple holes may exist in the early stages but eventually merge into a big tympanic membrane perforation with pale granulation tissue.
  • The presence of periauricular fistulae, lymphadenopathy, and facial palsy is uncommon. Facial paralysis, labyrinthitis, postauricular fistulae, subperiosteal abscess, and cerebral infection are also late consequences.

Option B: Syphilitic otitis media

  • Syphilitic otitis media: It is a rare condition.
  • Spirochaetes reach the middle ear through the eustachian tube when syphilitic lesions are present in the nose or nasopharynx.
  • Infection may also be blood-borne.
  • Sensory end organs of the inner ear and their nerves are soon invaded by spirochaetes leading to profound sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo.
  • Bone necrosis and sequestrum formation are common, and they lead to fetid ear discharge.
  • Secondary pyogenic infection may occur, giving a clinical picture very much like chronic suppurative otitis media.

Option C: Pseudomonas infection

  • Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is an inflammatory condition caused by pseudomonas infection, usually in elderly diabetics or those on immunosuppressive drugs.
  • Its early manifestations resemble diffuse otitis externa, but there is excruciating pain and the appearance of granulations in the ear canal.
  • Facial paralysis is common. Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen, causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • Anteriorly, the infection spreads to the temporomandibular fossa, posteriorly to the mastoid, and medially into the middle ear and petrous bone.

Option D: Fungal otitis media

  • Otomycosis: Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the ear canal that often occurs due to Aspergillus niger, A. fumigatus, or Candida albicans.
  • It is seen in the hot and humid climates of tropical and subtropical countries. Secondary fungal growth is also seen in patients using topical antibiotics for the treatment of otitis externa or middle ear suppuration.
  • The clinical features of otomycosis include intense itching, discomfort or pain in the ear, watery discharge with a musty odour, and ear blockage.
  • The fungal mass may appear white, brown, or black and has been likened to a wet piece of filter paper. Examined with an otoscope, A. niger appears as black-headed filamentous growth, A. fumigatus as pale blue or green, and candida as a white or creamy deposit. Meatal skin appears sodden, red, and edematous.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with a humerus fracture after a road track accident. The orthopedic surgeon admitted him; he is posted for open reduction and external fixation. As soon as the patient was administered the local anesthetic agent, he exhibited the symptoms of seizures and sensory and visual changes with a reduced level of consciousness. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lipid emulsion therapy

  • In the above-given case, the findings such as seizures, sensory and visual changes, and reduced level of consciousness after anaesthesia are caused by the local anaesthetic systemic toxicity.
  • If a patient experiences profound cardiovascular depression or circulatory arrest after the administration of bupivacaine, ropivacaine, or by extrapolation, other local anaesthetics, then along with the initiation of the basic life support and the ACLS protocol, it is recommended that a rapid bolus of intralipid 20% lipid emulsion is to be administered.

Option A: Lignocaine

  • Lignocaine is used as a local anaesthetic and antiarrhythmic drug. Lignocaine causes blurred vision, fingernails, chest pain, and pale skin.

Option C: Vasopressin

  • Vasopressin is an antidiuretic hormone.
  • It is used to regulate blood pressure and blood osmolality during the procedure.
  • Vasopressin causes back pain, agitation, convulsions, swallowing difficulty, and chest tightness. 

Option D: Ephedrine

  • Ephedrine is used to treat hypotension under anaesthesia.
  • Ephedrine causes insomnia, tachycardia, anxiety, and tremors.

questions.text: A nineteen years old male presents to your clinic with symptoms of a gradually progressive, painless decrease of vision in both eyes. Other medical problems include a recent decrease in hearing and has been having blood in his urine for quite some time now. Anterior segment examination of the eye shows a conical protrusion of the anterior lens capsule with a clear underlying lens. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Alport's syndrome

  • A cone-shaped bulge seen on the anterior or posterior capsule respectively is called anterior lenticonus or posterior lenticonus.
  • On distant direct ophthalmoscopy, lenticonus is seen as an oil globule lying in the centre of the red reflex.
  • Slit-lamp examination confirms the diagnosis.
  • Alport's syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterised by chronically progressive hemorrhagic nephropathy, bilateral deafness and ocular disorders.
  • This is due to mutations in genes coding for type IV collagen.
  • Anterior lenticonus is associated with Alport Syndrome.

Option B: Lowe's syndrome

  • Lowe's syndrome is a rare disorder characterised by mental retardation, hypotonia, and kidney dysfunction.
  • Posterior lenticonus is seen in Lowe's syndrome.
  • This patient's findings are suggestive of anterior lenticonus.

Option C: Marfan syndrome

  • Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of the connective tissue.
  • People with Marfan syndrome are tall and thin with unusually long arms, legs, fingers and toes.
  • The most common ocular finding in Marfan syndrome is ectopia lentis.
  • This patient's findings are suggestive of anterior lenticonus.

Option D: Homocystinuria

  • Homocystinuria is an inherited disorder in which the body cannot process the amino acid homocysteine.
  • It is characterised by increased homocysteine in the blood and the presence of homocysteine in urine.
  • Ectopia lentis is the most common ocular finding in homocystinuria.
  • This patient's findings are suggestive of anterior lenticonus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the psychiatric outpatient department due to a change in personality for 7 months. It is associated with hearing voices that tell him he is the best man in the world. He also believes that he can be alive even after death. The clinician suspects a case of psychosis. Which of the following does not define psychosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Preserved contact with reality

  • The term psychosis is defined as:
  • Gross impairment in reality testing (not in contact with reality)
  • Marked disturbance in personality, with impairment in social, interpersonal, and occupational functioning.
  • Marked impairment in judgment and absent knowledge of the current symptoms and behavior (lack of insight).
  • Presence of the characteristic signs and symptoms like delusions and hallucinations.
  • The major non-organic psychotic disorders are schizophrenia and mood disorders.
  • The symptoms of psychosis occur due to changes in neurotransmitters in the brain.
  • The main neurotransmitter involved is dopamine. Increase in dopamine results in hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized thinking.
  • Certain medical conditions also lead to psychosis, e.g., SLE, syphilis, HIV, and multiple sclerosis.
  • Cortisol released during stress may also lead to psychosis.
  • Psychotic conditions can be inherited.
  • Substance abuse with cannabis, amphetamines, and cocaine increases the chance of developing psychosis.

Option A: Lack of insight

  • It is one of the defining factors of psychosis.
  • Patients with psychotic disorders lack insight.
  • They have impaired judgment and no knowledge of current symptoms and behavior.

Option B: Presence of delusions

  • It is one of the defining factors of psychosis.
  • Delusions and hallucinations are characteristic signs of psychosis.

Option D: Personality disturbances

  • It is one of the defining factors of psychosis.
  • Marked disturbances are seen in personality and social, occupational, and interpersonal functioning.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented to the clinic complaining of skin hyperpigmentation, central obesity, violet striae & proximal myopathy for the past 3 months. His B.P. is 160/90 mmHg. Lab studies show hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Basal ACTH level is likely to be low.
Circulating corticotropin-releasing hormone is likely to be elevated.
Pituitary magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) will visualize all ACTH-secreting tumours.
Serum potassium level < 3.3 mmol/L is suggestive of ectopic ACTH production

questions.solution:
Option D: Serum potassium level <3.3 mmol/L is suggestive of ectopic ACTH production

  • The given scenario describes a man with hyperpigmentation, central obesity, violet striae and hypertension, suggesting the diagnosis of Cushing syndrome.

  • Serum potassium level < 3.3 mmol/L is suggestive of ectopic ACTH production
  • Also, hypertension, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis & glucose intolerance are more prominent in ectopic ACTH secretion than in pituitary tumours
  • Ectopic ACTH  production
    • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid
    • Small cell cancer in the lung
    • Medullary carcinoma of thyroids
    • Pheochromocytoma

Option A: Basal ACTH level is likely to be low

  • Basal ACTH are likely to be elevated in pituitary and ectopic ACTH-producing tumours

Option B: Circulating corticotropin-releasing hormone is expected to be elevated.

  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone is rarely the cause of Cushing syndrome. Rather it is low in Acth-dependent Cushing's syndrome due to the negative feedback

Option C: Pituitary magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) will visualize all ACTH-secreting tumours

  • MRI of the pituitary gland will not visualize lesions <2 mm tumours, so this statement is incorrect

questions.text: A 47-year-old lady with left calf pain, edema, and erythema, diagnosed with a popliteal vein thrombosis, was prescribed warfarin. Three months later, she experienced a nosebleed with an INR of 7.0. Apart from stopping warfarin, what additional measures are needed to prevent further bleeding?
questions.solution:
Option B: Vitamin K1

  • The patient presents with a complaint of pain in the left leg and the leg is oedematous and hyperemic, suggesting a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. He is on long-term warfarin therapy and now presents with above-the-target INR.
  • Vitamin K acts as a co-factor in the synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX and X by the liver.
  • Warfarin works as an anticoagulant by inhibiting the liver's vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKOR). Inhibition of VKOR decreases the synthesis of clotting factors.
  • Overdose of warfarin can result in bleeding. Haematuria is usually the first to occur. Other common bleeding sites are  GIT, nose, and under-the-skin ecchymoses.
  • Excessive anticoagulant effects and bleeding from warfarin can be prevented by stopping the drug and administering oral or parenteral vitamin K1 (phytonadione).
  • A four-factor complex or fresh-frozen plasma can treat acute bleeding.

Option A: Desmopressin

  • Desmopressin is used to treat central cranial diabetes insipidus.
  • It has no role in the treatment of warfarin over-use.

Option C: Factor VIII

  • The synthesis of factor VIII is not dependent on vitamin K.
  • It is produced by epithelial cells, not by the liver.

Option D: Protamine sulfate

  • It is an inhibitor of heparin.
  • Administration of this agent in warfarin overdose has no effect.

questions.text: The parents of an 18-month-old girl appeared at the ER with their daughter, who had an abrupt onset of vomiting and watery diarrhoea. The symptoms began two days previously at her daycare centre. Initially, she had a mild fever which subsided after a day. She had 3 episodes of vomiting and multiple episodes of watery diarrhoea with abdominal pain. She refused to eat or drink and is very lethargic. What property of the infectious agent causing these symptoms allowed the preparation of a vaccine that could have prevented them?

choices.text: Ability to survive as a temperature-sensitive mutant.

questions.solution:
Option D: Segmented genetic material

Segmented genetic material allowed the preparation of a vaccine for Rotavirus.

  • Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhoea in infants.
  • Rotaviruses are about 60 to 80 nm and have icosahedral symmetry, triple-layered capsid and segmental double-stranded RNA (11 segments).

Reassortant vaccines:

  • It takes advantage of the natural ability of viruses with segmented genomes to reassort when more than one strain infects the host cell.
  • The goal of reassortment is to assemble a virus variant with attenuated pathogenicity that can be used for safe vaccination.

Two types of reassortant Rotavirus vaccines have been developed:

  • Reassortant of human Rotaviruses
  • Reassortant of human and bovine Rotaviruses.
  • RotaTeq and Rotarix are available for the prevention of Rotavirus.
  • RotaTeq is a live, oral pentavalent vaccine that contains 5 live reassortant rotaviruses.

Viruses having segmented genome (Mnemonic: PARBO virus):

P- Picornavirus

A-Arenaviridae

R- Reoviridae

B-Bunyaviridae

O- Orthomyxoviridae

ROTA VIRUS

  • Rotavirus is a very contagious virus that causes diarrhoea.
  • Before the vaccine development, most children had been infected with the virus at least once by age 5.
  • Although rotavirus infections are unpleasant, you can usually treat this infection at home with extra fluids to prevent dehydration.
  • Occasionally, severe dehydration requires receiving fluids through a vein (intravenously) in the hospital.

Symptoms

  • Rotavirus infection usually starts within two days of exposure to the virus.
  • Early symptoms are a fever and vomiting, followed by three to seven days of watery diarrhoea.
  • The infection can cause abdominal pain as well.

Spread of infection

  • Rotavirus is present in an infected person's stool two days before symptoms appear and up to 10 days after symptoms lessen.
  • The virus spreads easily through hand-to-mouth contact throughout this time, even if the infected person doesn’t have symptoms.

Diagnosis

  • Mostly it is diagnosed on symptoms and physical exam.
  • However, a stool sample analysis may be done for confirmation.

Treatment

  • There is no specific treatment for rotavirus infection. It usually resolves within 5 to 7 days.

Option A: Ability to survive as a temperature-sensitive mutant

  • Rotavirus temperature-sensitive mutants are genetically stable.
  • Temperature-sensitive mutants cause disease with reduced severity
  • However, the formation of the vaccine is based on its segmental RNA.

Option B: Identification of an enterotoxin

  • The virus enters the body through the mouth.
  • Viral replication occurs in the villous epithelium of the small intestine.
  • Up to two-thirds of children with severe rotavirus gastroenteritis show the presence of rotavirus antigen in serum (antigenemia), and children can have rotavirus RNA detected in serum.
  • Rotavirus nonstructural protein 4 (NSP4) is an enterotoxin identified as an important agent in symptomatic rotavirus infection.
  • However, the formation of a vaccine is not based on enterotoxin.

Option C: Loss of colonisation factors

  • The ability of ETEC to adhere to the host's intestinal epithelium is an important virulence determinant, and adhesion is mediated by proteinaceous surface appendages called colonisation factors.
  • The basis of rotavirus vaccine formation is its segmented genome.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of itching, discomfort, and vaginal discharge for the last 2 years. She also complains of some degree of dysuria and vaginal spotting. On examination, she has vulvar growth. On a biopsy, the findings are suggestive of squamous cell cancer of the vulva. Which of the following is most  associated finding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lichen Sclerosis

  • All of the above are associated with Vulvar cancer. The etiologic agents, however, differ according to the age group.
  • Two distinct etiologic entities of squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva exist.
  • Basaloid or warty types account for 40% of vulvar squamous cell carcinomas.
    • These tend to be multifocal, usually common in younger patients.
    • This type is directly related to HPV infection, Usual type VIN (VIN), immunosuppression and cigarette smoking.
  • Keratinizing type accounts for about 60% of cases of squamous cell carcinoma.
    • These tend to be unifocal, found Predominantly in older patients, and are not related to HPV.

 

 

Basaloid or warty types

 

 Keratinizing

 
40% of squamous

 

 60 % of squamous

 
Multifocal

 

 Unifocal

 
Younger patients

 

 Older patients

 
Related to HPV

 

 Not related to HPV, related to lichen sclerosis

 
Usual VIN, immunosuppression, smoking-related

 

 Differentiated VIN, chronic inflammatory dermatosis

 

 

risk factors of vulvar cancer:

  • HPV infection
  • Herpes simplex virus type 2 infection
  • History of smoking
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Immunosuppression
  • Chronic vulvar disease
  • Previous malignancies of the lower genital tract
  • Age >60 years

 

Option B: Human papillomavirus

  • HPV is associated with the development of vulvar cancer in young and sexually active females and not post-menopausal women.

Option C: Immunosuppression

  • It can be a risk factor in the development of vulvar cancer but has no direct involvement in the development of vulvar cancer in older women.

Option D: Smoking

  • Smoking is an important risk factor for squamous carcinoma worldwide, but it is generally not directly related to the development of vulvar carcinoma in older women.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman who has suffered a gunshot wound to her mid-abdomen presents to the emergency department pale and sweating with a blood pressure of 78/55 mmHg and a pulse of 130 beats/min. Initially, the patient was managed with fluid resuscitation. After examining the patient's angiogram, a trauma surgeon locates the source of bleeding from pairs of veins that typically terminate in the same vein. Which of the following veins are damaged?
questions.solution:
Option D: Left and right hepatic veins

  • Is a case of an abdominal gunshot wound, penetrating trauma to the abdomen.
  • The patient is given the sign of shock with low blood pressure. Most of the time, it's due to excessive blood loss from bleeding.
  • The right and left hepatic veins drain into the inferior vena cava.

Option A: Left and right ovarian veins

  • The right ovarian vein drains into the inferior vena cava, while the left ovarian vein drains into the left renal vein.

Option B: Left and right gastroepiploic veins.

  • The right gastroepiploic vein drains into the superior mesenteric vein, but the left drains into the splenic vein.

Option C: Left and right colic veins

  • The right colic vein ends in the superior mesenteric vein, but the left one terminates in the inferior mesenteric vein.

questions.text: A 60-year-old otherwise healthy woman presents to her physician with a 3-week history of severe headaches. A contrast CT scan reveals a small, circular, hypodense lesion with a ring-like contrast enhancement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Metastatic lesion

  • Although these CT findings can be consistent with all the options given in immunocompetent individuals, there is more incidence of it being a metastatic lesion.
  • Brain metastases occur when cancer cells spread from their original site to the brain. Any cancer can spread to the brain, but the types most likely to cause brain metastases are lung, breast, colon, kidney, and melanoma.
  • Brain metastases may form one tumour or many tumours in the brain. As the metastatic brain tumours grow, they create pressure on and change the function of surrounding brain tissue. This causes signs and symptoms such as headache, personality changes, memory loss, and seizures.
  • Treatment for people whose cancer has spread to the brain may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy or a combination of treatments. Other treatments might be recommended in certain situations. Treatment is often focused on reducing pain and symptoms resulting from cancer.

Option A: High-grade astrocytoma

  • Astrocytoma is one of the most common types of brain tumour that can develop in children. It arises from a specific type of cell in the brain called an astrocyte. Astrocytomas are divided into subgroups based on their grade and their location in the brain. 
  • High-grade astrocytomas are either grade 3 or grade 4 brain tumours. Both are malignant, but grade 4 tumours are more aggressive than grade 3 tumours. These tumours most often occur in the cerebral hemispheres but can also occur in the thalamus or, less commonly, in the posterior fossa.

Option C: Parenchymal Hemorrhage

  • A parenchymal hemorrhage, or an intraparenchymal hemorrhage (IPH), is a bleed that occurs within the brain parenchyma, the functional tissue in the brain consisting of neurons and glial cells. A hemorrhage, or the profuse release of blood from a ruptured blood vessel in the brain, disrupts normal blood flow and subsequently deprives the brain of oxygen.
  • As a result, the brain cells can die, which damages the affected nerves and the related functions they control as well. Spontaneous IPH accounts for less than 20% of stroke cases, but it is associated with the highest mortality rates of all forms of stroke. It can be classified as primary or secondary, depending on the cause.
  • Primary IPH accounts for about 80% of cases, occurring when there is a spontaneous rupture of damaged arteries. Meanwhile, secondary IPH is due to an underlying condition that increases the likelihood of hemorrhage.

Option D: Brain abscess

  • A brain abscess is a pus-filled swelling in the brain. It usually occurs when bacteria or fungi enter the brain tissue after an infection or severe head injury.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to your clinic with complaints of severe cough and fever. The cough has progressively worsened and is associated with bloody sputum. A sputum culture is performed, which is positive for acid-fast bacilli. A diagnosis of uncomplicated pulmonary tuberculosis is made. After initial treatment, he is prescribed isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide and ethambutol. Which of the following is the next most appropriate step in management of  this patient?

choices.text: His asymptomatic 3-year-old sibling should receive isoniazid prophylaxis
A baseline test of renal functions is essential before drug treatment is initiated

questions.solution:
Option A: His 3-year-old sibling should receive isoniazid prophylaxis

  • Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • It usually affects the lungs.
  • TB is curable and preventable.
  • Signs and symptoms include:
    • Bad cough (lasting greater than 2 weeks)
    • Fever
    • Chest pain
    • Blood tinged sputum
    • Weight loss
    • Fatigue
  • Active, drug-susceptible TB disease is treated with a standard 6-month course of 4 antimicrobial drugs.
  • First-line antitubercular drugs include:
    • Isoniazid (H)
    • Rifampin (R)
    • Ethambutol (E)
    • Pyrazinamide (Z)
    • Streptomycin
  • Prophylaxis with isoniazid is always advisable for family members and close contacts in active cases.

Option B: A baseline test of renal functions is essential before drug treatment is initiated

  • None of the drugs prescribed is associated with nephrotoxicity.
  • Routine liver function tests should be done in younger patients if isoniazid plus rifampin is given in higher doses.
  • Ocular function tests should be performed before starting ethambutol.

Option C: Polyarthralgia is a potential adverse effect of the drugs the boy is taking

  • Polyarthralgia is a side effect of pyrazinamide.
  • Pyrazinamide is not prescribed for this patient.

Option D: His mother, who takes care of him, does not need isoniazid prophylaxis

  • All family members of active TB patients are advised to take prophylactic isoniazid.
  • The mother, who will be closest in contact with the patient, most definitely requires prophylactic treatment.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old pregnant woman presents to the emergency room of a maternity hospital in labour and is admitted for safe delivery. Her previous medical record shows:

HIV-antibodies: detectable

HIV p24 antigen: Positive

HIV-RNA: Positive

On examination, there are good uterine contractions; the cervix is 2cm dilated and 50% effaced with intact membranes. There is no other obstetric contraindication to delivery. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Lower segment cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery.
Early artificial rupture of membranes should be done to detect meconium, as these patients are at high risk of fetal distress.
If the need for instrumental delivery arises, vacuum suction is better than forceps.
Routine suctioning of the newborn should be avoided.

questions.solution:
Option D: Routine suctioning of the newborn should be avoided.

  • Human immunodeficiency virus is a retrovirus, enveloped RNA virus, containing 2 molecules of RNA. It infects and replicates in CD4+ T cells and macrophages, leading to eventual immune system dysfunction, opportunistic infections and malignancy, also called acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).
  • It is transmitted by blood, sexual fluids and breast milk.
  • HIV testing:
    • ELISA for HIV antibody and antigen (p24): Very high sensitivity and specificity.
    • Rapid point-of care-testing.
    • Viral load: Quantification of viral RNA.
    • Nucleic acid amplification test/ Viral PCR: It is a qualitative test for the presence of viral RNA. It is used to test for vertical transmission in neonates as the transfer of maternal antibodies can affect ELISA antibody testing.
    • CD4 count: Used to monitor immune system function.
  • Management of a pregnant woman with HIV: The risks of mother-to-child transmission of HIV are related to:
    • Increased risk is associated with: advanced maternal HIV disease, high maternal plasma viral load, low CD4 lymphocyte counts, chorioamnionitis, coexisting viral infections (Hepatitis B and C), preterm delivery and breastfeeding.
    • Decreased risk is associated with: low viral counts at the delivery time, antiretroviral therapy, and exclusive formula feeding.
    • Interventions that can be done to reduce vertical transmission include:
      •  Antiretroviral therapy: To prevent HIV transmission from mother to child, triple agent antiretroviral therapy is given to all HIV+ pregnant women irrespective of their gestational age of presentation, CD4 counts and stage of the disease. It is given antenatally and intrapartum to the mother and the neonate for the first 4-6 weeks of life.
      • Per vaginal examination should be minimized, and aseptic techniques should be used.
      • Obstetric interventions such as amniotomy, use of fetal scalp electrodes, fetal blood sampling and instrumental deliveries should be avoided in HIV+ pregnant women.
      • Artificial rupture of membranes should be avoided for as long as possible.
      • Instrumental delivery should be avoided; however, if needed, low cavity forceps should be used instead of ventouse suction cups because the latter is associated with more fetal trauma.
      • Newborn suctioning by vacuum extractors cups/ ventouse cups should be avoided unless there is meconium staining of liquor.
      • Delivery by elective cesarean section in the presence of high viral load: There is no particular benefit of doing a cesarean to reduce mother-to-child transmission. However, it is indicated when there is a clear obstetric indication for cesarean section. There are some other indications for a cesarean section in an HIV+ mother:
        • A cesarean section is recommended when the viral load is heavy >1000 copies/ml.
        • It is indicated when the woman takes zidovudine (ZDV) monotherapy at or beyond 36 weeks of gestation.
        • It is also recommended in women who have coinfection with hepatitis C, as the risk of transmission is higher.
        • Women with a very high viral load >1000 copies/ml should be given IV zidovudine at the time of delivery if they are undergoing an elective cesarean section or present with spontaneous rupture of membranes.
        • The choice between elective and cesarean delivery can be selected based on the viral loads:
          • HIV RNA >1000 copies/ml - c-section at 38 weeks can be done.
          • HIV RNA <1000 copies/ml - vaginal delivery can be done.
      • Breastfeeding should be avoided.

 

Option A: Lower segment cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery.

  • Cesarean section should only be performed on a pregnant woman with HIV when there is any clear obstetric indication.

 

Option B: Early artificial rupture of membranes should be done to detect meconium, as these patients are at high risk of fetal distress.

  • Minimum intervention during delivery reduces the chance of HIV transmission. So, artificial rupture of membranes should be delayed for as long as possible in an HIV-positive pregnant woman.

 

Option C: If the need for instrumental delivery arises, vacuum suction is better than forceps.

  • Vacuum extractors/ Ventouse cups are associated with more fetal trauma than forceps, so these should be avoided during delivery in an HIV-positive mother.

questions.text: A low-risk primigravida undergoes vaginal delivery. An episiotomy is performed due to a protracted second stage of labor. Two hours after delivery, the patient appears pale. Pulse is  110/min, and blood pressure is 90/60. There is no apparent bleeding. Vaginal examination shows a bulge over the episiotomy stitch line. Haemoglobin shows a drop from 9 gm% to 7 gm%. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Blood and fluid transfusion with IV antibiotics
Blood transfusion and cold compression of episiotomy
Immediate exploration of episiotomy and blood transfusion
Cervical exploration with uterotonics with blood transfusion

questions.solution:
Option C: Immediate exploration of episiotomy and blood transfusion:

  • This patient shows signs of hemodynamic compromise with a significant drop in haemoglobin. This is suggestive of acute haemorrhage.
  • As uterine bleeding is not evident and a bulge is present at the site of episiotomy, it appears to be a case of a large hematoma at episiotomy, which should be urgently explored and evacuated, and the bleeder should be secured.
  • The above-given history suggests vulvar hematoma, a known complication of vaginal delivery and a cause of traumatic PPH.
  • It is caused due to trauma to perineal blood vessels, which, when ineffectively sutured, may be left to bleed, causing a hematoma.
  • Most cases of smaller non-expanding hematomas can be managed conservatively, at least initially, but if the pain does not disappear and if there is suspicion of an expanding hematoma, it will be necessary to examine the areas with the patient under anaesthesia and drainage to reduce the pain, blood loss, accelerate the recovery and prevent secondary infection and necrosis.

Option A: Blood and fluid transfusion with IV antibiotics:

  • Blood transfusion and IV antibiotics must be given, but the management is incomplete if the source of bleeding is not secured.
  • This patient needs urgent surgical exploration to find the cause of the bleeding.

Option B: Blood transfusion and cold compression of episiotomy:

  • Blood transfusion and cold compressions can be used for smaller, non-expanding hematomas

Option D: Cervical exploration with uterotonics with blood transfusion:

  • Cervical exploration is not indicated here, as the bulge is evident at the episiotomy site, and no bleeding is seen from the vagina.

questions.text: A 63-year-old presents to the emergency department with headache, vomiting, blurred vision, and drowsiness after a fall. The suspected cause is raised intracranial pressure. Which cranial nerve is most commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Option D: Abducent nerve

  • The abducent nerve is most commonly involved in intracranial hypertension
  • Reasons
    • Longest intradural course
    • Taking a sharp bend over the apex of the petrous part of the temporal bone.
    • Passing through the cavernous sinus, not supported laterally by any dura mater.
  • Its palsy causes loss of abduction of the affected eye.

Option A: Oculomotor nerve

  • The oculomotor nerve is most commonly affected intracranially due to an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery.

Option B: Trochlear nerve

  • It is a false statement
  • The trochlear nerve has the longest intracranial route, but it is not most commonly affected due to increased intracranial pressure.
  • It supplies the superior oblique muscle.

Option C: Trigeminal nerve

  • Trigeminal nerve is not commonly affected in intracranial hypertension.
  • Penetrating wounds and facial fractures cause damage to peripheral branches of the trigeminal nerve.

questions.text: WHO recommends the transmission assessment survey (TAS) to determine when infections have been reduced below the target thresholds. Transmission assessment survey is done for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option D: Wuchereria bancrofti

  • Transmission Assessment Survey is done for lymphatic Filariasis → caused by Wuchereria bancrofti.

Transmission Assessment Survey (TAS)

  • Two major role of TAS:
    1. To stop mass drug administration
    2. To check for recrudescence.
  • Two criteria for TAS:
    1. Microfilaria prevalence should be less than 1% even after the 5th mass drug administration MDA.
    2. More than 65% coverage in the population in each MDA.
  • TAS is done in 2 places:
    1. Schools
    2. Community
  • 2 methods of TAS :
    1. Cluster survey
    2. Systematic sampling

Diagnostic tools:

  • ICT (Immunochromatographic Test)
  • Brugia Rapid.

Extra Edge:

Criteria for (ELF) Elimination of lymphatic filariasis (i.e. it ceases to be public health problem):

  • Microfilaria carriers being < 1% of population.
  • Children born after initiation of ELF are free from circulating antigenemia (presence of adult filaria worm in human body).
  • WHO recommends triple therapy of Ivermectin + Diethylcarbamazine + albendazole to achieve the target, set to eliminate lymphatic filariasis by 2020.

Option A/ B/ C: Plasmodium vivax/ Plasmodium falciparum/ Leishmania donovani

  • Transmission Assessment Survey is done for lymphatic Filariasis → caused by Wuchereria bancrofti.
  • Therefore, these are incorrect choices.

Learning Objective

  • Transmission Assessment Survey is done for lymphatic Filariasis → caused by Wuchereria bancrofti.
  • WHO recommends triple therapy of Ivermectin + Diethylcarbamazine + albendazole to achieve the target, set to eliminate lymphatic filariasis by 2020.

questions.text: A 53-year-old female is admitted to the post-operative floor after a mastectomy for a large malignant phyllodes tumor. On the 2nd post-operative day, the output from the suction drain is 80ml for 24 hours. The intern accidentally removed the drain on 3rd postoperative day. On examination, the patient has oozing serosanguinous fluid from the wound with swelling around the wound. Which of the following can prevent this condition?

choices.text: Aspiration under aseptic conditions and pressure dressing

questions.solution:
Option C: Re-insertion of the drain

  • This patient with wound swelling and serosanguinous discharge after mastectomy has likely developed a seroma.
  • Seroma is one of the most common and earliest complications of mastectomy or modified radical mastectomy.
  • It develops in the dead space under the skin flap created by removing the breast tissue or lymph node dissection.
  • This complication can be prevented using appropriate surgical techniques to minimize the dead space beneath the skin flaps.
  • It can also be prevented by placing suction drains under the skin flap to introduce negative pressure and reduce the dead space.
  • Suction drains are removed when output is <30cc/day for 2 consecutive days to minimize the risk of seroma formation.
  • Accidental removal of the drain results in the formation of seroma and discharge of serous or serosanguinous fluid.
  • Management of seroma involves fluid aspiration; however serial aspirations increase the risk of infection.
  • The definitive management of high-output seroma (as seen in this patient) is the re-insertion of the suction drain until the daily output is <30ml for 2 days.

Option A: Open incision and saline gauze placement

  • Open incision and removal of the seroma may be required for cases that persist for weeks and recur after serial aspirations.
  • This patient does not need an open incision or surgical exploration on her 3rd post-operative day.

Option B: Aspiration under aseptic conditions and pressure dressing

  • Aspiration of the seroma and pressure dressing are temporary measures to manage seroma formation.
  • These techniques do not help prevent the recurrence of seroma.

Option D: Wait and watch

  • Seromas increase the risk of infections and lymphoedema; hence, the wait-and-watch policy is not a management option for these patients.
  • In addition, seromas do not tend to resolve independently and require intervention.

questions.text: The baby came for immunization for 1st time at 18 months. Which vaccine can be given?
questions.solution:
Option B: Only DPT booster and OPV

  • A completely unimmunized child 18 months of age should receive:
    • BCG (Only after Mantoux Test: Indirect BCG).
    • DPT-1 (Next two doses one month apart each and booster after 1 year of 3rd dose).
    • OPV-1 (Next two doses one month apart each and booster after 1 year of 3rd dose).
    • Measles (If not suffered from measles disease previously).
    • Vitamin A (2 Lac IU).

Option A: Only Pentavalent vaccine

  • The pentavalent vaccine has 5 components- Diptheria, Pertusis, Tetanus, Hep-B, and HiB.
  • The Component of the Pentavalent vaccine Hep B should be given before 1 year of age.
  • In our case, the baby is 18 months old. Hence pentavalent is not recommended. 

Option C: Pentavalent, OPV, DPT, and Measles

  • DPT-1 (Next two doses one month apart each and booster after 1 year of 3rd dose).
  • OPV-1 (Next two doses one month apart each and booster after 1 year of 3rd dose).
  • Measles (If not suffered from measles disease previously).
  • The Component of the Pentavalent vaccine Hep B should be given before 1 year of age.
  • In our case, the baby is 18 months old. Hence pentavalent is not recommended. 

Option D: Only BCG 

  • Direct BCG: Is administered up to 1 year of age, without Mantoux Test.
  • Indirect BCG: Beyond age 1 year, it is recommended after the prior Mantoux Test.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man complains of double vision worse on the left side for two weeks, without history of headaches, trauma, or other ocular complaints. Past medical history includes type 1 diabetes since age 10. During clinical examination, ocular motility towards both left and right sides is tested, as shown below.



Which of the following cranial nerves are involved in the clinical presentation shown below?
questions.solution:
Option C: Abducent Nerve

  • In the scenario described above, the signs and symptoms are consistent with abducent nerve palsy.
  • The abducent nerve (sixth cranial nerve) supplies the lateral rectus of the eye, which is responsible for the abduction of the eyeball.
  • Abducent nerve palsy results in the failure of abduction of the eyeball of the ipsilateral eye. It commonly manifests as binocular diplopia, which is most prominent in the direction of the affected side and better in the direction of the unaffected side.
  • The picture above shows the patient has right-sided abducent nerve palsy and, thus, non-functioning right lateral rectus muscle.
  • The top of the picture shows the neutral position of the eye while looking straight ahead. In the neutral position of the eye, the right eyeball is slightly medial to the neutral position because of the unopposed medial rectus muscle of the right eye.
  • The patient is asked to look towards the right side in the middle picture. The right lateral rectus and the left medial rectus are supposed to be used in this movement, but the right eyeball remains in the neutral position due to the right lateral rectal palsy.
  • The bottom picture asks the patient to look towards the left side. The right medial and left lateral rectus are supposed to be used in this movement and result in the normal movement of both eyeballs.
  • The common etiologies of the abducent nerve palsy include trauma, diabetic neuropathy, ischemia, pseudotumor cerebri, space-occupying lesions, and cavernous sinus thrombosis.
  • Abducent nerve palsy requires the patient to turn his or her head to see in the affected direction of gaze to avoid the development of diplopia; however, both the head-turning and diplopia are abolished by patching of the paretic eye.

Option A: Oculomotor Nerve

  • The Oculomotor is the third cranial nerve and innervates all extraocular muscles except the superior oblique and the lateral rectus.
  • In addition to the innervation of the extraocular muscles, the oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris and regulates pupillary reflexes in one way or the other.
  • Oculomotor nerve palsy results in an eye looking outwards and downwards, ptosis of the eyelid, and impaired pupillary light reflexes.

Option B: Trochlear Nerve

  • The trochlear (fourth cranial nerve) supplies the superior oblique muscle responsible for the eyeball's downwards and inwards rotation.
  • Hence, trochlear nerve palsy causes an ipsilateral higher eye (hypertropia) and excyclotorsion (eyeball looking upwards and outwards owing to the unopposed action of the inferior oblique muscle).
  • This results in vertical/torsional diplopia worsening on the downgaze or gazes away from the affected side.

Option D: Optic Nerve

  • The optic nerve (second cranial nerve) is responsible for vision and visual reflexes.
  • It does not innervate any extraocular muscles; hence, second nerve palsy can lead to impaired vision and visual reflexes. ​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 58-year-old obese man presents with the complaint that his eyes are continuously active, making several scanning saccades each second for the last 1 week. The attending doctor said that this was due to the cerebellar lesion. Which cerebellar nucleus is involved in such movements?
questions.solution:
Options C: Fastigial

  • The caudal fastigial nuclei are the output nuclei by which the cerebellum influences the production of visual saccades.
  • Cerebellum plays an important role in the control of eye movements
  • The cerebral hemispheres are extremely important for the programming and coordination of both saccadic and pursuit conjugate eye movements
  • The vestibulocerebellum (flocculus and nodule) is involved in gaze holding, smooth pursuit and the vestibulo-ocular reflex.
  • The dorsal vermis and fastigial nucleus play a major role in programming accurate saccades and smooth pursuit.
  • The cerebellar nuclei are given in the picture below:

Cerebellar Nuclei

  • On each side-4 Nuclei
  • Lat. – med.
  1. Dentate nucleus
  2. Emboliform nucleus
  3. Globose nucleus
  4. Fastigial nucleus

 

Option A: Dentate

 

  • Dentate nucleus is the latest (in evolution) and lateral most (in location).
  • It functions for smooth performance of highly skilled voluntary movements of precision

Option B: Emboliform

  • Interposed nuclei (emboliform & globose).
  • Working with para vermal area.
  • Feedback mechanism from joints to have proper coordination of joint.
  • Control crude movements of limbs

Option D: Globose

  • Interposed nuclei (emboliform & globose).
  • Working with para vermal area.
  • Feedback mechanism from joints to have proper coordination of joint.
  • Control crude movements of limbs

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with pustular acne is taking oral isotretinoin for therapy. She has been married for two years and is now planning to conceive. What is to be done about her isotretinoin therapy?

choices.text: To be stopped the day she tests positive for pregnancy
To be stopped 3 months before planning conception
To be stopped at least a year before planning pregnancy

questions.solution:
Option C: To be stopped 3 months before planning conception.

  • Isotretinoin is effective for treating severe acne, but it is a category X drug according to FDA (Food and Drug Administration)
    • Category X medications are contraindicated in women who are or may become pregnant. They may cause fetal harm.
    • Exp: rubella vaccine, vitamin A, tetracycline, androgens, lithium, etc.

 

  • It is recommended that a woman should stop taking isotretinoin 3 months before trying to become pregnant.

 

Option A: Can continue without harm.

  • It can’t be continued as isotretinoin is highly teratogenic.

 

Option B: To be stopped the day she tests positive for pregnancy.

  • Isotretinoin must be stopped three months before trying to conceive. 

 

Option D: To be stopped at least a year before planning pregnancy.

  •  Stopping isotretinoin 3 months before trying to conceive is sufficient.

questions.text: A 30 years old sexually active man comes to the doctor's office with complaints of low-grade fever, malaise, sore throat, lymph node swelling, and multiple cutaneous lesions, as shown in the image below. On examination, deep dermal tenderness was noted when the lesions marked in the image were pressed with a pinhead. This finding is seen in which stage of syphilis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Secondary syphilis

Secondary syphilis

It is a sexually transmitted condition occurring 2-12 weeks after developing primary syphilis. Characteristic findings of secondary syphilis are:-

  • Buschke Ollendorff sign: Deep dermal tenderness on pressing the papular lesions of syphilis with a pinhead.
  • Cutaneous or mucosal rash along with fever, swollen lymph nodes, sore throat, headaches, fatigue, weight loss, and muscle aches.
  • Usually, no vesiculobullous lesions are seen.
  • The copper-colored macular rash is seen on the trunk, extremities, palm & sole.
  • Condyloma lata: These are flesh-colored or hypopigmented, macerated papules or plaques present on the genitals.
  • Moth-eaten alopecia is seen.

Investigation:

  • Non-specific: VDRL/ RPR.
  • Specific: FTA-ABS (fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test) or, TPPA (treponema pallidum particle agglutination test).

Treatment: A single dose of long-acting benzathine penicillin G injection.

Option A: Primary syphilis

Clinical features:

  • Single, painless genital ulcer with a clean base.
  • Rubbery / shotty lymphadenopathy with firmly indurated base.
  • Diagnosis: Dark ground microscopy shows corkscrew-shaped treponema pallidum with spiral movement.
  • Treatment: Benzathine penicillin.

Option C: Latent syphilis

  • <2yrs is early latent; >2yrs is late latent.
  • Clinical features: If 2 syphilis isn't treated, it converts into latent syphilis, C/F is absent, and serological tests are positive.
  • IOC: Enzyme immunoassay.
  • DOC: Benzathine penicillin.

Option D: Tertiary syphilis

  • If patient in latent phase is not diagnosed & treated, tertiary syphilis develops.
  • Clinical features
    • Gumma: Rubbery nodules may ulcerate; ulcers have punched-out edges washed leather with base.
    • CVS features Aneurysm in ascending aorta and valvular heart disease (aortic regurgitation).
    • CNS (Neuro) features General Paresis of Insane (GPI) (psychiatric abnormality) and tabes dorsalis (gait abnormality).
  • IOC: CSF-VDRL (Look for CSF pleocytosis that corresponds to treatment.
  • DOC: Benzathine penicillin (3 doses, i.e.,7.2MU).

questions.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India, has launched a national initiative on the 15th of May, 2015 Kayakalp award. Which of the following is the correct reason the Kayakalp award is given for?
questions.solution:
Option D: Hygiene and infection control

  • KAYAKALP is a Government initiative, and the purpose of this initiative is to appreciate and recognize their effort to create a healthy environment.

  • Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India, launched a national initiative on the 15th of May 2015 to promote cleanliness and enhance the quality of public health facilities.
  • Those District Hospitals, Sub-divisional hospitals, Community Health Centres, Primary Health Centres and Health & Wellness Centres in the public healthcare system who have achieved high levels of cleanliness, hygiene and infection control were recognised and felicitated with awards.
  • Objectives:
    • To promote cleanliness, hygiene and infection control practices in public healthcare facilities, through incentivizing and recognizing such public healthcare facilities that show exemplary performance in adhering to standard protocols of cleanliness and infection control.

Other options

Option A: Hospital administration

  • KAYAKALP does not include hospital administration.

Option B: Hospital management

  • Hospital management is not included.

Option C: Leadership

  • The purpose of this initiative is to appreciate and recognize their effort to create a healthy environment. The name of this initiative is “KAYAKALP”.

questions.text: A nephrology professor refers to a case of 30-year-old male patient who presented to the nephrology clinic complaining of oliguria, burning micturition, high-grade fever, and generalized body weakness from the last six days. After investigations and examination, he was suspected of suffering acute kidney injury. The professor later gives a questionnaire at the end of the lecture inquiring about the net filtration rate, stating capillary and interstitial hydrostatic pressures of 30 mm of Hg and 5 mm of Hg and colloid oncotic pressure of capillaries and interstitium of 25 mm of Hg and 5 mm of Hg. The question sought the calculation of net filtration pressure for this patient. What would it be?
questions.solution:
Option A: 5 mm Hg

Given the values, capillary and interstitial hydrostatic pressures of 30 mm of Hg and 5 mm of Hg and colloid oncotic pressure of capillaries and interstitium of 25 mm of Hg and 5 mm of Hg

  • NFP = (PC+ πif) - (Pif + πP)
    • Pc → Capillary hydrostatic pressure 
    • πif → Plasma oncotic pressure
    • Pif → Interstitial hydrostatic pressure
    • πP → Capillary oncotic pressure

 

  • NFP = (30+5) - (25+5) = 5 mm Hg

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was one among the 5 people who had died after being exposed to some poisonous fumes at the factory she was working in. By the time the body was brought for an autopsy, the doctor noticed that there was Chocolate brown hypostasis in the back, over the buttocks, thighs, and posterior side of the arm. This can be secondary to exposure to any one of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hydrogen sulphide

  • In H2S poisoning it's bluish green; red discoloration.

Option B/C/D: Aniline/ Nitrites/ Potassium chlorate

  • Chocolate brown hypostasis can be seen in Potassium chlorate, Aniline, and Nitrite poisoning.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the clinic after an acute episode of hemoptysis and bouts of coughing over the last 6 hours. He has been a known case of bronchogenic cancer for the last 2 years. He is planning for a bronchoscopy. The pulmonologist is performing the bronchoscopy in the procedure room of the outpatient department of a tertiary care hospital. To make the instrument safe for the next patient waiting outside, what is the most appropriate method to disinfect the endoscope after using by this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: 2% glutaraldehyde for 20 min

  • The patient has been a known bronchogenic cancer for the last 2 years. He is here for a bronchoscopy.
  • The most appropriate method to disinfect the endoscope is 2% glutaraldehyde for 20 min.
  • For sterilizing all scopes – we use 2% glutaraldehyde (Cidex).
  • Except for the stethoscope – for which we use:
  • Isopropyl alcohol.
  • Formaldehyde.
  • Liquid formalin.
  • 2 % glutaraldehyde (Cidex) is used for cleaning:
  • Cystoscopes and bronchoscopes.
  • Endoscopes.
  • Corrugated rubber anaesthetic tubes and face masks.
  • Plastic endotracheal tubes.
  • Metal instruments.
  • Polythene tubing.

 

Uses of CIDEX

  • A disinfectant 
  • A tanning agent in leather
  • To sterilize endoscopic instruments, thermometers, rubber or plastic equipment which cannot be heat sterilized 

 

  • Disinfects objects within 20 min.
  • Available in inactive form & activated by alkalinization before use.
  • Remains active only for 14 days.

Option A: 70% alcohol for 5 min

  • It is the most common and widely used disinfectant:
  • Pharmaceutics
  • Hospitals
  • Cleanrooms
  • Electronics or medical device manufacturing
  • Different solutions
  • Purity grade concentrations

Option C: 2% formaldehyde for 10 min

  • It is a colourless poisonous gas formed by the oxidation of methanol
  • It is an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications.

Option D: 1% sodium hypochlorite for 15 min

  • It is used in hospitals as a high-level disinfectant for some types of equipment.
  • It is used in lower concentrations.
  • It is rarely used as an antiseptic.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old male presents with fever and altered sensorium for two days with the following rash on his legs. Her BP is 70/50 mm Hg, and Neck stiffness is present. The doctor sends her for lab examinations. Lumbar puncture reveals cloudy CSF. Which of the following correctly describes the organism causing this condition?


	
		
			Cerebral spinal fluid (CSF)
			4200 cells/uL
		
		
			Protein level
			198
		
		
			Glucose
			21mg/dL

choices.text: Gram-negative diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose
Gram-positive cocci catalase negative, bacitracin sensitive

questions.solution:
Option B: Gram-negative diplococci ferments glucose and maltose

  • It is the case in which history and clinical presentation suggest Meningococcal Meningitis. Meningococcal Meningitis is caused by Neisseria meningitidis
  • Gram-negative diplococci ferment with glucose and maltose correctly describe the organism causing this condition.
  • Neisseria meningitidis is a gram-negative diplococcus that is encapsulated and lens-shaped. This pathogen ferments glucose and maltose. It can be both extracellular and intracellular.
  • Meningococci spreads by droplet infections in which the lungs are involved. Meningitis is the inflammation of the protective membrane covering the brain or spinal cord. Bacterial meningitis is rare but a more deadly condition with a high mortality rate if left untreated.

Option A: Gram-negative diplococci (kidney-shaped), oxidase-positive

  • Neisseria gonorrhoea is the causative agent in this. It is a pathogen that is primarily involved in sexually transmitted diseases.
  • It is a gram-negative diplococcus which is kidney-shaped and oxidase positive. Mainly non-capsulated and ferments with glucose only.
  • This bacteria is mainly intracellular and causes urethritis, cervicitis, and ophthalmia noenatorum.

Option C: Gram-positive cocci catalase negative, bacitracin sensitive

  • Streptococcus pyogenes is the pathogen here. It is a gram-positive coccus present in the chains.
  • It is catalase-negative and bacitracin sensitive. These bacteria are extracellular. Children are more susceptible to them.

Option D: Gram-positive diplococci (lanceolate), catalase negative, optochin sensitive

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is the microbe in this scenario. It is gram-positive diplococci with a lanceolate or flame-shaped appearance.
  • It is a catalase-negative and optochin-sensitive bacteria. They are the leading cause of pneumococcal infection.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrics OPD with complaints of irritability, poor feeding, and vomiting. His mother also added that his urine smells like burnt sugar. After a proper physical examination, his urine sample is sent to the laboratory for analysis. Which of the following amino acids will not be found in this patient’s urine test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B : Phenylalanine

  • This patient is suffering from maple syrup urine disease. A burnt sugar-like smell is a characteristic feature of this disease.
  • Valine, isoleucine, and leucine will be found in urine tests, but not phenylalanine.
  • Phenylalaine is present in the urine in case of phenylketonuria patients which also show musty body odor.

Option A, C and D: Leucine, Isoleucine, Valine

Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD):

  • It is a rare autosomal recessive disease.
  • Typically present in children between 5 months to 7 years of age.
  • It occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched-chain keto-acid decarboxylase resulting in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids - valine, isoleucine, and leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in the urine.
  • It may cause increased alfa-ketoacid in blood, especially leucine.
  • Typical clinical presentation includes poor feeding, irritability, vomiting, loss of appetite, and poor muscle tone.
  • Urine smells like maple syrup or burnt sugar.
  • It may cause progressive neurological decline.
  • Mental retardation may occur due to increased isoleucine.
  • In untreated cases, the disease may progress to life-threatening coma or respiratory failure, and death can occur within a few months.
  • Treatment: Isoleucine, leucine, and valine restriction in diet and thiamine supplement.

questions.text: Bedwetting >5 nights per week and episodes of daytime urgency in an 11-year-old girl.HPI: Mom has tried limiting fluid intake after 5 p.m. and placing her on the toilet at night. She's never been dry for more than six months. She is quite humiliated. FHX: My older sister was prone to bedwetting. What is the most effective treatment for nocturnal enuresis in children?
questions.solution:
The synthetic antidiuretic hormone analog desmopressin (DDAVP) acts to reduce urine production whilst the child is asleep and is effective at producing dry nights in 50 percent of children.

It is available as an oral tablet or as a nasal spray which is preferred by most children.

  1. Bed alarms (behavioral therapy)- TOC
  2. Desmopressin (DOC)
  3. Imipramine (TCA Antidepressant)


HOW TO REMEMBER: Children learn alphabets. D is before I. Try desmopressin before imipramine.

questions.text: A 71-year-old male of CKD III presented with a syndrome suggestive of chronic tubulointerstitial disease. He had a history of longstanding, intermittent flank pain which began in his 50s ascribed to nephrolithiasis, although no stone was ever seen. On further workup, a non-contrast CT scan showed characteristic 'Atrophic kidney with papillary calcification in a garland pattern'. What would be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Analgesic Nephropathy

  • Long-term use of analgesic preparations containing phenacetin, aspirin, and caffeine
  • Atrophic Kidney with Garland Pattern
  • Because of decreased PG

questions.text: A 43-year-old female presents to the emergency department with gradually worsening shortness of breath, fatigue, and exertional chest pain. Upon further examination, there is a loud P2 heard on auscultation. An x-ray is done, showing the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pulmonary artery hypertension

  • Given X-ray shows a prominent descending right pulmonary artery - giving a "Jug handle" appearance, which signifies Pulmonary artery hypertension.
  • Pulmonary hypertension is a form of high blood pressure that impacts the arteries that are located in the lungs as well as the right side of the heart.
  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension, also known simply as PAH, is a subtype of pulmonary hypertension that occurs when arteries in the lungs become constricted, clogged, or damaged. As a result of the injury, blood flow through the lungs becomes more restricted, which leads to an increase in blood pressure within the lung arteries. To force blood into the lungs requires an increased effort on the part of the heart. The additional work will, in the long run, lead the heart muscle to become frail and eventually fail.

Signs and symptoms of pulmonary hypertension:

  • Cyanosis
  • Chest pressure or pain
  • Vertigo and possible episodes of fainting (syncope)
  • A rapid pulse or a heartbeat that is hammering (palpitations)
  • Fatigue
  • Dyspnea, or shortness of breath, occurs initially during physical activity and eventually even when the patient is at rest.
  • Oedema in the lower extremities, specifically the ankles, legs, and finally, the abdominal region (abdomen).

 

Option A: Aortic dissection

  • Aortic dissection is seen on a CT scan.

Option B: Coarctation of the aorta

  • Coarctation of the aorta shows 3 signs on X-ray.

Option D: Boot-shaped heart

  • Tetralogy of Fallot shows a Boot shaped heart.

questions.text: A 45-years-old female presented to the emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and lethargy for the past 1 day. On a general physical examination, the woman looks dehydrated with a pulse of 110 beats/minute, blood pressure of 98/64 mmHg, temperature is 101°F, and oxygen saturation of 96% at room air. She has a history of diabetes mellitus type 1 with poor compliance with her insulin regime. Blood glucose level is high, and serum ketones are 3.2mmol/dl. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: 500ml of 0.9% Saline over 15 minutes and a fixed rate insulin infusion
500ml of 0.9% Saline over 15 minutes with potassium chloride and a fixed rate insulin infusion
500ml of 0.9% Saline over 30 minutes with potassium chloride and a rapid-acting subcutaneous insulin injection
500ml of 0.9% Saline over 30 minutes and a rapid-acting subcutaneous insulin injection

questions.solution:
Option B:  500ml of 0.9% Saline over 15 minutes with potassium chloride and a fixed-rate insulin infusion.

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is an acute complication of diabetes mellitus(more common in type 1 DM).
  • It is a life-threatening medical emergency.
  • It is caused by insulin deficiency and excess glucagon, leading to severe hyperglycemia and accelerated ketogenesis.
  • Severe hyperglycemia leads to osmotic diuresis, causing dehydration and volume depletion.
  • Elevated ketone bodies cause metabolic acidosis.
  • Elevated lipolysis leads to increased free fatty acids and more ketogenesis from free fatty acids producing ketone bodies (beta-hydroxybutyrate, acetoacetate, and acetone).
  • DKA  is precipitated by stress or illness such as infections, trauma, myocardial infarction, stroke, recent surgery, sepsis, gastrointestinal bleeding, or inadequate insulin administration.
  • Clinical presentation
    • Vomiting, Nausea, Fever.
    • Kussmaul breathing (rapid, deep breathing), fruity (acetone) breath odor,
    • Abdominal pain (may mimic acute abdomen with guarding and rigidity), dehydration, tachycardia, polydipsia, polyuria, weakness, and altered mental status (drowsiness, confusion, delirium, psychosis, and coma).
  • Laboratory values will show
    • Hyperglycemia (serum glucose >450 mg/dl and <850mg/dl),
    • Low serum pH (pH <7.3) and bicarbonate (<15mg/dl), and high anion gap metabolic acidosis(due to the production of acidic ketone bodies),
    • Leukocytosis, increased urine, and blood ketone levels (serum levels of acetone, acetoacetate, and beta-hydroxybutyrate are raised), leukocytosis, hyponatremia (sodium levels fall by 1.6mEq/l for every 100mg/dl rise in glucose levels),
    • Elevated serum amylase and increased serum potassium(due to acidosis, potassium is shifted from the intracellular to the extracellular compartment; however, total body potassium is low).
  • The management of diabetic ketoacidosis is as follows:
    • Intravenous(IV)/subcutaneous(SC) regular insulin: 500ml of 0.9% Saline over 15 minutes with potassium chloride and a fixed rate insulin infusion. Regular insulin is the only type of insulin that can be given intravenously and subcutaneously.
    • In emergencies such as DKA, hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state, and acute hyperkalemia, IV regular insulin is given. Subcutaneous regular insulin is given just as the diagnosis is made. A dose of regular insulin of 0.1 units/kg is given IV as the primary dose, followed by an infusion of regular insulin of 0.1 units/kg/hour in 0.9%saline. Continue the insulin until the anion gap is corrected. Give subcutaneous insulin when the patient starts eating again.
    • Fluid replacement is done with IV normal saline. 5% or 10% dextrose can be added when the blood glucose levels fall to 200mg/dl.
    • Potassium replacement is done prophylactically with IV fluids. Due to insulin deficiency, potassium efflux from the cells into extracellular space, and serum potassium levels are falsely elevated. Insulin infusion causes potassium to move back into the cells, causing hypokalemia, which is dangerous as it can cause arrhythmias. So KCl is added to IV fluids with insulin to avoid hypokalemia.
    • If serum potassium levels are <3.5 mmol/l, then insulin should be held, and 20-30mmol/l KCl is given until serum potassium is >3.5mmol/l.
    • If serum potassium levels are 3.5-5.2mmol/l, then KCl is given along with IV fluids to maintain serum potassium levels at 4-5mmol/l.
    • If serum potassium levels are >5.2 mmol/l, then there is no need to add KCl in saline infusion.
  • Complications of DKA include
    • Life-threatening mucormycosis, cerebral edema, cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, respiratory fatigue and failure, and pulmonary edema.

Option A: 500ml of 0.9% Saline over 15 minutes and a fixed rate insulin infusion.

  • Insulin causes an influx of potassium ions into the cells leading to hypokalemia. So KCl should be added to the saline and insulin infusion while treating DKA.

Option C: 500ml of 0.9% Saline over 30 minutes with potassium chloride and a rapid-acting subcutaneous insulin injection

  • Regular insulin is the only preparation of insulin that can be given intravenously. In emergencies such as DKA, intravenous insulin treatment is preferred.

Option D: 500ml of 0.9% Saline over 30 minutes and rapid-acting subcutaneous insulin injection.

  • Rapid-acting insulin can not be given intravenously. In DKA, regular intravenous insulin is given.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents to the emergency with severe pain behind his right eye for the last 30 minutes. He states that his right eye has also been 'watering excessively' for the last two hours. The man has had similar episodes over the last few weeks. Still, the pain is significantly worse this time, prompting him to present to the E.R. The vitals are normal, and the ophthalmic examination demonstrates conjunctival injection and miosis of the right pupil. A CT scan of the brain and ESR are unremarkable. Which is the initial treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: High-flow oxygen

  • This patient is suffering from cluster headache, and the abortive measure for cluster headache is a High flow of oxygen
  • A cluster headache is a Unilateral and periorbital headache that is associated with ipsilateral autonomic symptoms such as:
    • lacrimation
    • rhinorrhea
    • Horner's syndrome
    • Duration is 15 minutes - 3 hours
  • 1st line of treatment:
    • High flow oxygen at 12-15 L/min
    • To prevent future episodes of cluster headaches: Verapamil

Option A: Sumatriptan

  • 1st line treatment for Migraine headache: Sumatriptan/Rizatriptan

Option B: Rizatriptan

  • Rizatriptan and sumatriptan are both first-line treatments for acute  migraine headache

Option C: Steroids

  • Steroids are used for the prevention of further attacks of Migraine

questions.text: A 25-year-old  infertile female presents to Gynaecology OPD with a complaint of menorrhagia over the last 6 months. She looks pale and reports cyclical lower back pain from the last 2 months. On her examination, an abdominal mass is palpable, which is immobile. On vaginal examination, the uterus and appendages are fixed. Which of the following is irrelevant in the medical management of this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Misoprostol

  • A history of menorrhagia, a fixed uterus, and appendages suggest endometriosis. All of the given drugs are used for endometriosis except misoprostol. So, it is an irrelevant option in management.
  • Endometriosis is a disorder where tissue resembling the uterus lining grows in some places, such as the ovaries and fallopian tubes. Endometriosis affects women of any age.
  • The examination may reveal a cystic pelvic mass suggestive of ovarian endometriosis, a fixed retroverted uterus (suggestive of pelvic adhesions), tenderness, or nodularity in POD (suggestive of peritoneal deposits).
  • Drugs used for medical management of endometriosis are:
    • Oral contraceptive pills
    • Mirena: LNG IUCD
    • Progesterone: Dienogest, Medroxyprogesterone, dydrogesterone
    • Androgens: Danazol
    • GnRH analogues 
    • Mifepristone

 

Option A: Danazol

  • It causes suppression of GnRH and gonadotropin secretion, direct inhibition of steroidogenesis, and increased metabolic clearance of estradiol and progesterone.
  • These effects produce a local high androgen low estrogen environment that does not support the growth of endometriosis.
  • Hence it is the right option.

 

Option B: Progestins

  • They exert an anti-endometriotic effect by causing initial decidualization of endometrial tissue followed by atrophy.

 

Option C: GnRH analogues

  • They cause downregulation of GnRH secretion, resulting in low LH and FSH and, finally, low ovarian estrogen and progesterone production, providing a medically reversible menopause-like state.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, P2L2 with heavy uterine bleeding is diagnosed to have a uterine fibroid. Neither does she want a hysterectomy nor any regular long-term medications. All of the following are treatment options, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Management of uterine fibroids
Medical Surgical
  • GnRH agonist
  • GnRH antagonist
  • Mifepristone
  • Danazol
  • Low dose OCP
  • Ulipristal acetate
  • LNG IUCD
  • Myomectomy

Laparoscopic

Hysteroscopic

Vaginal

Abdominal

  • Hysterectomy

Abdominal

Vaginal

Laparscopic

laparoscopic assisted vaginal

  • Uterine artery embolization
  • Myolysis
  • MRI-guided focussed USG
  • High frequency focussed USG

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with cough and sputum production, fever with chills, night sweats, and rigor for the last six days. On examination, his blood pressure is 105/65mmHg, his heart rate is 99 beats per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 91%. Crepitations present and reduced breath sounds on the right side. The chest X-ray has been done, and the findings are given below. Which of the following is an indication of the surgery?

choices.text: Lung abscess unresponsive to medical management

questions.solution:
Option A: Lung abscess unresponsive to medical management

  • Based on the symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is lung abscess.
  • A lung abscess that is unresponsive to medical management is an indication for surgery.
  • Lung abscess is characterized by necrosis of the lung tissue and the formation of cavities containing necrotic debris, mostly caused by microbial anaerobic infection.
  • The formation of multiple small (less than 2 cm) abscesses is sometimes referred to as necrotizing pneumonia or lung gangrene.
  • The usual symptoms are fever, cough with sputum production, night sweats, anorexia, and weight loss.
  • The expectorated sputum is characteristically foul-smelling and bad tasting.
  • Diagnostic Tests:
    • A complete white blood cell count with differential may reveal leukocytosis and a left shift.
    • Obtain sputum for gram stain, culture, and sensitivity.
    • If tuberculosis is suspected, an acid-fast bacilli stain and mycobacterial culture should be requested.
    • A blood culture may help establish the etiology.
    • Bronchoalveolar lavage
  • Treatment:
    • Medical:
      • The standard treatment for an anaerobic lung abscess is clindamycin.
      • An antibiotic regimen should include coverage against S. aureus, Enterobacter, and Pseudomonas species in hospitalized patients who have aspiration pneumonia and then develop a lung abscess.
      • When methicillin-resistant Staph aureus (MRSA) is suspected, vancomycin and linezolid should be used.
      • The antibiotics should generally be prescribed for 4-6 weeks.
    • Surgery:
      • The surgical procedure done is either lobectomy or pneumonectomy.

Option B: Asthma exacerbation

  • The patient has a diagnosis of lung abscess, and there is no indication of surgery for asthma exacerbation.
  • The signs and symptoms of asthma exacerbations are as under:
    • Breathlessness
    • Coughing
    • Wheezing
    • Chest tightness
    • Agitation
    • Tachypnea
    • Tachycardia

Option C: Acute pulmonary edema

  • Acute pulmonary edema is mostly due to increased capillary hydrostatic pressure secondary to increased pulmonary venous pressure.
  • The major complications associated are respiratory fatigue and failure.
  • Common symptoms are:
    • Shortness of breath
    • Diaphoresis
    • Dyspnea on exertion
    • Orthopnea
    • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea
    • Cough
    • Pink, frothy sputum may be present in patients with severe disease.
    • Auscultation of the lungs usually reveals fine crepitations.

Option D: Mild Community-acquired pneumonia

  • Community-acquired pneumonia is an infection of the pulmonary parenchyma that is acquired outside of the hospital.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae and respiratory viruses are the most common pathogens in patients with CAP.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with benign prostate hyperplasia presents with blood in urine and severe pain. Recent tests showed multiple bladder stones. He's been taking alpha-blockers for 6 years and is prepared for surgery. During surgery, he developed vomiting and altered sensorium. What's the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dilutional hyponatremia

  • Trans urethral resection of the prostate (TURP) is the surgical procedure for benign prostate hyperplasia. The indications of surgery in this patient are :
    • Failure of medical treatment
    • Bladder stones are a complication of BPH    
  • Cysto-urethroscopy is done. It is the procedure in which a 26Fr resectoscope with a 30-degree telescope is introduced per-urethra into the bladder. The prostate is visualized and assessed for size. The bladder is seen for stones. Tissues are cut from the bladder neck by a diathermy loop mounted in front of the scoop.
