First median lobe and then lateral lobes are resected. Chips of a prostate pass to the bladder, and these pieces and stones are evacuated by the Ellik evacuator.
  • For continuous irrigation, a three-way Foley catheter is passed. The irrigation is done with normal saline to avoid clot retention.
  • This continuous irrigation with fluid (glycine) may be absorbed into the circulation, leading to dilutional hyponatremia. This condition is called TURP syndrome. It is the most common complication of TURP surgery.
  • The treatment is:       
    • Fluid restriction
    • Diuretics
    • Hypertonic saline 3% infusion
  • The risk of TURP syndrome increases with resection time > 90 minutes or gland size > 75 gm.

Option B: Dilutional hyperkalemia

  • By irrigation of saline, hyponatremia occurs, which causes altered sensorium.

Option C: Rupture of bladder

  • It can be a complication of surgery, but it is not associated with vomiting and altered sensorium.

Option D: Hemorrhage

  • Hemorrhage can be a complication during this surgery, but to a less extent, that can be tolerated by this patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with perianal discharge, flatus, and stool coming out from an opening. Medical history of diabetes, hypertension, and tuberculosis but non-compliant with medications. He had an anorectal abscess two years ago, which was surgically removed. On examination, the external opening was found at the 4 o'clock position to the anus. What is the location of the internal opening according to Goodsall's rule ?
questions.solution:
Option D: 6'o clock

  • This is the case of fistula-in-ano presented with discharge, the passage of flatus, and feces from an opening near the anal orifice, indicating a connection with the rectum/anus. The risk factor in this case: male gender, tuberculosis, and a history of anorectal abscess. The location of the internal opening is 6'o clock according to Goodsall's law.
  • Goodsall's rule is applied to predict the location of the internal opening.

  • Anterior openings usually have straight tracks hence the location of external and internal openings are in the same position.
    • For example, the location of the external opening is at 1'o clock position the location of the internal opening is also at 1'o clock position.
  • Posterior openings usually follow a Curved track, so the location of external and internal openings are not the same.
    • For example, if an external opening is at 4,5,6,7,8,'o clock, Internal opening may be at the 6'o clock position.
  • Exceptions to this rule include multiple external openings and external openings more than 3cm away from the anal verge; in these cases, the Posterior rule is applied.

Option A: 3'o clock

  • The posterior tract follows a curved path.
  • Hence external opening at 4'o clock cannot have an internal one at 3'o clock.

Option B: 4'o clock

  • The posterior tract follows a curved pathway.
  • Hence internal and external openings cannot be in the same position.

Option C: 5'o clock

  • The posterior tract follows a curved pathway according to Goodsall's rule.
  • Hence external opening at 4'o clock cannot have an internal one at 5'o clock.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male was referred to your hospital from a local hospital, where he was followed up for liver cirrhosis induced by 4 years of chronic alcoholism. His condition was complicated by alcohol-induced encephalopathy, delirium tremens, portal hypertension, and arrhythmia. On endoscopic examination, the existence of abdominal ascites, pedal edema, clammy skin, and esophageal varices. Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) Scoring was done, which placed him in class C. What of the following probable treatment?
questions.solution:
Option A: Liver transplantation

  • This patient has cirrhosis; the complication is portal hypertension manifested in variceal bleeding with ascites.
  • The child's class 'C' score means no surgical intervention should be done → Best treatment is liver transplantation.
  • Patients with variceal bleeding who are transplantation candidates include
    • Alcoholic cirrhotic patients with limited hepatic functional reserve (Child-Pugh class B and C).
    • There is poor quality of life secondary to the disease (encephalopathy, fatigue, bone pain ), and intervention should be done.
  • Child-Pugh classification:
Clinical and lab criteria Point 1 Point 2 Point 3
Encephalopathy None Grade 1 or 2 Grade 3 or 4
Ascites None Mild to moderate (diuretic responsive) Severe (diuretic refractory)
Bilirubin (mg/dL) <2 2-3 >3
Albumin (g/dL) >3.5 2.8 - 3.5 <2.8
Prothrombin time      
Seconds prolonged  <4 4 - 6 >6
International normalized ratio <1.7 1.7 - 2.3 >2.3

Option B: Major surgery

  • Major surgery is indicated in Class B, Child-Pugh Classification.

Option C: Minor surgery

  • Minor surgery is indicated in Class A, Child-Pugh Classification.

Option D: TIPS

  • TIPS is a transjugular intrahepatic portal-systemic shunt.
  • This procedure is used to relieve portal hypertension.
  • Hepatic encephalopathy is a notorious complication of TIPS.

questions.text:
Calculate the Sensitivity and Specificity of ELISA in a population screened for HIV. Data is given below.


	
		
			 
			HIV Present
			HIV Absent
		
		
			ELISA +ve
			80
			40
		
		
			ELISA -ve
			20
			60
questions.solution:
Option B: 80%, 60%

  HIV Present HIV Absent
ELISA + ve 80 = a 40 =b
ELISA -ve 20 = c 60 =d

 

  • Sensitivity = a/a+c x 100

= 80/100 X 100

= 80%

  • Specificity = d/b+d x 100

= 60/100 X 100

= 60%

Option C: 66.6%, 75%

  • PPV= a/a+b x 100

= 80/120 X 100

= 66%

  • NPV= c/c + d

=60/80 X 100

= 75%

questions.text: Photograph shown below overall depicts:
questions.solution:
• Given image shows the complete course of disease from pathological onset to eventual resolution (in absence of treatment or intervention) which depicts the Natural history of disease.
  • The natural history of disease is best established by Cohort studies.
  • Natural History of Disease has 2 steps:
    • Period of pre-pathogenesis: Where we can try to prevent & control the disease by applying primordial or primary level of prevention.
    • Period of pathogenesis: Disease has shifted into body where we can do secondary & tertiary level prevention.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man complains of drooping of eyelids of both eyes for the last 2 months. He can open his eyes when he first wakes up, but a few hours later, his ptosis worsens with diplopia. On examination, extraocular movements are normal initially, which get worse on repeated movements. Muscle strength in all four limbs is 5/5, deep tendon reflexes are +2, and there is no sensory deficit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Myasthenia gravis

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease (IgG and T cell-dependent). It is characterised by significant muscle weakness and muscle fatigue after repeated movements.

  • Pathophysiology:

    • This happens because of decreased availability of acetylcholine receptors (AChR) at the postsynaptic membrane due to their destruction by anti-AChR antibodies (85% present).

    • Other antibodies associated with Myasthenia Gravis are muscle-specific kinase antibodies (Anti-MuSK), which are present in 10% of patients, and antibodies to low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (anti-LRP4).

    • It is linked to anomalies in the thymus. The thymus is abnormal in 75% of patients, hyperplastic in 65%, and thymoma in 10%.

  • Clinical features:

    • Age: Typically between the age of 20 and 30 for women and 50 to 60 for men. It is more common in females (F: M ratio of 3:2).

    • Progressive weakness and fatigability of muscles increase with repeated use or late in the day and improve with rest or sleep.

    • Initially, cranial muscles, particularly eyelid and extraocular muscles are involved, causing ptosis and diplopia.

    • Other symptoms include facial weakness, weakness in chewing, speech difficulty (nasal voice, dysarthric speech), swallowing difficulty that increases the risk of aspiration and generalised limb weakness. Involvement of the diaphragm causes respiratory depression.

    • Deep tendon reflexes are normal.

    • Infections or systemic illnesses can worsen weakness and may lead to a myasthenic crisis.

  • Diagnosis:

    • Ice-Pack Test.

    • Autoantibodies include anti-AChR antibodies, anti-MuSK antibodies, and anti-LRP4 antibodies.

    • Electrodiagnostic Testing: decremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation.

    • Edrophonium or Tensilon test: rapid improvement is seen in a patient with Myasthenia gravis on edrophonium administration.

    • CT chest or MRI of the chest to rule out thymoma.

    • Pulmonary function tests.

  • Management:

    • Anticholinesterase medications, e.g., pyridostigmine.

    • Thymectomy.

    • Immunotherapy medications include glucocorticoids, mycophenolate mofetil, azathioprine, and rituximab.

    • IVIG or plasmapheresis for severe weakness or myasthenic crisis. Ventilatory support (diaphragm involvement).

Option A: Thyroid ophthalmopathy

  • Thyroid-associated ophthalmopathy is an autoimmune process commonly associated with Graves' disease.

  • It is characterised by orbital soft tissue involvement such as eyelid retraction (not ptosis), proptosis, extraocular muscle dysfunction, chemosis, and optic neuropathy.

  • The patient may also have symptoms of hyperthyroidism, which are not present in this patient.

Option B: Horner’s syndrome

  • It is a triad of miosis, ptosis and anhidrosis that affect only one side of the face.

  • Common causes include Brainstem stroke, carotid dissection, and neoplasm compressing on the sympathetic chain (Pancoast tumour), but most cases are idiopathic.

Option D: Third nerve Palsy

  • The third cranial nerve, or oculomotor nerve, has two components:

  1. Parasympathetic fibres supply the ciliary muscles and the sphincter pupillae.

  2. Somatic fibres supply the levator palpebrae superioris in the eyelid, superior, middle, inferior recti, and inferior oblique muscle.

  • Damage to the oculomotor nerve results in:

  1. Paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle leads to ptosis, which is constant and does not improve on rest, unlike in myasthenia gravis.

  2. Deviation of eyes due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique brings the eye in a "downward and outward" position and causes diplopia.

  3. Mydraisis due to due to paralysis of sphincter pupillae

  4. Loss of accommodation due to paralysis of the ciliary muscle.

  • This patient presents with features of Myasthenia gravis, not third nerve palsy.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought by his mother to Ophthalmology OPD with an abnormal head posture while reading and writing. He is not having any pain or other complaints. On examination, the right eye shows Entropia. The doctor suspects it to be strabismus. A refraction test is advised for further evaluation and confirmation of this condition and measurement of its angle. Which of the following drug is used before doing this test?
questions.solution:
Option B: Atropine

  • The most common cause of squint in children is accommodative esotropia, i.e. due to uncorrected refractive error, which in children is mostly hypermetropia.
  • So for refraction testing, we need the cycloplegic drug to paralyze the ciliary muscles and reveal the true refraction of the child.
  • This drug is used to both prevent and treat specific eye problems as well as eye exams like refraction and such as uveitis.
  • It is a member of the anticholinergic drug family.
  • The smaller the children, the more powerful the accommodation.
  • The most powerful cycloplegic drug is atropine, which is indicated in children below 5 years old.

Option A: Pilocarpine

  • Glaucoma and other eye diseases are managed with pilocarpine.
  • It is also used To treat presbyopia and utilize eye drops (age-related eye or vision problems).
  • Pilocarpine is parasympathomimetic and thus not used.

Option C: Tropicamide

  • Tropicamide is less potent than cycloplegic.
  • Tropicamide is used to dilate (enlarge) the pupil so the medical professional can see behind your eye.
  • It is used before eye examinations like cycloplegic refraction and fundus examinations.
  • Tropicamide can be applied both before and following eye surgery.

Option D: Lidocaine

  • Lidocaine is a member of the class of drugs known as local anesthetics.
  • Before several surgeries, this medication is injected into the eye to create numbness or lack of feeling.
  • It functions by obstructing the signals at the eye's nerve terminals.
  • Lidocaine is a local anesthetic and not a cycloplegic.

questions.text: Which of the following antihyperlipidemic drugs exerts its effects through the inhibition of PCSK9?
questions.solution:
Option C: Alirocumab

  • In the above case, the features are suggestive of hypercholesterolemia for which we use PCSK9 inhibitors such as Alirocumab.
  • Monoclonal antibodies that target PCSK9: Alirocumab and Evolocumab.
  • Proprotein convertase subtilisin Kexin type 9 (PCSK9) is a protein that binds LDL receptors and transports them to lysosomes, where these are degraded.
  • Therefore instead of recycling LDL receptors to the surface of hepatocytes, they get destroyed.
  • Inhibitors of PCSK9, therefore, prevent the destruction of LDL receptors resulting in the lowering of LDL cholesterol.

Option A: Reslizumab

  • It is an interleukin-5 antagonist monoclonal antibody. IL-5 is the major cytokine responsible for the growth and differentiation, recruitment, activation, and survival of eosinophils.
  • The most common adverse effect of reslizumab is oropharyngeal (mouth and throat) pain.

Option B: Brodalumab

  • It is a human monoclonal antibody designed for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.
  • Brodalumab binds to the interleukin-17 receptor and so prevents interleukin 17 (IL-17) from activating the receptor.

Option D: Ixekizumab

  • It is an injectable medication for the treatment of autoimmune diseases.
  • The substance acts by binding interleukin 17A and neutralizing it, reducing inflammation.
  • The most common side effects include upper respiratory infections, injection site reactions and fungal (tinea) infections.

questions.text: A 64-year-old patient with ischemic heart disease arrived in the emergency room with coughing, shortness of breath, and bilateral foot swelling. He has a pulse of 140 beats/minute, irregular rhythm, blood pressure of 70/50 mmHg, bilateral pedal edema, and fine crepitation at the base of his lungs. Dobutamine is needed for inotropic support, but it's not accessible in the emergency trolley. What alternative medication or combination of medications can offer a similar pharmacological effect to dobutamine?
questions.solution:
Option C: Norepinephrine plus phentolamine

  • The patient is a known case of ischemic heart disease and presented with clinical manifestations of cardiogenic shock. The inotrope of choice used in such situations is dobutamine.
  • Dobutamine acts mainly on the β1 receptor.
  • Dobutamine increases inotropy and chronotropy and reduces left ventricular filling pressure.
  • Noradrenaline stimulates α1,α2 and β1 receptors, but phentolamine is an α blocker.
  • Noradrenaline produces potent vasoconstriction as well as a modest increase in cardiac output. Reflex bradycardia occurs in response to the increased mean arterial pressure (MAP). The mild chronotropic effect is cancelled out, and the heart rate remains unchanged or decreases slightly.

  • Thus, the combination providing the same effect as dobutamine is noradrenaline and phentolamine

Option A: Dopamine (at a very high dose)

  • Dopamine at very high doses stimulates D1, β1, and α1.
  • It will increase peripheral vasoconstriction and, thus, afterload, aggravating the clinical condition of cardiogenic shock.

Option B: Ephedrine plus propranolol

  • Ephedrine leads to the release of noradrenaline which will stimulate α1,α2 and β1 receptors.
  • Propranolol will block the β receptor.
  • So net effect of ephedrine and propranolol would be stimulation of α1 and α2 receptors.

Option D: Methoxamine plus atropine

  • Methoxamine is an α1 agonist.
  • Atropine is a muscarinic blocker.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male is diagnosed with cancer of the head of the pancreas and is posted for Whipple's procedure. Being a surgeon, you would know that the anatomical important structure __________ is present immediately posterior to the pancreatic head.
questions.solution:
Option A:Right renal vein

  •  Immediately behind the head of the pancreas, we have 3 veins,
  •  Right renal vein.
  •  Left renal vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava.
  • Along with 2 veins inferior vena cava is behind the head of the pancreas.

Pancreas

  • The pancreas is a glandular organ and it is located retroperitoneum.
  • Embryologically it is developed from the foregut.
  • It is located in between the duodenal curvature and splenic hilum.
  • It is both exocrine and endocrine in nature.
  •  It has 4 parts
    • Head
    • Neck
    • Body and tail
  • It receives blood supply from the celiac trunk and its branches.

Option B: Splenic artery

  • The splenic artery is the branch of the celiac trunk.
  • It is superior to the pancreas before turning into a splenorenal ligament to the hilum of the spleen.

Option C: Inferior mesenteric vein

  • It arises from the splenic vein.
  • It arises from the midbody of the pancreas before the junction of the splenic and superior mesenteric veins.

Option D: Coeliac trunk

  • It supplies to the foregut of the GI tract.
  • It arises from the abdominal aorta.
  • It provides three branches left gastric, common hepatic, and splenic arteries.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male has an eight-month history of progressive abdominal swelling, gross hematuria with flank pain, and a weight loss of 20 kg over two years. Physical examination reveals a palpable mass in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory examination shows low hemoglobin levels, high platelets, and alkaline phosphate. The patient was diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma invading the inferior vena cava and renal vein through an abdominal CT scan.which of the following is true in management and evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: Chest X-ray could be done to rule out pulmonary metastasis

questions.solution:
Option D: Chest X-ray could be done to rule out pulmonary metastasis

  • Clinical signs: Hematuria, left flank pain and progressive abdominal distension are the symptoms. The palpable mass, mildly tender in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen, indicates renal cell carcinoma.
  • Chest X-ray could be done to rule out pulmonary metastasis.
  • Renal cell carcinoma:
    • Five Histological subtypes are Clear cell carcinoma, Papillary carcinoma, Chromophobe type, Bellini duct tumor, and Medullary carcinoma.
    • Male: Female–2:1. Risk factors are age, sex, hypertension, obesity, and tobacco smoking.
    • Clinical presentation includes loin pain, mass, and hematuria (the most common presentation).
    • Indications of partial Nephrectomy: Size <4 cm, RCC in a solitary kidney, bilateral RCC (familial syndromes), and RCC with diseased contra-lateral kidney.
    • A radical nephrectomy is done when there is a large-size tumor.
    • The metastatic tumor is removed by cytoreductive nephrectomy, adrenals are not mandatory, and ureters are removed until the pelvic brim.
    • Patients with renal vein or IVC involvement by renal cell carcinoma but without evidence of metastatic disease are the surgical candidates.
  • Occasionally, nephrectomy and removal of IVC tumor thrombus need to be done.

Option A: A Pre-op biopsy is necessary

  • A pre-op biopsy is unnecessary as it is diagnosed with radiology and on a clinical basis.

Option B: IVC involvement indicates inoperability

  • Patients with renal vein or IVC involvement by renal cell carcinoma but without evidence of metastatic disease remain surgical candidates.
  • Occasionally, nephrectomy and removal of IVC tumor thrombus need to be done.

Option C: Pre-op radiotherapy is essential

  • Pre-op radiotherapy is not required as long as the candidate is still a candidate for surgical removal. After that, radiotherapy may be needed as per demand.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is presented to the physician by his mother with complaints of right foot swelling for three days. He has no history of any other abnormalities. There is no family history of lymphedema. The patient if febrile. On physical examination, the right foot had pitting edema and a positive Stemmer’s sign. A lymphoscintigram was performed to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following will be the most common bacterial infection that can occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Streptococcus

  • This is a case of erysipelas in which the patient is brought to the physician with complaints of right foot swelling for 3 months.
  • A lymphoscintigram was performed to confirm the diagnosis of erysipelas.
  • It is the most common complication of both primary and secondary lymphedema.
  • Erysipelas is caused by streptococcus infection.
  • Cellulitis may occur concurrently with lymphedema because of pooling of protein-rich lymph fluid makes it easier for the patient to develop an infection.

Option A: Staphylococcus

  • Erysipelas is usually not caused by staphylococcus infections.
  • Staphylococcus bacteria commonly cause cellulitis.

Option C: E. coli

  • Escherichia is a gram-negative bacterium.
  • It can cause:
    • Diarrhea
    • Urinary tract infection.
  • E. coli shows lactose fermenting and non-mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar.

Option D: Pseudomonas

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an aerobic gram-negative bacterium.
  • It is a non-spore-forming rod.
  • It usually causes infections in immunocompromised patients.
  • It can cause UTI.
  • It doesn’t cause erysipelas.

questions.text: A professor is giving a lecture on plasma osmolality and gives an example of a woman who runs a marathon in 32.2°C (90°F) weather. After the race, she feels exhausted, and thirsty and drinks plenty of distilled water. It replaces all volume lost in sweat. Which of the following statements is true regarding her body's fluid status?
questions.solution:
Option D: Decreased plasma osmolarity

  • Plasma osmolarity is the concentration of solutes in plasma.
  • By sweating and then replacing all volume by drinking H2O, the woman has a net loss of NaCl without a net loss of H2O.
  • Therefore, her extracellular and plasma osmolarity will be decreased; as a result, water will flow from extracellular fluid (ECF) to intracellular fluid (ICF).

Option A: Decreased total body water (TBW)

  • Total body water (TBW) will be unchanged because the woman replaced all volume lost in sweat with drinking water.

Option B: Decreased hematocrit

  • Hematocrit will be increased because of the shift of water from ECF to ICF and the shift of water into the red blood cells (RBCs), which causes their volume to increase.

Option C: Increased extracellular fluid (ECF) volume

  • By sweating and then replacing all volume by drinking H2O, the woman has a net loss of NaCl without a net loss of H2O.
  • Water will flow from extracellular fluid (ECF) to intracellular fluid (ICF), and the ECF volume will be decreased.

questions.text: A psychiatrist is being called to the emergency department to assess a 40-year-old woman. The patient has a history of chronic depression. "My belly and chest are empty," she says. "My organs have all died. I'm not here. I'm no longer alive." Which of the following best describes her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option C: Nihilistic delusions

  • Nihilistic delusions are characterized by fixed, false beliefs that one is dead (as the above patient says that her organs have died) or does not exist ("I am no longer alive"), that one's body is breaking down, or that the world around them does not exist ("I am not here," as the above patient says).
  • Nihilistic delusions:
    • The term 'annihilate' comes from the root 'nihilistic,' which signifies destruction or death. People who suffer from nihilistic delusions feel they are disintegrating, their bodies don't work, their internal organs are rotting or hardening, or they are genuinely dead.
    • A mnemonic to remember this is: Nihilistic people feel NILL and dead.

Option A: Paranoid delusions

  • Paranoid delusions are based on the constant and fixed irrational fear that someone or some group will mistreat, harm, and sabotage the affected person.
  • The symptoms described in the above case do not suggest any fear of being harmed, so paranoid delusion is not the correct option.

Option B: Delusions of persecution

  • Delusions of persecution are characterized by suspicion of being cheated on, conspired against, or harassed.
  • The symptoms described in the above case do not suggest any suspicion of being cheated or conspired against, so this is not the correct option.

Option D: Delusions of reference

  • Delusions of reference imply that the patient believes that normal events are of special importance to them.
  • The symptoms described in the above case do not suggest any idea of reference, so this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with asthma was admitted to the hospital for breathing problems and coughing. He was given two drugs, A and B, intravenously every 24 hours for 6 days. What does the graph showing the concentration of these drugs in the blood over time reveal?

choices.text: Drug A does not maintain persistent therapeutic levels when administered every 24 hours
Drug B is non-cumulative when administered every 24 hours
Drug B is destroyed in less than 24 hours

questions.solution:
Option A: Drug A does not maintain persistent therapeutic levels when administered every 24 hours

  • In this case, the patient presented with an acute exacerbation of asthma. He has been admitted to the ward and two drugs are given intravenously. A graph is plotted between the time duration and concentration of the drugs in blood.
  •  From the graph, Drug, A does not maintain persistent therapeutic levels when administered every 24 hours.
  •  The drug concentration reaches zero by the time the next dose is administered.
  • Drug A is non-cumulative when administered every 24 hours because its concentration is never more than first-day peak levels

Option B: Drug A exhibits cumulative properties

  •  Drug B exhibits cumulative properties, not A and its concentration constantly increases with every dose.
  • Drug A concentration decreases to zero every 24 hours.

Option C: Drug B is non-cumulative when administered every 24 hours

  •  Drug A is non-cumulative when administered every 24 hours because its concentration is never more than the first day's peak levels.
  • Drug B exhibits cumulative properties, not A and its concentration constantly increases with every dose.

Option D: Drug B is destroyed in less than 24 hours

  •  Drug B is not destroyed in less than 24 hours and shows cumulative properties.
  • Drug A is destroyed in less than 24 hours and its concentration reaches zero by the time the next dose is administered.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to the outpatient department accompanied by her mother with complaints of weakness in his lower limbs for the past few months. His mother adds that he still has urinary incontinence. Examination reveals scoliosis and a tuft of hair over the skin of the lumbar spine. There is atrophy of muscles in the lower limbs, power is 3/5, and deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. X-ray spine reveals the two lumbar vertebrae at that level are fused. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Diastematomyelia

  • Diastematomyelia is a type of spinal dysraphism (spina bifida occulta) when there is a longitudinal split in the spinal cord.
  • It results either from a fibrous band or bony spicule.
  • Diastematomyelia is of two types: 
    • Type I: Duplicated dural sac, with common midline spur (osseous or fibrous) and usually symptomatic
    • Type II: Single dural sac containing both hemicords; impairment less marked.

  • Patients can present with the following symptoms:
    • Gait disturbance
    • Scoliosis
    • Neurological deficits
    • Bladder or bowel problems
    • Foot deformities
  •  patients with mild type II may be minimally affected or entirely asymptomatic.

Option A: Hemivertebra

  • Rare Congenital spine malformation.
  • It can be fully segmented, semi-segmented, incarcerated, or non-segmented.

Option C: Sacrococcygeal teratoma

  • A tumor that develops from a baby's coccyx before birth.

Option D: Spinomuscular Dystrophy

  • It is a genetic disorder
  • Characterized by muscle wasting and weakness.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought in by his mother to the Pediatric department with complaints of delayed walking and learning disability over the previous year. She reports that her child has been mentally disabled since birth. His detailed history taken from his mother is suggestive of delayed developmental milestones. The child's examination reveals a large face, mandible, large everted ears, and macro-orchidism. CGG repeat sequence is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Fragile x syndrome

  • The case mentioned above has clinical features of mental retardation and has examination findings such as a large face, mandible, large everted ears, and macroorchidism, suggesting Fragile X syndrome.
  • Fragile X syndrome is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.
  • Features in males include:
    • Difficulty in learning
    • May have large, low, set ears, a long thin face, and high arched palate.
    • Macroorchidism
    • Hypotonia
    • Autism
    • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Symptoms in females with one fragile chromosome and one normal X chromosome range from normal to mild.
  • Diagnosis can be made antenatally by chorionic villus sampling or amniocentesis and by analysis of the number of CGG repeats using restriction endonuclease digestion and Southern blot analysis.

Option B: Huntington's Disease

  • Huntington's disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder.
  • It manifests between the ages of 30 and 50 years.

Option C: Dentatorubropallidolusyian atrophy

  • Dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy, commonly known as DRPLA.
  • It is described as a progressive neurological disorder causing involuntary movements and decreased mental abilities.
  • The age of onset of DRPLA is usually 30 years.

Option D: Machado joseph disease

  • Machado-Joseph disease (MJD) is also known as spinocerebellar ataxia 3/ SCA3.
  • It’s the most common dominant ataxia.
  • It usually appears between 30 and 40 years of age.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his son, complaining of the inability to move his left arm and leg. According to his son, the patient was reading a book 30 minutes ago when he could not raise his left arm to pick up a different book. While attempting to move away from the table, the patient noticed that his left leg also became extremely weak. Finally, he felt as if everything in his vision had doubled. A history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia is significant. His temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), blood pressure 165/100 mmHg, pulse 85 beats/min, and respirations 16 breaths/min. On examination, there is right-sided ptosis, and his right eye is directed inferiorly and laterally. When asked to smile, the left corner of the mouth droops. His left upper and lower extremity strength is 3 out of 5, while his right upper and lower extremity strength is 5 out of 5. Which of the following areas of his brain has become ischemic?
questions.solution:
Option C: Midbrain

  • With baseline hypertension and hyperlipidemia, this patient has crossed neurologic deficits as evidenced by left hemiparesis and right-sided oculomotor palsy (classic "down and out" presentation due to unopposed lateral rectus and superior oblique action) with ptosis. Hence, this patient probably has Weber syndrome, caused by a stroke affecting the right side of his midbrain.
  • Weber syndrome is a constellation of neurological symptoms resulting from ischemic damage to the midbrain.
  • It is most often caused by occlusion of the peduncular perforating branches of the posterior cerebral artery. This mainly affects the brainstem (where the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts pass) and oculomotor fibres.
  • As a result, patients develop ipsilateral oculomotor deficits (eye downward and outward, diplopia and ptosis) and contralateral hemiparesis.
  • A closely related midbrain syndrome is Benedict syndrome. In a more paramedian region of the insult, the medial lemniscus and red nucleus are affected and cause contralateral hemianesthesia with impairment of proprioception.

​​​​​​​Option A: Internal capsule

  •  Infarcts of the internal capsule are lacunar infarcts that occur due to the occlusion of small penetrating arteries that supply deeper structures. It is called the pure motor stroke. It will not cause isolated involvement of cranial nerve 3.

Option B: Medulla

  • Medullary infarcts can cause medial and lateral medullary syndromes.
  • The medial medullary syndrome is caused by occlusion of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery or vertebral artery. It manifests as ipsilateral hypoglossal palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, and contralateral lemniscus loss.
  • The lateral medullary syndrome is caused by posterior inferior cerebellar or vertebral artery occlusion and presents with ipsilateral vestibular abnormalities, dysphagia, dysarthria, hoarseness, gait ataxia, and absent gag. There is further loss of pain and temperature sensation in the ipsilateral face and contralateral body.

Option D: Occipital lobe

  • Occipital lobe infarct can be seen with posterior cerebral artery occlusions. Classically, patients present with contralateral hemianopsia with macular sparing. The macula is spared due to collateral flow from the middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for converting T4 to T3 in the periphery?
questions.solution:
Option A: D1 thyroid deiodinase

Deiodinase enzymes:

  • Three deiodinases act on thyroid hormones: D1, D2, and D3.
  • All are unique, and they contain the rare amino acid selenocysteine, with selenium in place of sulfur, which is essential for their enzymatic activity.
  • D1 is in high concentrations in the liver, kidneys, thyroid, and pituitary. It appears to be primarily responsible for maintaining the formation of T3 from T4 in the periphery. This is because excess T3 substrate causes upregulation of the D1 deiodinase, which leads to increased conversion of T3 to T4.
  • D2 is present in the brain, pituitary, and brown fat.
  • D3 is also present in the brain and reproductive tissues. It acts only in the 5th position of T4 and T3 and is probably the main source of RT3 in the blood and tissues.

Option B: D2 thyroid deiodinase

  • D2 thyroid deiodinase is an enzyme of the outer ring
  • Does not get inhibited by propylthiouracil, however, gets inhibited by amiodarone.
  • Excess T4 causes D2 protein degradation
  • The active site has selenocysteine.

Option C: D3 thyroid deiodinase

  • D3 thyroid deiodinase is an enzyme of the inner ring.
  • Does not get inhibited by propylthiouracil or amiodarone.
  • Substrate T3 induces the D3 deiodinase expression

Option D: Thyroid peroxidase

  • Thyroid peroxidase oxidizes the iodide to iodine and then incorporates this into the carbon 3 position of tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin in the organification process.
  • The first product is monoiodotyrosine (MIT); MIT is next iodinated on the carbon 5 positions to form diiodotyrosine (DIT). Two DIT molecules then undergo an oxidative condensation to form T4 by eliminating the alanine side chain from the molecule that forms the outer ring.

questions.text: In a couple undergoing in-vitro fertilization for 4 years, which resulted in the birth of a female child today, if a sample is drawn for investigation, at which stage of meiosis would the oocyte be?
questions.solution:
Option A: Prophase I

  • At the time of birth, the oocyte is dormant in the diplotene stage (resting stage during prophase I) in all females, regardless of the type of conception- natural/ IVF.
  • Stages of prophase- I
    • Leptotene
    • Zygotene
    • Pachytene
    • Diplotene
    • Diakinesis

Option B: Metaphase I

  • In metaphase I, the homologous pairs of chromosomes align on each side of the equatorial plate. The secondary oocyte is arrested in the metaphase-2 stage of meiosis II, which is completed when fertilization occurs.

Option C: Anaphase I

  • Anaphase I is the 3rd stage of meiosis I & follows prophase I & metaphase I.
  • Sister chromatids of every chromosome separate & start to move towards the opposite pole of the cell. The separation and the movement are because of the shortening of the kinetochore microtubules.

Option D: Telophase I

  • Telophase I is the last stage of meiosis 2 followed by telophase II. Four daughter cells are formed
  • Nuclear membranes form around each set of chromosomes & decondensation of the chromosomes occurs. Cytokinesis splits the sets of chromosomes into new cells, four haploid cells.

questions.text: The national plan of action of the Government of India focuses on under-served areas with an emphasis on community participation. It facilitates the formation of state-level Vision 2020- plans of action and programmes led by the state governments, along with intensive input from local and international NGOs. According to the Indian version of Vision 2020, which of the following diseases is not included?
questions.solution:
Option D: Onchocerciasis

  • Onchocerciasis is absent in India. Therefore, it is not included in Vision 2020: Right to sight by the WHO.
  • 'Vision 2020: The Right to Sight',10 is a global initiative launched by WHO in Geneva on Feb. 18, 1999, in a broad coalition with a 'Task Force of International Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs) to combat the massive problem of blindness in the world.
  • The objective of Vision 2020:

This new global initiative aims to eliminate avoidable blindness by the year 2020 and to reduce the global burden of blindness, which currently affects an estimated 45 million people worldwide.

  • Strategic approaches of Vision 2020: Right to Sight (Global perspective) are:
    • Disease prevention and control,
    • Training of eye health personnel,
    • Strengthening of existing eye care infrastructure,
    • Use of appropriate and affordable technology, and
    • Mobilisation of resources.
  • Disease prevention and control: Globally, WHO has identified five major blinding eye conditions for immediate attention to achieve the goals of Vision 2020, which are:
    • Cataract
    • Childhood blindness
    • Trachoma
    • Refractive errors and low vision
    • Onchocerciasis
  • These conditions have been chosen based on their contribution to the burden of blindness, feasibility and affordability of interventions to control them.
  • Each country will decide its priorities based on the magnitude of specific blinding conditions in that country.

Option A: Diabetic retinopathy

  • Diabetic retinopathy is considered in place of onchocerciasis in the Indian version of the right to sight.

Option B: Glaucoma

  • Glaucoma has been included in Vision 2020: Right to sight by WHO.

Option C: Refractive error

  • Refractive errors and low vision have been included in Vision 2020: Right to sight by WHO.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman underwent oophorectomy for a unilateral ovarian tumor. Histopathology shows the tumor to be of germ-cell origin. Which of the following is NOT a possible diagnosis in the woman?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mesonephroid tumors (Clear cell carcinoma)

  • A mesonephroid tumor is an epithelial tumor and not a germ cell tumor and is most commonly seen in older women.
    • Also known as clear cell carcinoma.
    • Uncommon tumor of the ovary.
    • Highly malignant.
    • Composed of large cuboidal epithelial cells with abundant clear cytoplasm.

 

 

Primitive germ cell tumors

 

 Biphasic/ triphasic teratoma

 

 Monodermal and somatic tumors associated with dermoid cysts

 
Dysgerminoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Embryonal
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor
 Immature teratoma
  • Mature teratoma
 Thyroid tumor
  • Carcinoid
  • Neuroectodermal tumor
  • Melanocytic
  • Sarcoma
  • Sebaceous tumor
  • Pituitary type tumor

 

Option B: Teratoma

  •  A teratoma is a germ cell tumor that may contain immature tissues, including teeth, hair, bone, and muscle.
  • Teratomas may be malignant or benign and can affect people of all ages. Treatment involves surgical removal. Malignant teratoma may need chemotherapy and radiation therapy.

 

Option C: Dysgerminoma

  • It is a type of cancer that forms in germ cells in females.

 

Option D: Endodermal sinus tumor

  • An endodermal sinus tumor is also called a yolk sac tumor. Endodermal sinus tumors occur most often in small children and is a germ cell tumor.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a complaint of passing dark-colored urine and back pain for the past month. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the right costovertebral angle. His urine analysis report is shown below. Urine microscopic analysis reveals many RBCs, few WBCs, and no casts or crystals. The kidney lesion's typical gross appearance is depicted in the figure. Which one of the following components in this man's blood is most likely to be elevated

Urine Analysis Report


	
		
			
			pH
			
			
			6
			
		
		
			
			Specific Gravity
			
			
			1.015
			
		
		
			
			Hematuria
			
			
			2+
			
		
		
			
			Protein
			
			
			Nill
			
		
		
			
			Glucose
			
			
			Nill
			
		
		
			
			Ketones
			
			
			Nill
questions.solution:
Option C: Erythropoietin

  • The figure demonstrates renal cell carcinoma. In between 5% and 10% of these tumours, erythropoietin is secreted, resulting in polycythemia.
  • Erythropoietin production by renal cell carcinoma cells and cyst epithelial cells in the left kidney may cause polycythemia.
  • Serum urea nitrogen and creatinine levels are not raised, and renal function is not significantly lost since renal cell carcinomas are frequently unilateral and do not completely kill a kidney.
  • Erythropoietin is a glycoprotein produced mainly by the kidney and controls erythropoiesis. Increased erythropoiesis production results in secondary erythrocytosis, which is observed in various tumours, including renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, and cerebellar hemangioblastoma.
  • The lack of erythrocytosis in renal cell carcinoma patients with elevated erythropoietin levels may be explained by the possibility that renal cell carcinoma cells create an inactive isoform of erythropoietin.

Option A: Globulin

  • Globulin would be increased with multiple myeloma and lead to amyloid deposition, a diffuse process.
  • Increased gamma globulin proteins may indicate any acute infection

Option B: Cortisol

  • Corticotropin (adrenocorticotropic hormone) results in hypercortisolism in Cushing syndrome, but these cases are encountered less frequently than polycythemia. 
  • Cushing's disease can manifest as secondary polycythemia, and polycythemia can be the first sign of Cushing's disease.

Option D: Vasopressin:

  • A syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (vasopressin) is more likely a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with small-cell lung carcinomas.
  • Vasopressin also has a potent constricting effect on arterioles throughout the body

questions.text: An investigator is studying patients with acute decompensated congestive heart failure. He takes measurements of a hormone released from atrial myocytes and serial measurements of left atrial and left ventricular pressures. The investigator observes a positive correlation between left atrial pressures and the serum level of this hormone. Which of the following is most likely the mechanism of action of this hormone?

choices.text: Decreases sodium reabsorption at the collecting tubules
Increases potassium excretion at the collecting ducts
Decreases reabsorption of bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubules

questions.solution:
Option A: Decreases sodium reabsorption at the collecting tubules

  • Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) dilates the afferent arterioles and constricts the efferent arterioles, which increases the glomerular filtration rate by increasing the net filtration pressure.
  • Moreover, ANP decreases sodium reabsorption in the collecting tubules principal cells.
  • Using these two mechanisms, ANP promotes natriuresis in response to increased stretch on the atrial lumen to reduce the impact of volume overload.
  • While atrial myocytes release ANP upon stretching, ventricular myocytes liberate BNP, which has a similar effect but lasts longer than ANP.
  • Hence, BNP and NT-pro BNP levels are important serum markers for the diagnosis of CHF.

Option B: Increases potassium excretion at the collecting ducts

  • Increased potassium excretion at the collecting ducts occurs with hyperaldosteronism.
  • Aldosterone increases extracellular fluid.
  • In these patients, however, this mechanism would worsen cardiac congestion.
  • In this patient, ANP is released, which decreases potassium excretion.

Option C: Constricts afferent renal arteriole

  • Constriction of afferent arterioles decreases renal blood flow and reduces the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), reducing urine output and worsening congestion in patients with CHF exacerbations.
  • In contrast, the release of ANP in this patient attempts to compensate for volume overload by stimulating afferent arteriole dilation and promoting natriuresis.

Option D: Decreases reabsorption of bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubules

  • Decreased bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) leads to urine alkalinization and causes mild diuresis.
  • Although this might moderately decrease congestion in patients with CHF, this does not describe the mechanism of action of the ANP released in this patient.
  •  However, it describes the MOA of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide).

questions.text: Following is a non modifiable risk factor?
questions.solution:
Option C: Personality Type A 

  • It is a non modifiable risk factor

Other options

Option A: High BP

  • Modifiable risk factor

Option B: DM

  • Modifiable risk factor

Option D: Stress

  • Modifiable risk factor.

questions.text: The hemoglobin level of pregnant females in a community was found to have a mean of 10.6 g/dL and a standard deviation of 2 g/dL. What is the minimum hemoglobin level below which 5% of the pregnant females will have their hemoglobin levels?
questions.solution:
Option A: 7.32

  • 2.5% of the population will have a Hb less than (Mean – 2SD) = (10.6) – 2(2) = 6.6
  • Since we need a value below which 5% values will lie, we need a value between –1SD and –2SD i.e., between 6.6 and 8.6,
  • Hence, 7.32 is the only available value in this range.

questions.text: A 53-year-old menopausal woman presents with dirty white discharge and vaginal itching. She states that she never had vaginal infections before menopause. Her physician counsels her about the loss of vaginal defense mechanisms after menopause. Which of the following is the hormone responsible for vaginal defense?
questions.solution:
Option A : Estrogen

The vaginal defense mechanism depends upon Estrogen

  • Estrogen is responsible for the maturation of superficial cells of the vaginal epithelium and maintaining an acidic environment in the vaginal secretions. This acidity is mainly responsible for the resistance of the vagina to pathogenic organisms.
  • During the reproductive period with high estrogen, the vaginal defense is maximum
  • Post menopause, after the withdrawal of estrogen, the vaginal defense is lost.

Option B : Progesterone

  • Progesterone has no role in vaginal defense

Option C : FSH

  • FSH is responsible for follicle recruitment and maturation and has no role in vaginal defense

Option D : LH

  • LH is responsible for ovulation and maintainence of corpus luteum and has no role in vaginal defense.

questions.text: A 50 years male met with an accident and was brought to the emergency. O/E - BP = 100/70 mm Hg, Pulse= 96 bpm. X-ray Hip showed a bilateral Pelvic fracture. The patient's vitals are deteriorating, and he is suspected of developing Hypovolemic shock. The treating doctor advises transfusing 3 units of PRBC. The transfusion is started, but after 20 mins, the blood is found incompatible. Acute renal failure in this patient who received an incompatible blood transfusion with hemolytic reaction is best managed by:
questions.solution:
Option D: Stopping blood transfusion

  • Stop the transfusion immediately
  • Microvascular thrombosis and deposition of haemoglobin in the distal renal tubule can result in acute renal failure.
  • The extent of precipitation is inversely related to urine flow. I.V. fluids, vasopressors and diuretics should be given to maintain renal perfusion pressure and to produce diuresis.
  • If acute renal failure develops, haemofiltration should be considered.

Option A: 20% Mannitol

  • Mannitol can be used to cause diuresis and the excretion of toxins, but the first appropriate step will be stopping the transfusion

Option B: IV fluids with K+ supplementation

  • In hemolytic reaction, cells are lysed, and intracellular potassium is released, which causes hyperkalemia. Since there is already increased potassium, there is no point in its infusion

Option C: Alkalinizing the urine

  • Alkalinise the urine with IV sodium bicarbonate to keep haemoglobin soluble and reduce kidney tubular damage. Alkalization is monitored by urinary pH, which should be maintained greater than 6.5 or 7. But 1st step will be stopping the transfusion

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is brought to the operation theatre for heart valve surgery. He has a history of syncopal attacks on exertion and angina. The intra-operative appearance is shown below. Which kind of pulse is expected to present in this case before surgery?
questions.solution:
Option D: Anacrotic pulse

  • Valvular Aortic stenosis is the condition shown in the image.
  • Aortic stenosis, also known as aortic valve stenosis, is a form of disease that affects the heart's valves (valvular heart disease). The aorta is the major artery in the body, but the valve that leads from the lower left chamber of the heart to it is constricted and does not open all the way. Because of this, blood flow from the heart to the aorta and the rest of the body is reduced or blocked completely.

Symptoms of aortic valve stenosis:

  • A stethoscope can pick up an abnormal sound coming from the heart called a heart murmur.
  • Pain or tightness in the chest (angina) brought on by physical activity
  • Experiencing lightheadedness, vertigo, or fainting as a result of physical activity
  • Symptoms of shortness of breath, particularly during physical activity
  • A state of extreme tiredness, often during periods of intense activity
  • A heartbeat that is irregular and racing (palpitations)
  • Consuming insufficient food (mainly in children with aortic valve stenosis)
  • losing too much weight too quickly (mainly in children with aortic valve stenosis)
  • Examination Findings of Aortic stenosis include:
    • Pulsus parvus et tardus
    • Anacrotic pulse ( due to increase in ejection velocity)
    • Double apical impulse
    • Narrow/Paradoxical split S2
    • Ejection-systolic murmur

​​​​​​​Option A: Dicrotic pulse

  • Twice beating pulse palpable both in systole as well as diastole
  • It is seen in dilated cardiomyopathy

Option B: Pulsus bigeminus

  • A cardiovascular condition known as pulsus bigeminus is characterised by clusters of two quick heartbeats followed by an extended pause.

Option C: Pulsus bisferiens

  • Pulsus bisferiens is a Fast rising pulse with a fast fall.
  • Seen in Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented to the physician's office with a complaint of cold lower extremities as she had to wear warm socks even in the summer season. On physical examination, it was noticed that she had high blood pressure, and her femoral pulse was weak compared to radial and carotid pulses. Chest radiography showed remarkable notching of ribs along with their lower borders. Which of the following radiological sign is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: “Egg on side” appearance

  • This patient has coarctation of the aorta due to her high blood pressure, notching of ribs, and weak femoral pulse compared to carotid and radial pulses.

  • Transposition of great vessels involves the vascular pedicle which is characteristically narrow in the frontal plane because the pulmonary artery lies behind the aorta and not by its side.

  • The Heart is enlarged and takes the shape of an “egg on the side."

Coarctation of the Aorta

  • Coarctation of the aorta is the most common congenital cardiovascular cause of hypertension.

  • It is the luminal narrowing of a short section of the aorta.

  • It occurs most commonly at the site of insertion of the ductus arteriosus.

  • It develops from the presence of excessively integrated ductal tissue around the aortic isthmus, which contracts along with the ductus arteriosus during the point of involution at birth.

  • Systemic perfusion is compromised in cases of severe coarctation; in less severe cases, perfusion is maintained by systemic hypertension, which occurs proximal to the coarctation.

  • As a result, patients develop decreased lower body perfusion (beyond the coarctation) and unexplained hypertension.

  • The diagnosis may be confirmed by chest x-ray and Transesophageal echocardiography.

  • Rib notching is the most specific sign, and it occurs mainly in the fourth to the tenth ribs and appears by age 10.

  • The left border of the Heart shows the 3 signs.

  • Transposition of great arteries (TGA):

    • The vascular pedicle is characteristically narrow in the frontal plane because the pulmonary artery lies behind the aorta and not by its side.

    • The Heart is enlarged and takes the shape of an “egg on the side."

​​​​​​​

Option A: 3 sign

  • Figure 3 sign is formed by the pre-stenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian artery, the indentation of the coarctation site, and the post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.

  • A corresponding contour abnormality is a reverse figure 3 sign (or "E" sign).

Option B: Reverse 3 sign

  • The reverse 3 sign (also called the “E” sign) on barium swallow is seen as the medial equivalent of the figure 3 sign seen in chest radiographs. It is formed by the pre-stenotic dilation of the ascending aorta, indentation of the coarctation site, and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.

Option C: Normal Heart

  • Patients with coarctation of the aorta show notching of ribs, 3 sign, and reverse 3 signs due to the aortic stenotic segment with the associated pre and post-stenotic segments. In this disease, the Heart appears normal.​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 27-year-old young female comes to the office complaining of moderate to severe unilateral headache and photophobia for the last 24 hours. Her past medical history includes three similar episodes in the last 5 months. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no significant family history. On examination, her vitals are normal. After diagnosis, the physician prescribes a selective 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist for her condition. Which of the following drug acts on this receptor?
questions.solution:
Option C: Frovatriptan

  •  This patient's presenting symptoms (unilateral headache, photophobia) and history of recurring episodes mostly suggest a severe acute migraine.
  • Triptans like sumatriptan, frovatriptan etc., are the drug of choice for severe acute migraine.
  • These drugs are 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists.
  • Frovatriptan is the longest-acting among the triptans.
  • Two primary hypotheses have been proposed for their action:
    • Activation of 5HT1D/1B receptors on pre-synaptic trigeminal nerve endings inhibits the release of vasodilating peptides, and anti-seizure agents may suppress the excessive firing of these nerve endings.
    • Vaso-constricting action of direct 5HT agonists (triptans and ergot) may prevent vasodilation and stretch of pain nerve endings
  • Contraindications of triptans:
    • Hypertension
    • Ischemic heart disease
    • Epilepsy
    • Pregnancy
    • Liver and renal impairment

Option A: Buspirone

  • Buspirone is a 5-HT 1A receptor agonist used for anxiety disorders.

Option B: Ondansetron

  • It is a 5HT3 receptor antagonist used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

Option D: Ketanserin

  • It is a 5HT2 receptor antagonist with alpha-blocking properties.
  • It is used to treat hypertension.

questions.text: The average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span (15-44 or 49 years), assuming no mortality is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option B: Gross Reproduction rate

  • The gross reproductive age is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span (15-44 or 49 years), assuming no mortality.

Other options

Option A: Net Reproduction rate

  • Net reproduction Rate is defined as the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rate.

Option C: Total Marital Fertility rate

  • The average number of children that would be born to a married woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span.

Option D: Total Fertility Rate

  • The total fertility rate represents the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the woman in each group.
  • It is computed by summing the age-specific fertility rates for all ages.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He could neither straighten his leg nor extend it. A CT scan of his knee is given below. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Wire fixation

  • The CT scan of the patient shows a comminuted transverse fracture of the patella
  • Tension band wiring (TBW) would be the answer if it were present in options (Open reduction and internal fixation with tension band wiring)
  • K-wire is used to fixate the fractured segments of the bone
  • It is placed in a vertical figure of eight.
  • The tension provided by the wire causes early healing of the fractured bone.

Option A: Excision of a small segment

  • In Comminuted Transverse Fracture of the Patella
    • The bone has shattered into three or more pieces.
    • It can be stable or unstable.
    • Some bone pieces may be too small to reconnect when it is unstable and must be removed in surgery.

Option C: Plaster cylinder

  • Undisplaced patellar fractures with minimal joint incongruity and intact extensor retinaculum can be treated by cylinder cast.
  • ORIF and band wiring treat the comminuted transverse fracture of the patella.

Option D: Patellectomy

  • Patellectomy treats severely comminuted fractures where the reduction of the fragments is difficult.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented to the hospital with a high fever, chills, inflammation of lymphatic vessels, and swollen lymph nodes. On physical examination, the left leg of the patient was swollen with thickened skin. The clinical diagnosis of lymphatic filariasis was made by the physician. All of the following statements are true regarding Lymphatic Filariasis except?

choices.text: Main vector in India – Culex quinquefasciatus
Most common epidemiological method for detection – Thick film preparation

questions.solution:
Option B: Intermediate host – Man

  • The intermediate host in lymphatic filariasis is Mosquito.
  • Man is the Definitive host.

Option A: Causative agent – Wuchereria bancrofti

  • The causative agent of lymphatic filariasis is Wuchereria bancrofti.

Option C: Main vector in India – Culex quinquefasciatus

  • Main vector in India is Culex quinquefasciatus.

Option D: Most common epidemiological method for detection – Thick film preparation

  • Thick film preparation is the most common epidemiological method for detection.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company is studying a new antibiotic that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. When this antibiotic is added to an in-vitro protein synthesis system that is translating the mRNA sequence AUGUUUUUUUAG, the only product formed is the dipeptide fMet-Phe. Which of the following step in protein synthesis is inhibited by this antibiotic?

choices.text: Binding of charged tRNA to the ribosomal A site

questions.solution:
Option D: Ribosomal translocation

  • As fMet-Phe is made, the ribosomes must be able to complete initiation.
  • Phe-tRNA binds to the A site and uses peptidyltransferase activity to form the first peptide bond.
  • Because the ribosome is not able to proceed any further, ribosomal movement (translocation) is most likely the inhibited step.
  • The ribosome is frozen before it reaches the termination codon of this message.
  • Therefore, the only product formed is the dipeptide fMet-Phe

Option A: Initiation

  • As fMet-Phe is made, the ribosomes must be able to complete initiation.

Option B: Binding of charged tRNA to the ribosomal A site

  • As second maino acid is which shows that  binding of charged tRNA to A site.

Option C: Peptidyltransferase activity

  • Phe-tRNA binds to the A site and uses peptidyltransferase activity to form the first peptide bond.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the dermatologist by her parents. She has many freckles on her face, neck, arms, and hands and her parents report that she is sensitive to sunlight. On examination, there is dry skin with hyperpigmentation and mild atrophy of the skin. Two lesions resembling basal cell carcinoma are observed on her face. Which processes are most likely to be defective in this patient?

choices.text: Removal of mismatched bases from the 3’ end of Okazaki fragments
Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA

questions.solution:
Option C: Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA.

  • This patient is showing characteristics of a condition known as Xeroderma pigmentosum.
  • These individuals have sensitivity to sunlight with extensive freckling on body parts exposed to the sun.
  • In addition to increased cutaneous sensitivity to UV rays of sunlight, they are also present with hyperpigmentation (freckles), skin atrophy, and dehydrated skin.
  • This is a fatal condition as these patients are prone to developing skin cancers very young.
  • Exposure to UV light can form a covalent bond between two thymine molecules leading to the formation of thymine dimers.
  • These dimers halt the replication process of DNA as they do not allow DNA polymerase to move past them.
  • To prevent this, a mechanism called nucleotide excision repair is present.
  • Certain proteins (i.e., NER proteins) recognize the thymine dimers and excise them from the DNA.
  • If the genes responsible for NER proteins are mutated, the thymine dimers cannot be removed, resulting in the accumulation of damaged DNA, which ultimately leads to xeroderma pigmentosum.

Option A: Repair double-stranded breaks

  • Double stranded breaks involve cut in both the strands of DNA.
  • Double-stranded DNA breaks are repaired via non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) or homologous recombination (HR).

Option B: Removal of mismatched bases from the 3’ end of Okazaki fragments

  • The proofreading function of DNA polymerase III removes the mismatched base from the 3' end through its 3' to 5' exonuclease activity.
  • This makes sure rectification of errors and correct base pairing during DNA replication.

Option D: Removal of uracil from DNA

  • Removal of uracil from DNA is done by base excision repair.
  • Mutation in proteins involved in base excision repair is associated with MUTYH-associated polyposis.

questions.text: Which of the following hormonal changes are most likely to occur in the plasma in response to the large insulin injection dose?
questions.solution:
OPTION (C) :

Growth Hormone Glucagon Epinephrine
↑ ↑

↑

 

 

  • A large dose of insulin injection will cause hypoglycemia.
  • Hypoglycemia triggers increased secretion of at least four counter-regulatory hormones:
  • Glucagon,
  • Epinephrine,
  • Growth hormone, and
  • Cortisol.
  • Insulin inhibits glucagon secretion, so low blood glucose indirectly affects glucagon secretion through the removal of inhibition by insulin.
  • Circulating catecholamines stimulate the secretion of glucagon via β2-adrenergic receptors.
  • The CNS senses even mild hypoglycemia, which triggers a central sympathetic response.
  • Glucagon and epinephrine increase the hepatic output of glucose by increasing glycogenolysis.
  • The keys to counter-regulation appear to be glucagon > epinephrine.

Option A:

Growth Hormone Glucagon Epinephrine
↑ ↓ ↔
  • A high dose of insulin given will cause hypoglycemia. It increases the secretion of counter-regulatory hormones such as Glucagon, Epinephrine, and Growth hormone.

Option B:

Growth Hormone Glucagon Epinephrine
↔ ↑ ↑
  • Hypoglycemia caused by insulin triggers the increased secretion of at least four counter-regulatory hormones:
    • Glucagon,
    • Epinephrine,
    • Growth hormone

Option D:

Growth Hormone Glucagon Epinephrine
↓ ↑ ↑
  • A high dose of insulin given will cause hypoglycemia.
  • Hypoglycemia triggers increased secretion of at least four counter-regulatory hormones:
    • Glucagon,
    • Epinephrine,
    • Growth hormone, and
    • Cortisol.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient's arterial phase CT of the spleen showed a lack of parenchymal enhancement that appeared Lardaceous. T2-weighted MR imaging showed decreased signal intensity. The given finding is due to deposition in which of the followings?
questions.solution:
Option A: Sinusoids of red pulp

  • Amyloidosis of the spleen may be inapparent grossly or may cause moderate to marked splenomegaly (up to 800 g).
  • Two patterns of deposition are seen:-
    • The deposits are limited to the splenic follicles, producing tapioca-like granules on gross inspection, designated sago spleen.
    • The deposits involve the red pulp of the spleen.
    • Fusion of the early deposits gives rise to large, maplike areas of Amyloidosis, creating the lardaceous spleen.

Option B: White pulp

  • White pulp is a historical designation for the spleen.
  • It appears whiter than the surrounding Red pulp.
  • It comprises 25% of splenic tissue.
  • White pulp consists of 25% of the splenic tissue.
  • It contains lymphoid tissue, but it is not involved in Amyloidosis.

Option C: Trabecular arteries

  • The trabecular arteries are the branches of the splenic artery after it passes into the trabeculae of the spleen.
  • When these arteries reach the white pulp, they become covered with periarteriolar lymphoid sheaths.
  • Amyloid protein is not deposited in the trabecular arteries.

Option D: Splenic trabeculae

  • Dense connective tissue structures comprise collagen, elastic, reticular fibres, and smooth muscle cells.
  • They are projections from the splenic capsule into the parenchyma.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman, G5P4, presents to the antenatal clinic at 10 weeks of gestation for a routine visit. The physician advises a prenatal urine culture test. Her urine culture grows >100,000 CFU/mL of Escherichia coli. She is otherwise totally asymptomatic with no complaints. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: No additional treatment or workup indicated

questions.solution:
Option A: Amoxicillin-clavulanate

  • This woman with positive urine culture for E. coli with no complaints likely has asymptomatic bacteriuria.
  • All pregnant patients are screened and treated for asymptomatic bacteriuria at the initial prenatal visit due to the risk of pyelonephritis, preterm birth and low birth weight associated with untreated asymptomatic bacteriuria.
  • The most common pathogen is Escherichia coli. First-line antibiotics include cephalexin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, and nitrofurantoin.
  • E. coli is the most common bacteria responsible for urinary tract infections in pregnancy, including acute pyelonephritis and asymptomatic bacteriuria.
  • Other organisms are klebsiella, enterobacter, proteus, staphylococcus, and group B streptococcus.
  • Urinary tract infections in pregnancy are a risk factor for:
    • threatened abortion
    • chorioamnionitis
    • preterm labour
    • IUGR
    • increased perinatal mortality
    • maternal anaemia
    • preeclampsia

Option B: Ciprofloxacin

  • It is not the ideal drug for treating E. coli bacteriuria. 
  • Fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in pregnancy.

Option C: No additional treatment or workup indicated

  • Asymptomatic bacteriuria increases the risk of preterm labour. So, it should be treated once diagnosed.

Option D: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole

  • It is not the ideal drug regimen for treating E. coli bacteriuria.

questions.text: Which cardiac event would be seen after the end of the isometric relaxation phase in a normal heart?

choices.text: Corresponds to the peak of the C wave in JVP
Corresponds to T wave in ECG

questions.solution:
Option A: Atrioventricular valves open

Cardiac Cycle:

Phases of the cardiac cycle ECG changes Valves JVP Heart sound
Atrial systole or the last phase of ventricular diastole P wave PR interval - a wave 4th 
Isometric ventricular contraction QRS complex Starts with AV valve closure c wave due to bulging of AV valves back to atria 1st
Rapid ventricular ejection ST-segment Semilunar valve opens x descent -
Slow ventricular ejection T wave - - -
Protodiastole + isometric relaxation - Starts with the closure of semilunar valves and ends with the opening of AV valves (Appearance of dicrotic notch or incisura in pulse wave tracing) V wave 2nd
Rapid ventricular filling - AV valve opens y descent 3rd
Diastasis - - - -

Option B: Atrioventricular valves close

  • AV valves close during 2nd phase of a cardiac cycle, called the isovolumetric contraction phase.

Option C: Corresponds to the peak of the C wave in JVP

  • No correspondence to the peak of the C wave in JVP is associated with a wave and y descent.

Option D: Corresponds to T wave in ECG.

  • As mentioned above, its association is with a wave and y descent.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the hospital with complaints of nasal congestion, loss of smell, sneezing, runny nose, body aches and sore throat from the last 2 days. The systematic examination is unremarkable. The doctor associated his symptoms with a viral infection. Laboratory diagnosis of respiratory tract infections can be established by which of the following tests?

choices.text: Detection of virus specific IgG antibodies in single serum specimen
Demonstration of viral antibodies in indirect immunofluorescence assay in nasopharyngeal washings
Isolation of viruses using blood culture
Detection of viral heamagglutination inhibiting (HAI) antibodies in a single serum specimen

questions.solution:
Options B: Demonstration of viral antibodies in indirect immunofluorescence assay in nasopharyngeal washings

Specimens for diagnosis of respiratory infections:

  • bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL)
  • Nasopharyngeal swabs
  • Nasopharyngeal aspirates and washings
  • Throat washings

 

Calcium alginate or Teflon-coated swabs are used.

  • Rapid molecular methods include integrated nucleic acid extraction, amplification, and detection systems.
  • These tests have excellent sensitivities and specificities.

 

Option A: Detection of virus-specific IgG antibodies in a single serum specimen

  • Detection of virus-specific IgM antibodies in a single serum specimen.
  • IgG antibodies in the serum indicate chronic infection.

Option C: Isolation of viruses using blood culture

  • Isolation of the virus is done using cell culture of the target tissue.
  • Viral isolation through blood culture is done when a virus is present in the blood (viremia).

Option D: Detection of viral hemagglutination inhibiting (HAI) antibodies in a single serum specimen

  • Detection of viral hemagglutination inhibiting (HAI) antibodies cannot be done in single serum specimens.
  • It can be detected with at least two serum specimens.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: An untreated AIDS patient (CD4+ count of 80 cells/mm3) from southern California has developed a progressively severe headache and mental confusion, along with ataxia and retinochoroiditis. Focal lesions are present on a CT scan of his brain. The mucocutaneous lesions are not found. He has been living under a bridge road for the previous 2 years. His level of immunoglobulin G (IgG) to the infectious agent is high. What is the most likely explanation for how this current infection started?

choices.text: Reactivation of bradyzoites in cysts from an earlier infection

questions.solution:
Option C: Reactivation of bradyzoites in cysts from an earlier infection

  • Reactivation of Toxoplasmosis is most likely the answer, which is due to the reactivation of bradyzoites in cysts from an earlier infection.
  • In this case, encephalitis with focal lesions is present.
  • High levels of IgG indicate chronic infection; the current infection is likely a reactivation of an earlier infection; therefore, recent exposures can be eliminated.

Option A: Earlier exposure to pigeons

  • Exposure to pigeons suggests Cryptococcosis, which is often a reactivation infection.
  • However, in Cryptococcosis, antibody levels are rarely monitored, and there is no mention of an India ink stain or capsular polysaccharide in the cerebrospinal fluid, which are the major diagnostic methods.
  • In addition, based on the patient's symptoms, the infection is more likely to be encephalitis rather than meningitis or meningoencephalitis; also, retinochoroiditis is usually not present in Cryptococcosis.

Option B: Earlier exposure to desert sand

  • Desert rheumatism (Coccidioides) is a disease caused by exposure to desert sand.
  • The retinochoroiditis and lack of mucocutaneous lesions make infection with Coccidioides less likely.

Option D: Recent exposure to cat faeces

Toxoplasma gondii:

  • Oocysts are the sexual form of the parasite found in cats and felines.
  • Definitive hosts -cats and other felines.
  • Intermediate hosts - man and other mammals (goat, sheep)

Transmission:

  • MC mode: Ingestion of sporulated oocysts from contaminated soil, food, or water.
  • Ingestion of tissue cyst containing bradyzoites from undercooked meat.
  • Sporulated oocyst in cat's faeces in saline mount.

​​​​​​

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman complains of severe episodes of sharp pain in her left eye over the past two months. Her visual acuity was normal in both eyes, and her IOP was elevated. The doctor notices white spots in the pupillary zone on slit-lamp microscopy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Glaukomflecken

  • Angle-closure glaucoma can have the appearance of glaukomflecken.
  • Glaukomflecken are small anterior subcapsular opacities secondary to lens epithelial necrosis resulting from acute angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Signs of Angle-closure glaucoma: Stony hard eye, steamy cornea, Vertically oval mid-dilated non-reacting pupil
  • Symptoms: Severe pain, coloured halos, sudden drop in vision. Symptoms occur late at night.
  • Nd-Yag Laser iridotomy is done for the management of Angle-closure glaucoma.

Option A: Corneal edema

  • Corneal edema refers to the swelling of the cornea.
  • When left untreated, corneal edema can lead to cloudy vision.
  • Treatment: concentrated saline drops or ointment.

Option C: Aqueous cells

  • The presence of cells in the aqueous fluid can be counted and monitored on slit-lamp examination.
  • Aqueous flare: The characteristic appearance of a beam of slit-lamp light when shone through the anterior chamber.
  • Aqueous cells and flare are due to cellular infiltration and protein exudation into the anterior chamber.
  • Aqueous cells are an early and definite sign of active inflammation. The translucence of the aqueous due to its high albumin content is called an aqueous flare.

Option D: Posterior synechiae

  • Synechiae are the adhesions between the iris and the lens or cornea.
  • It results from trauma or eye surgery or as a complication of glaucoma or cataract; it can lead to blindness.
  • Posterior synechiae, if substantial, may affect the movement of aqueous from the posterior to the anterior chamber, a condition known as iris bombe.
  • The iris may bow forward posteriorly with secondary angle closure as pressure builds up posteriorly.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with pancreatic adenocarcinomas comes to the emergency room in a comatose state. A brain CT scan shows findings consistent with a recent left temporal lobe infarction. Blood cultures are negative; the patient never regains consciousness and dies after 2 days. The picture shows the heart from the autopsy. Which of the following is most likely to cause a stroke in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis

  • Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis, also known as marantic endocarditis, refers to sterile vegetation in seemingly normal heart valves.
  • The image shows the sterile vegetation with a warty appearance.
  • Almost always associated with cancer or some other debilitating disease.
  • The cause of endocarditis marantic has been little researched but is attributed to increased blood coagulation and deposition of immune complexes.
  • The main danger is embolization in distant organs.

Option A: Calcific aortic stenosis

  • Calcific aortic stenosis is the most prevalent heart valve disorder in developed countries.
  • It is characterized by progressive fibro-calcific remodelling and thickening of the aortic valve leaflets that, over the years, have evolved to cause severe obstruction to cardiac outflow.
  • It is mainly associated with stroke.
  • The image is consistent with Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis

Option B: Carcinoid heart disease

  • It is a form of neuroendocrine tumour and carcinoid syndrome.
  • It occurs in advanced form.
  • It involves the right-sided heart walls and eventually leads to right heart failure.
  • The image is consistent with Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis.

Option C: Cardiac metastases

  • Its manifestation includes the cardiac tamponade from pericardial involvement.
  • Tumours can reach the heart via blood, lymph, transvenous, or directly.
  • It can also lead to arrhythmias and heart failure.
