  • The image is consistent with Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fatigue and recurrent fever for the last 9 months. He also complains of yellowish discolouration of sclerae and skin, abdominal tenderness, and dark urine. His physical examination reveals mild hepatomegaly and jaundice. His laboratory studies demonstrate elevated levels of serum bilirubin (3.1 mg/ dL) and decreased serum albumin (2.5 g/dL), along with prolonged prothrombin time (17 seconds). His serologic tests reveal positive antibodies to hepatitis B core antigen (IgG anti-HB core antigen). The serum is positive for Hepatitis B surface antigen and Hepatitis B e Antigen. A liver biopsy is shown in the figure. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Chronic hepatitis B

  • The clinical features and liver biopsy findings indicate that patient has a chronic hepatitis B infection.
  • Hepatitis B is a double-stranded DNA hepadnavirus.
  • It spreads through exposure to infected blood or body fluids, including vertical transmission from mother to child.
  • The incubation period if the virus is 6-20 weeks.
  • The clinical features of hepatitis B include fever, jaundice and elevated liver transaminases.
  • Complications of hepatitis B infection include chronic hepatitis fulminant liver failure (1%), hepatocellular carcinoma glomerulonephritis, and polyarteritis nodosa cryoglobulinaemia.
  • There is necrosis and inflammation of the liver with hepatitis B infection lasting for more than 6 months:
    • A biopsy of the liver shows chronically-inflamed fibrous septa and hepatocellular nodules.
    • Surface antigen (HBsAg) is present in patients with chronic hepatitis B serum.
    • If HbeAg is present, it is often associated with the progression of the disease.

Option A: Acute hepatitis B

  • HBsAg normally implies acute disease. (Present for 1-6 months).
  • If HBsAg is present for > 6 months, this implies chronic disease (i.e. Infective).
  • Acute hepatitis B does not demonstrate cirrhosis as depicted in the picture and does not show the serologic characteristics of HBV infection.

Option B: Alcoholic hepatitis

  • The alcoholic liver disease covers a spectrum of conditions:
    • Alcoholic fatty liver disease
    • Alcoholic hepatitis
    • Cirrhosis
  • Gamma-GT is characteristically raised.
  • ALT is normally > 2, and a ratio of > 3 strongly indicates acute alcoholic hepatitis. Alcoholic hepatitis does not cause cirrhosis as depicted in the picture and does not show the serologic characteristics of HBV infection.

Option D: Delta virus infection

  • Hepatitis D, also called "delta hepatitis," is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis D virus (HDV).
  • Hepatitis D always occurs in patients infected with the hepatitis B virus. Delta virus infection does not cause cirrhosis as depicted in the picture and does not show the serologic characteristics of HBV infection.

questions.text: A thirty-five-year-old woman is admitted to your hospital with lobar pneumonia. She complained of breathlessness and chronic cough with increased sputum production. The patient is a non-alcoholic and non-smoker. Examination findings are positive for wheezing all over her chest. The patient goes into respiratory failure and dies shortly after. An image of the patient's lung autopsy is shown below. Which of the following underlying conditions was most likely associated with the pathological changes seen here?
questions.solution:
Option A: α1-Antitrypsin deficiency

  • Hereditary deficiency of α1-antitrypsin enzyme is responsible for about 1% of all patients with a clinical diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is comparatively more common in young persons who present with severe emphysema.
  • α1-antitrypsin causes inhibition of neutrophil elastase enzyme that digests elastin and other structural components of the alveolar septa.
  • Lack of α1-antitrypsin results in the destruction of alveolar walls causing emphysema and hypersecretion of mucus, causing chronic bronchitis.
  • Patients with this hereditary condition have diffuse emphysema.
  • The emphysema is classified as panacinar.

 

Option B: Cystic fibrosis

  • Hyperplasia of bronchial submucosal glands can be seen in cystic fibrosis, asthma and chronic bronchitis.
  • This patient's findings suggest α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

 

Option C: Goodpasture syndrome

  • Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease affecting the lungs and kidneys.
  • This patient's findings suggest α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

 

Option D: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

  • An allergic reaction to inhaled microorganisms causes hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
  • This patient's findings suggest α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD with fever, chills and shortness of breath. The patient complains of chest pain and appears to be in acute respiratory distress. His past medical history is significant for type-2 DM for 20 years. He has been an alcoholic for 32 years but does not smoke. On physical examination, he is  malnourished; breath sounds are decreased on both lung fields and crackles are heard. The patient exhibits tachypnea, with flaring of the nares. His sputum is mucoid, thick and blood-tinged. Gram stain shows gram-negative non-motile rod-shaped bacteria. Which one of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Klebsiella pneumoniae

  • Klebsiella pneumoniae is the most common cause of pneumonia among gram-negative bacteria.
  • It commonly affects malnourished and debilitated people, particularly chronic alcoholics.
  • Characteristic thick, mucoid (often blood-tinged) sputum is seen because the organism produces excessive viscid capsular polysaccharide, which is difficult to expectorate.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination reveals signs of consolidation (crepitation, bronchial breathing, and increased vocal resonance)
    • The gram stain of sputum shows gram-negative, non-motile, rod-shaped bacteria.
    • A chest x-ray may show lobar infiltrate.
  • Treatment: Third or fourth-generation cephalosporin or respiratory quinolone.

Option A: Legionella pneumophila

  • It is a gram -negative rod that causes atypical pneumonia.
  • It does not produce blood-tinged sputum as seen in mycoplasma pneumonia. 

Option C: Mycoplasma pneumoniae

  • It is a common cause of atypical interstitial pneumonia.
  • It is a pleomorphic organism that cannot be seen on gram stain.

 

Option D: Streptococcus pneumoniae

  • It is a gram-positive coccus and a common cause of pneumonia in asplenic patients.
  • It produces a characteristic rusty sputum.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. The patient had a mild bruise on his hand. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination examinations reveal no abnormalities. The patient prompted an abdominal computed tomography scan, which came out to be normal, with the exception of a questionable mass in the right lobe of the liver. A fine-needle biopsy was done, which confirmed the presence of the liver adenoma. Which of the following is associated with the development of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Option C: Oral contraceptives

  • This is a case of liver adenoma in which the patient presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident.
  • Liver adenoma was an incidental finding in this case.
  • The abdominal CT revealed a questionable mass in the right lobe of the liver, which was later confirmed as liver adenoma after a fine-needle biopsy.
  • Benign liver tumours are commonly associated with the use of oral contraceptives in young women.
  • These tumours usually resemble hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • It is usually subcapsular.
  • It is a benign tumour and usually doesn’t cause any serious symptoms.
  • It can rupture and can cause intra-abdominal haemorrhage, so it should be treated.

Option A: Hepatitis B

  • Hepatitis B is a virus which can cause inflammation of the hepatocytes.
  • It can lead to hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option B: Polyvinyl chloride

  • Polyvinyl chloride is used in IV bags, urine bags, oxygen masks, blood bags and tubing.
  • Polyvinyl chloride predisposes to angiosarcoma of the liver.

Option D: Polycythemia vera

  • Polycythemia vera is a chronic proliferative neoplasm in which there is an irreversible increase in erythrocytes and platelet count.
  • It is associated with thrombosis of the hepatic veins.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and confusion. On examination, he is found to have weakness in his left arm and leg. A head CT scan reveals a hypodense area in the right cerebral hemisphere. A subsequent MRI shows a ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding edema. A biopsy of the lesion is performed, and histopathological examination shows an area of necrosis with neutrophilic infiltrate. What is the most likely type of necrosis observed in this case?
questions.solution:
The correct option is:

B) Liquefactive necrosis
 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and radiological findings described in the case are suggestive of a brain abscess, which is commonly associated with liquefactive necrosis. Liquefactive necrosis is a type of necrosis where tissue architecture is completely lost, and the affected area transforms into a fluid-filled space due to the action of hydrolytic enzymes, particularly in the presence of neutrophils. This type of necrosis is often observed in bacterial or fungal infections, as well as in ischemic infarctions of the brain.

In this case, the neutrophilic infiltrate seen in the histopathological examination of the brain biopsy is characteristic of liquefactive necrosis. The ring-enhancing lesion observed on MRI is a result of the accumulation of inflammatory cells and fluid at the border between the necrotic tissue and the surrounding healthy tissue.

Other options:

A) Coagulative necrosis: Coagulative necrosis is a type of necrosis commonly seen in ischemic injuries, such as in myocardial infarction. It is characterized by the preservation of the tissue architecture with coagulation of proteins, resulting in a firm texture.

C) Caseous necrosis: Caseous necrosis is typically observed in granulomatous infections like tuberculosis. It presents as a "cheese-like" appearance with a combination of cellular debris and amorphous granular material.

D) Fat necrosis: Fat necrosis is often seen in adipose tissue after trauma or pancreatitis. It is characterized by the formation of chalky-white areas due to the saponification of fatty acids.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man has been evaluated for recurrent peptic ulcer disease for the past few months. He has tried multiple acid suppression treatments without significant improvement. An endoscopy is done, which shows multiple gastric and duodenal ulcers. H.Pylori testing is negative. Serum gastrin is significantly elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these observed findings?
questions.solution:
Option D: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

  • Recurrent intractable peptic ulcer disease is suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by excess gastrin production, most often from a gastrinoma.

Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) is a gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumour often localized to the duodenum and pancreas.
  • Most gastrinomas occur sporadically, but some are associated with other endocrine neoplasias (e.g., pituitary adenomas, parathyroid adenomas, and insulinomas).
  • Although some gastrinomas are benign, more than half of all gastrinomas are malignant.
  • Gastrinomas release high levels of gastrin, which then increases gastric acid production.
  • Patients typically present with recurrent, therapy-resistant peptic ulcer disease and diarrhoea.
  • Patients with gastrinomas have low gastric pH and elevated serum gastrin.
  • Furthermore, serum gastrin levels increase with secretin administration (positive secretin stimulation test).
  • Surgical resection of the tumour is indicated in patients with localized disease.
  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and octreotide may be used to control acid secretion.

Option A: Cushing syndrome

  • Results from an excess of cortisol caused due to adrenal/ pituitary adenoma.
  • Causes hyperglycemia, poor wound healing, hypertension, weight gain, and pink abdominal striae

Option B: Glucagonoma

  • Rare neuroendocrine tumours of pancreatic alpha cells can cause hyperglycemia.
  • May leads to necrolysis erythema migrans

Option C: Whipple triad

  • A triad comprises episodic hyperinsulinemia + hypoglycemia causing CNS dysfunction, reversible by glucose administration
  • Seen with insulinoma.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female presented to the outpatient clinic complaining of pain and redness in her left breast. She had never needed to see a doctor in the past ten years. A physical examination revealed an erythematous and swollen breast. On palpation, the breast is warm to the touch and tender. The breast has significant dimpling (peau d'orange), and the left nipple is completely retracted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Inflammatory carcinoma 

  • Inflammatory carcinoma is caused by carcinoma plugging lymphovascular spaces, resulting in swelling and nipple retraction. 
  • Although it is called inflammatory carcinoma, there is no inflammation present. 
  • This is usually of high grade and has distant metastasis. 
  • It has a very poor prognosis. 
  • Common symptoms are 
    • Pain 
    • Erythema 
    • Dimpling of skin (peau d'orange)
    • Skin thickening 
    • Usually, no palpable mass is present
  • Skin dimpling is caused by the involvement of the cooper ligament, which connects the skin to the breast. This gives the breast the appearance of an orange peel (peau d'orange).
  • The presentation is similar to breast infections, resulting in delayed diagnosis. 

Option A: Granulomatous mastitis

  • It is a rare breast disease that can manifest systemic granulomatous disease (Sarcoidosis, Tuberculosis, and so on).
  • The presence of granulomas adjacent to lobules is the histologic pattern, which may contain lipids. 
  • Histologically, the pattern resembles cystic neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis. 
  • It should be treated with antibiotics and, in some cases, steroids. 

Option B: Micropapillary carcinoma

  • Micropapillary carcinoma forms a cell ball that floats in intercellular fluid. 
  • It forms a structure similar to true papillae. 

Option C: Fibrocystic disease of the breast

  • Fibrocystic disease is characterised by the formation of cysts and stromal fibrosis. 
  • Smaller cysts then combine to form larger cysts. 
  • It is a benign breast condition.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy visited the paediatrician because his mother noticed an abnormal mass in his scrotum while changing his diapers. Further workup shows increased levels of serum α-fetoprotein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumour

  • Endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumour is the testis' most common malignant germ cell tumour in infancy and early childhood.
  • It is characterized by an elevated serum α-fetoprotein and histologically stainable α1 -antitrypsin.

ENDODERMAL SINUS TUMOUR

  • In this age range, choriocarcinoma is less prevalent and often leads to a rise in hCG. Although hepatocellular carcinomas can produce -fetoprotein, this is improbable in this patient's case.
  • Teratomas include several germ layers and various tissues, including hair, teeth, and sebaceous tissue, and are derived from the testicular stroma.
  • They generate androgens and estrogens and frequently present with premature puberty.
  • Unlike teratomas in women, the majority of teratomas in men are cancerous.

Option A: Choriocarcinoma

  • Trophoblastic cells give rise to a malignant, quickly expanding tumour (cells that help an embryo attach to the uterus and help form the placenta).
  • After a sperm fertilize an egg, almost all choriocarcinomas develop in the uterus; however, a tiny percentage develop in the testis or the ovary.
  • Choriocarcinoma symptoms, which have migrated to the lungs, include coughing, breathing problems, and occasionally chest pain.
    • Vagina: You could be bleeding heavily, and your doctor might find nodules in your vagina. You may be experiencing stomach pain.
  • The majority of the time, choriocarcinoma can be cured. Although it can occasionally result in difficulties, the outlook for patients with this illness is often very bright.

Option C: Hepatocellular carcinoma

  • The most typical form of primary liver cancer is the type of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
  • People with chronic liver illnesses, such as cirrhosis by hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection, are most likely to develop hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Symptoms
    • Abdominal discomfort or distention (enlargement)
    • Weight loss.
    • Jaundice (whites of the eyes and yellow of the skin)
    • Gastrointestinal haemorrhage (bleeding)
    • Nausea or vomiting.
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most frequent type of liver cancer.
  • It occurs more often in men than women.
  • It is most often diagnosed in people aged 50 or older.
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma is not the same as metastatic liver cancer.
  • Since HCC usually grows slowly in its early stages, it can often be cured if discovered early enough.

Option D: Teratoma

  • A germ cell tumour may contain several tissue types, such as bone, muscle, and hair. A teratoma develops when there are disruptions during your cells' differentiation process.
  • Teratomas might be mature or immature depending on how natural the cells seem under a microscope.
  • Sometimes immature and mature cells coexist in teratomas.
  • Although malignant degeneration is quite rare, the cyst should be removed entirely, and if immature elements are found, the patient should undergo a standard staging procedure.
  • Possible symptoms include:
    • A visible mass in the tailbone area.
    • Abdominal pain.
    • Constipation.
    • Dysuria (painful urination).
    • Pubic swelling.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of colicky abdominal pain for the last 4 hours, abdominal distention and non-bilious vomiting. On physical examination, her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), her pulse is 105/min, her respiration rate is 20/min, and her blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. On percussion abdomen is hyperresonant and bowel sounds are increased. An abdominal radiograph has shown that she has single dilated bowel loops with only one air-fluid level in the left lower quadrant. Full-thickness rectal biopsy was consistent with aganglionic megacolon. This condition is caused by the absence of which the following kinds of neural cell bodies?
questions.solution:
Option D: Parasympathetic postganglionic neuron cell bodies

  • The aganglionic megacolon (Hirschsprung's disease) is a congenital disorder characterized by the absence of intestinal ganglia (cell bodies of parasympathetic postganglionic neurons) in the lower part of the colon, causing the colon to expand proximal to the inactive segment, resulting in an obstruction.
  • Three nerve plexuses innervating the intestine are the submucosal (Meissner) plexus, the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus, and the smaller mucosal plexus to regulate bowel functions.
  • In Hirschsprung's disease, both myenteric and submucosal plexuses are absent.
  • Enteric nervous system reflexes are absent, so intestinal smooth muscle control is highly extrinsic.
  • In the absence of cell bodies of parasympathetic postganglionic neurons, the cholinergic system predominates the adrenergic system causing an increase in smooth muscle tone.
  • It results in an imbalance of smooth muscle contractility, disorganized peristalsis, and a functional obstruction.

Option A: Sympathetic preganglionic neuron cell bodies

  • The sympathetic preganglionic neuron cell bodies lie within the spinal cord, and their axons pass through the anterior horn to exit in ventral roots.
  • In the ventral roots, they form synapses with postganglionic neurons.
  • The absence of these cell bodies will disturb the sympathetic outflow at regions that have no relation to causing megacolon.

Option B: Sympathetic postganglionic neuron cell bodies

  • The cell bodies of the sympathetic postganglionic neurons are in autonomic ganglia located peripherally.
  • Their absence is not involved in causing aganglionic megacolon.

Option C: Parasympathetic preganglionic neuron cell bodies

  • They have cell bodies located in the brainstem and the sacral spinal cord region.
  • The axons of the preganglionic neurons release acetylcholine on the postganglionic neurons located near the target organs.
  • They have no involvement in causing the aganglionic megacolon.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain. His angiogram reveals thromboses of both brachiocephalic veins just before entering the superior vena cava. This condition would most likely cause dilation of which of the following veins?
questions.solution:
Option D: Left superior intercostal

  • The left superior intercostal vein is formed by the second, third, and fourth posterior intercostal veins. It drains into the left brachiocephalic vein.
  • Hence, the thrombosis of the left brachiocephalic vein leads to dilatation of the left superior intercostal vein.
  • Other tributaries of the left brachiocephalic vein are: 
    • Left vertebral vein
    • Left inferior thyroid vein
    • Left internal thoracic vein

Option A: Accessory Hemiazygos

  • Accessory hemiazygos vein → Drains upper intercostal spaces
  • Accessory hemiazygos vein turns towards the right in the thorax and passes behind the heart and drains into the azygos vein.

Option B: Hemiazygos

  • Formed in the abdomen and puncture the left curs of the diaphragm to enter the thorax and drains the lower intercostal spaces
  • Hemiazygos vein drains into the azygos vein. Hence, the thrombosis of the brachiocephalic vein would not cause dilatation of the hemiazygos vein

Option C: Right superior intercostal

  • The right superior intercostal vein drains into the azygos vein, which in turn drains into the superior vena cava (SVC).
  • The hemiazygos vein drains into the azygos vein, whereas the internal thoracic vein empties into the brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient with high triglyceride and LDL-cholesterol levels has premature cholesterol gallstone disease. The patient has been taking statins for the last three years, which did not reduce his complications. The same problems were also noted in two of his siblings. Dyslipidemia in this patient can be best explained by:

choices.text: Abnormal phospholipids influx in the gallbladder due to ileal disease

questions.solution:
Option B: A loss of CYP7A1 (cholesterol 7α-hydroxylase) function

  • It is a true statement. Therefore, it is the answer.
  • CYP7A1 malfunction will lead to defective cholesterol to bile salts conversion. Elevated triglyceride and LDL-cholesterol, premature cholesterol gallstone can result from blocking cholesterol breakdown enzyme. As a result, cholesterol accumulates in the bile along with the decreased synthesis of bile salt, which helps in cholesterol deposition and the formation of cholesterol gallstones.
  • Statin therapy can control only the rate of cholesterol synthesis but cannot accelerate cholesterol degradation. Although not well understood, the increase in blood triglyceride levels in CYP7A1 deficiency indicates a reciprocal relationship between bile acid synthesis and TG levels.
  • Finally, as siblings have the same conditions, it appears to be a genetic disorder, which points to a possible mutated gene and likely prevents the function of CYP7A1.
  • It helps maintain bile acid homeostasis and protects the liver from bile acid-induced cytotoxicity.

Option A: HMG-CoA reductase function loss

  • HMG-CoA reductase function loss will also lead to decreased formation of cholesterol, but this patient has high cholesterol levels.

Option C: Abnormal phospholipids influx in the gallbladder due to ileal disease

  • Nothing like that statement is present in the statement so that this option can be ruled out.

Option D: High levels of LCAT

  • High levels of LCAT will lead to increased formation of mature HDL-containing cholesterol esters.

questions.text: A 49-year-old multiparous woman comes to the clinic with urine leakage after coughing and sneezing for 5 days. Her history is significant, with six spontaneous vaginal deliveries. The doctor explained that she likely has a weakness in the pelvic floor muscles and advised her on some exercises. Which of the following muscle paralysis will cause the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A: Sphincter urethrae

  • In the clinical scenario above, the woman has presented with symptoms of stress incontinence, i.e., leakage of urine whenever abdominal pressure increases, such as coughing, sneezing, laughing, or lifting something heavy.
    • It is due to the weakness of the pelvic floor muscles and the muscles (urinary sphincter) that control the release of urine.
    • It mainly occurs in multiparous women who have undergone vaginal deliveries.
    • There is tissue or nerve damage during the delivery of a child that weakens these muscles.
    • Pelvis floor exercises like Kegel exercises help strengthen the pelvic floor muscles and the urinary sphincter.
  • The urethral sphincter is a muscular layer that encircles the urethra and controls urine flow from the bladder to the urethra.
  • There are two sphincters: external and internal sphincters. These sphincters contract and narrow the urethra, and the urine stops.
  • The internal urethral sphincter, a smooth muscle, is under autonomic/involuntary control. It is situated where the urinary bladder and the urethra join.
  • The external urethral sphincter is a skeletal muscle and is under voluntary control.
    • It surrounds the membranous part of the urethra.
    • It is innervated by the deep branch of the pudendal nerve.
    • In females, the external urethral sphincter has three parts: the innermost part, which consists of circular muscle fibres, is located around the proximal two-thirds of the urethra; the second part is an extension from the innermost part that encircles the urethra superior to the perineal membrane, and the third part which is the urethrovaginal sphincter surrounds both the urethra and vagina as one unit.

Option B: Coccygeus

  • It is a sheet of muscle and fibrous tissue of the pelvis that forms the pelvic diaphragm along with the levator ani.
  • It originates from the ischium and is inserted into the inferior end of the sacrum and coccyx.
  • It supports pelvic viscera and causes flexion of the coccyx. The aponeurotic portion of the muscle forms the sacrospinous ligament.
  • The S4 and S5 innervate it. The blood supply is by the inferior vesical, inferior gluteal, and pudendal arteries.

Option C: Superficial transverse perinei

  • It originates from the body of ischium and is inserted into the perineal body.
  • It travels across the superficial perineal space with the anus posterior to it.
  • It is innervated by the perineal branch of the pudendal nerve.
  • It is one of the muscles of the urogenital triangle that are important for reproduction and urinary excretion.

Option D: Levator ani

  • It is a broad, muscular sheet in the pelvis and forms the pelvic diaphragm and the coccygeus muscle.
  • It is a collection of three muscles: puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus.
  • It functions to stabilize the abdominal and pelvic organs and provides resistance against increased intra-abdominal pressure.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man fell from the parallel bar during the Olympic trial. On neurologic examination, he is having a lesion involving the lateral cord of the brachial plexus. Which of the following muscles is most likely involved in this injury?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pectoralis major

  • Pectoralis major is a thick, fan-shaped muscle that arises from the anterior surface of the sternal half of the clavicle and half the breadth of the anterior surface of the sternum down to the level of the sixth or seventh costal cartilage.
  • Pectoralis major muscle is supplied by the medial and lateral pectoral nerves originating from the medial and lateral cords of the brachial plexus, respectively.
  • The lateral pectoral nerve (C5, C6) is larger than the medial and may arise either from the anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks or by a single branch from the lateral cord just above or deep to the clavicle.
  • It sends a branch to the medial pectoral nerve forming a loop in front of the first part of the axillary artery to supply some fibers of pectoralis minor.
  • The medial pectoral nerve (C8, T1) branches from the medial cord while the latter lies posterior to the axillary artery and curves forwards between the axillary artery and vein. Anterior to the artery, it joins a ramus of the lateral pectoral nerve and enters the deep surface of the pectoralis minor to which it supplies.
  • Fibers for the clavicular part are from C5 and C6. Those for the sternocostal part are from the C7, C8, and T1.

Option A: Subscapularis

  • It is supplied by the upper and lower subscapular nerve (C5, C6), which originate from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.

Option B: Teres Major

  • It is supplied by the Inferior subscapular nerve (C5, C6, and C7), which originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.

Option C: Latissimus Dorsi

  • Latissimus dorsi is supplied by the thoracodorsal nerve from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus, C6, C7, and C8 (predominantly C7).
  • Therefore these muscles will not be affected by a lesion in the lateral cords of the brachial plexus

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman stepped on a broken wine bottle, and the sharp glass entered the posterior part of her foot. The patient was admitted to the hospital, and a physical examination concluded that her lateral plantar nerve had been transected. Which of the following conditions will most likely be confirmed by physical examination?

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the plantar surface of the third toe
Paralysis of the interossei and adductor hallucis

questions.solution:
Option C: Paralysis of the interossei and adductor hallucis

  • The lateral plantar nerve is a terminal branch of the tibial nerve
  • The most common cause of LPN is trauma, and the most common site of injury was at the passage of the lateral plantar nerve through the abductor tunnel at the instep of the foot.
  • Like in this patient where a sharp glass entered through the posterior part of the foot.
  • The Lateral plantar nerve innervates the interossei and adductor hallucis.
  • These losses would be obvious when the patient attempts to abduct and adduct the toes.
  • Sensations would be absent over the lateral side of the sole, little toe, and half of the fourth toe.

Option A:  Loss of sensation over the plantar surface of the third toe

  • The Medial plantar nerve provides sensations over the plantar surface of the medial three-and-a-half toes

Option B: Paralysis of the abductor hallucis

  • The medial plantar nerve supplies the LAFF muscles: first lumbrical, abductor hallucis, flexor hallucis brevis, and flexor digitorum brevis.

Option D : Flexor hallucis brevis

  • The medial plantar nerve supplies  the Flexor hallucis brevis muscle

questions.text: After several 12-hour daily rehearsals for a Wagner opera performance, the 52-year-old conductor experienced excruciating pain in his right forearm, rendering him unable to direct the musicians. Palpation 2 cm distal and posteromedial of the lateral epicondyle elicited excruciating pain. Steroid injections and rest were recommended. What injury is most likely?

choices.text: Compression of the median nerve by the pronator teres
Compression of the median nerve by the flexor digitorum superficialis
Compression of the superficial radial nerve by the brachioradialis
Compression of the deep radial nerve by the supinator

questions.solution:
Option D: Compression of the deep radial nerve by the supinator

  • The Radial Nerve divides into superficial and deep branches just proximal to the superior border of the Supinator muscle.
  • The deep radial nerve is also called the posterior interosseous nerve. Compression of the posterior interosseous nerve at the proximal forearm can cause radial tunnel syndrome.
  • The radial nerve runs between the two heads of the supinator and lies just medial and distal to the lateral epicondyle; it can be compressed by hypertrophy of the supinator causing pain and weakness.
  • Management should begin conservatively; if it is not successful, surgical treatment should indicate the easy complete release of the superficial height of the supinator muscle.

Option A: Compression of the median nerve by the pronator teres

  •  The median nerve merges into the flexor compartment of the forearm.

Option B: Compression of the median nerve by the flexor digitorum superficialis

  • The superficial radial nerve runs to the side of the back of the forearm and does not cause pain from pressure on the back of the forearm.

Option C: Compression of the superficial radial nerve by the brachioradialis

  • It lies underneath the tendon of the brachioradialis muscle; its compression does not cause severe pain in the lateral epicondylitis.
  • Its damage causes sensory loss at the dorsum of the hand.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with the complaint of painless pale skin lesions over the right arm on the dorsal and ventral surface for the past three weeks. On examination, thickened band-like lesions are present, and the sensations are reduced over the skin lesions. The nerves are thick and palpable. Histopathology shows the following:



In which disease of skin this histopathological picture is seen?
questions.solution:
Option A: Tuberculoid Leprosy (TT)

  • One or few asymmetrically located lesions. Painless skin patches can be seen.
  • Well-defined, hypo-pigmented, anesthetic macules or plaques, often with active border.
  • The affected area shows hair loss and impairment of sweating.
  • The affected nerve is thickened and often leads to nodularity
  • Histopathology shows Hard tubercles eroding into the epidermis; with no clear zone.

Option B: Lepromatous leprosy

  • Multiple lesions which are symmetrical are seen in lepromatous leprosy.
  • Number: Multiple, Diffused infiltration- face, ears, trunk.
  • Surface and character: Plaques and nodules Skin lesions multiple, bilaterally symmetrical Madarosis, Edema feet.
  • Anesthesia: Glove & stocking anesthesia.

Option C: lymphoma

  • The skin lesions are itchy, scaly, and red to purple in lymphoma
  • This patient has tuberculoid leprosy
  • Therefore, this is not the correct answer.

Option D: Histiocytosis

  • This patient has tuberculoid leprosy.
  • Hard tubercles invading the epidermis are not seen.
  • Therefore, this is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in the treatment of chronic gout?
questions.solution:
Option A: Febuxostat

  • Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used in chronic gout.

  • The excruciating pain associated with gout makes it a common form of inflammatory arthritis. In most cases, only one joint is affected at a time (often the big toe joint). There are times when symptoms become significantly worse, which are referred to as flares, and there are periods when there are no symptoms, which are referred to as remissions. Repeated attacks of gout might eventually progress to gouty arthritis, a kind of arthritis that is more severe.

  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicines (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen and steroids, in addition to the anti-inflammatory medication colchicine, are used in the treatment of gout.

  • Febuxostat is given to patients suffering from gout in order to bring their uric acid levels down. Febuxostat is effective because it lowers the quantity of uric acid that is produced by the body. Gout is a condition that can be brought on by an elevated level of uric acid.

Option B: Leflunomide

  • Leflunomide is a dihydroorotate dehydrogenase inhibitor that causes a halt in pyrimidine synthesis. Causes suppression in T-cell proliferation. It can be used in Rheumatoid Arthritis as a DMARD.

Option C: Etanercept

  • Etanercept is a biological agent that acts as a decoy for TNF-a (alpha), inhibiting its action. It is used in rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, and Ankylosing spondylitis. It should not be used in granulomatous diseases such as latent tuberculosis.

Option D: Methotrexate

  • Methotrexate is a dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor that is used as DMARD in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: A 9-year-old male child presents to the outpatient department for being restless and hyperactive for six months. He also does not listen to the chapters taught at school and disturbs other students; he also shows less interest in playing. On examination, the child cannot stay still and shows excessive physical movements. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: ADHD

  • In this case, a child presents to the outpatient department for being restless and hyperactive for 6 months. His mother gives the history that his teacher complains that he does not listen to the chapters taught at school and disturbs other students; he also shows less interest in playing. On examination, the child is unable to stay still for any amount of time and shows excessive physical movements. The scenario suggests that the child has attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
  • Attention, deficit hyperactivity disorder, is one of the most common neurodevelopmental disorders of childhood, and its onset is before the age of 12. In this disorder, a child might have trouble focusing on something or excess movements that are not fitting to the setting.
  • Common features include lack of concentration, impulsivity and hyperactivity.
  • In some cases, children also show destructive and aggressive behaviour. Such children take risks in activities without thinking about their personal safety or the safety of others.

Pharmacotherapy

  • Stimulants
    • Methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate
    • Amphetamines
    • Modafinil
  • Non stimulants
    • Atomoxetine
    • Bupropion
    • Clonidine, Guanfacine
    • Venlafaxine

Option A: Cerebral palsy

  • It is a group of movement and posture disorders causing activity limitation due to non–progressive disturbances that occur in the developing fetal or infant brain.
  • Cerebral palsy usually presents developmental delay, seizures, microcephaly, and speech abnormalities,  and imaging shows periventricular leukomalacia.

Option C: Mania

  • A specific period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased goal-directed activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most time of the day, nearly every day.
  • It is associated with inflated self-esteem or grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, more talkative than usual, flight of ideas, and distractibility (that is, attention too easily drawn to irrelevant external stimuli).

Option D: Delirium

  • It is cerebral dysfunction of the brain that results in confusion.
  • This disorder presents fast in a few hours or days and is usually temporary. It has 3 types hypoactive, hyperactive, and mixed.

questions.text: A group of researchers is working on the variation in response sensitivity to increasing the dosage of Amitriptyline in different individuals. Which of the following would give information about the response to increasing the dose of Amitriptyline?
questions.solution:
Option B: Quantal DRC

  • When the response is an ‘all or none phenomenon (e.g. antiemetic drug stopping the vomiting or not), the y-axis (response axis) shows the number of persons responding, and the X-axis shows the plasma concentration.
  • It thus shows how many people respond to a particular drug dose. It is used to calculate ED50 and LD50.
  • Quantal D-R curves plot the percentage of a population responding to a specified drug effect versus dose or log dose.
  • They permit estimations of the median effective or effective dose in 50% of a population—ED50.

  • It can reveal the range of intersubject variability in drug response.
  • A steep D-R curve reflects little variability.
  • A flat D-R curve indicates great variability in patient sensitivity to the effects of a drug.
  • Median Effective Dose (ED50): The dose will produce the desired response in half of the (50%)recipients. The more ED50 is, the lower the potency and vice versa.
  • Median Lethal Dose (LD50): The dose will result in the death of 50% of the animals receiving the drug. The more LD50 is, the safer the drug.
  • Therapeutic Index (TI): It is a measure of the safety of a drug. It is calculated as a ratio of LD50 to ED50. Drugs having high TI are safer, whereas those having low TI are more likely to be toxic.

Option A: Graded DRC

  • Dose-response curves:
    • The relationship between the dose of a drug or substance and the measured response. Typically plotted on a graph, the X axis is the drug dose, and the Y axis is the measured response.
    • Plots of dose (or log dose) versus response for drugs (agonists) that activate receptors can reveal information about these agonists' affinity, potency, and efficacy.
    • The following terms are used to describe dose-response relationships:
      • Potency (EC50): The potency of a drug is measured as the concentration required to produce a pharmacological response of a specified intensity. 
      • Not related to efficacy (drugs with a high potency can have a low efficacy) but dependent on affinity.
      • Efficacy
      • Affinity

Option C: Potency

  • Potency (EC50): The potency of a drug is measured as the concentration required to produce a pharmacological response of a specified intensity. 
  • Not related to efficacy (drugs with a high potency can have a low efficacy) but dependent on affinity
  • EC50 = the effective concentration required to produce 50% of the maximum possible response (Emax)
  • A left curve shift shows decreased EC50 and increased potency, meaning a lower drug concentration is needed.
  • EC50 is not to be confused with ED50; ED50 is the median effective dose that produces a desired beneficial effect in 50% of the population.
  • ED50 = 5 mg implies that administration of 5 mg of the drug achieves the desired effect in 50% of the studied population
  • The same drug may have different ED50 values based on the indication (e.g., aspirin has different ED50 values for headache and thromboembolism prophylaxis).
  • Drug potency is the drug concentration required to produce a specific effect. The relative potency graph illustrates the difference in potency between drugs A and B using the EC50 (concentration required to produce 50% of the maximal effect).

Option D: Efficacy

  • Drug efficacy (correlates with Emax): the maximum degree to which a drug activates receptors after binding and triggers a cellular response.
  • On an efficacy graph, the difference in efficacy of the two drugs is determined by the difference in the maximal effect exerted by each of them (shown on the y-axis); drugs with different efficacy will have different heights, with the difference in efficacy represented on the y-axis. 
  • Not related to potency (drugs with a high efficacy can have a low potency)
  • Partial agonists are less efficacious than full agonists.
  • In pharmacology, “drug efficacy” refers to the maximum effect (Emax) a drug is capable of producing (where increases in dose will not increase effect).
  • The relative efficacy graph illustrates the difference in efficacy between drugs A and B at high drug concentrations.

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate who is affected by jaundice is brought to ENT OPD to evaluate for risk of hearing loss. What would be the best test for evaluation of hearing in a neonate?
questions.solution:
Option B: BERA

  • Brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) / ABR is a confirmatory test.
  •  The screening test is done for a large population to find probable diseased cases among them. However, when a suspected patient is brought to the hospital confirmatory test is preferred.
  • Therefore BERA is the answer to this question.
  • BERA is an objective test.
  • It is the study of electric waves produced along the neural pathway of sound.
  • It is a confirmatory test for neonatal deafness.
  • BERA (brainstem evoked response audiometry) or Auditory brainstem response (ABR). Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential), it is to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts.
  •  It is a non-invasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons, and midbrain.
  •  In this method, electrical potentials are generated in response to several click stimuli or tone bursts and picked up. It measures hearing sensitivity in the range of 1000–4000 Hz.
  •  In a normal person, seven waves are produced in the first 10 ms. The first, third, and fifth waves are most stable. The waves are studied for absolute latency, interwave latency (usually between waves I and V), and the amplitude.

Option A: OAE

  • OAE is a screening test.
  • The tests available for newborn hearing screening are automated otoacoustic emissions (AOAEs) using either transient or distortion product otoacoustic emissions or automated auditory brainstem response (AABR).
  • Otoacoustic emissions reflect the activity in the outer hair cells of the cochlea, while AABR measures the neural response from the brainstem.
  •  Both types of tests are available in portable. Most screening programs use a two-stage protocol (either OAE followed by AABR if required or two-stage AABR).
  • The OAE is quick and minimally invasive, and consumable costs are relatively low compared with AABR.

Option C: PTA

  • Pure Tone Audiometry an audiometer is an electronic device that produces pure tones, the intensity of which can be increased or decreased in 5 dB steps.
  •  The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing impairment at that frequency.
  •  It is charted in the form of a graph called an audiogram.

Option D. Impedance

  • This option is incorrect because it is an audiometry test for the middle ear and is difficult to do in children; and also has no role in confirming hearing loss in infants.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with bluish discolouration of both lower extremities. The oral mucosa is pink, and cyanosis does not involve the upper limbs. The patient was born prematurely at 36 weeks gestation via normal vaginal delivery, and there was no known history of cyanosis in the neonatal period. He has met all the developmental milestones. He is up to date with his current vaccination. On examination, his temperature is 37.2 (98.9F), blood pressure is 95/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 108/min, and respiratory rate is 22/min. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 95% in the right upper extremity, but 83% in the left lower extremity. Cardiac auscultation reveals a continuous machine-like murmur radiating to the interscapular area. Chest examination is unremarkable. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Which of the following is the possible underlying cause of this differential cyanosis in this child?
questions.solution:
Option A: PDA with reversal of shunt

  • This patient's condition, including cyanosis of lower limbs only (differential cyanosis) and continuous machine-like murmur radiating to the interscapular area, is consistent with patent ductus arteriosus with reversal of shunt.

 

 


PATENT DUCTUS ARTERIOSUS (PDA):

  • Failure of closure of ductus arteriosus after birth, resulting in a persistent connection between the aorta & pulmonary artery. Normally, PDA is acyanotic heart disease and blood flows from the aorta (highly oxygenated blood) to the pulmonary artery (low oxygenated blood), but with time, the right side of the heart undergoes remodelling due to increased blood overload across the shunt resulting in pulmonary hypertension with subsequent reversal of shunt, i.e. blood flows from right-to-left across the shunt known as Eisenmenger syndrome and differential cyanosis is seen.
  • The reason for the differential cyanosis is that with the right-to-left shunt across the PDA, deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle is preferentially directed into the aorta distal to the left subclavian artery and into the lower extremities. No cyanosis in the upper limbs is seen as oxygenated blood goes there.
  • Risk factors of PDA include hypoxia, maternal rubella infection, and prematurity.
  • Continuous machine murmur radiating to the interscapular or left infraclavicular area is the characteristic feature.
  • Treatment: For medical closure of PDA in preterm neonates, NSAIDS (prostaglandin inhibitor), mainly indomethacin or ibuprofen, is used.

Option B: VSD with Eisenmenger syndrome

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD) presents with a holosystolic murmur, not with a continuous machinery murmur.
  • The continuous machinery murmur with radiation to the interscapular area and differential cyanosis is consistent with PDA with shunt reversal.

Option C: Tetralogy of Fallot

  • The features of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) are PROV: Pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect (VSD). 
  • The murmur may be systolic due to pulmonary stenosis or holosystolic murmur of VSD.
  • Continuous machinery murmur is not seen in TOF.

Option D: ASD with reversal of shunt

  • The murmur of ASD is either a diastolic murmur at the tricuspid area or a systolic murmur at the pulmonic area.
  • This child’s differential cyanosis and machinery murmur strongly indicate PDA with shunt reversal.

questions.text: Pasteurization is a process in which packaged and non-packaged foods are treated with mild heat, usually to less than 100°C to eliminate pathogens and extend shelf life. Which one of the following is NOT used in testing for adequate pasteurization of milk?
questions.solution:
Option D: Glucose reduction test

  • This option is incorrect.

Other options

Option A: Phosphatase test

  • This test is frequently used to evaluate the effectiveness of pasteurization.
  • The test is based on the discovery that raw milk contains phosphatase, an enzyme that is destroyed when heated at a degree that nearly resembles the standard time and temperature needed for pasteurization.
  • Phosphatase is totally destroyed at 60 degrees C for 30 minutes. In order to identify inadequate pasteurization or the addition of raw milk, the test is used.

Option B: Coliform count

  • Coliform bacteria are often totally destroyed by pasteurization, their presence in pasteurized milk is a sign that either the pasteurization was done incorrectly or that there was contamination after the pasteurization process.
  • The majority of nations require that there be no coliforms in 1 milliliter of milk.

Option C: Standard plate count

  • The standard plate count is used to assess the bacteriological quality of pasteurized milk.
  • The majority of Western nations mandate a limit of 30,000 microorganisms per milliliter of pasteurized milk.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female recently delivered a healthy baby. She wants to undergo a sterilization operation to prevent unwanted pregnancies in future. Which of the following is the correct ideal time to perform Post-partum sterilization as per Government of India guidelines?

choices.text: From 12 hours to 7 days of delivery
From 24 hours to 7 days of delivery
From 48 hours to 7 days of delivery

questions.solution:
Option B: From 24 hours to 7 days of delivery

  • Puerperal Sterilization/post-partum sterilization.
  • It is best done within 2-3 days after delivery.
  • The upper limit is 7-10 days (not 6 weeks).
  • After delivery, the uterus becomes a pelvic organ in 10-14 days and becomes a normal organ in 4-6 weeks.
  • Interval Sterilization: It is done after 6 weeks of delivery and is done by Laparoscopic methods.
  • Concurrent Sterilization: It is done along with MTPs or cesarean section.
  • Surgical Sterilization procedures are shown below:

Learning Objective

Sterilization New Guidelines 2014

FEMALE STERILIZATION MALE STERILIZATION
  • Married
  • Married
  • 22-49 yrs old female
  • 22-60 yrs old male
  • ≥ 1 living child should be present [> 1yr of age]
  • ≥ 1 living child [> 1yr of age] is present
  • No past history of self/ spouse sterilization
  • No past history of self/ spouse sterilization
  • MINILAP - Done by trained MBBS/ MD Gyn-obs/ DGO
  • Conventional vasectomy - Trained MBBS & above
  • Laparoscopic sterilization- MD Gyn-OBG /DGO
  • MS Surgery
  • No scalpel vasectomy [NSV] - Trained MBBS & above

questions.text: A rural village is supplied with adequate water to meet domestic needs. Which of the following is the recommended per capita allowance of water per day?
questions.solution:
Option A: 40-60 lit

  • In Rural villages recommended per capita allowance of water is 40-60 litres per capita per day.

other options

Option B: 80-120 lit

The recommended per capita allowance of water in rural villages is 40-60 litres per capita per day.

Option C: 120-150 lit

  • Urban: 150-200 liters per capita per day.
  • Rural: 40-60 liters per capita per day.

Option D: 150-200 lit

  • In an Urban area recommended per capita allowance of water is 150-200 liters per capita per day.
  • Therefore, for Rural villages, this is an incorrect choice.

questions.text: In a given population, the total number of births in a year is 4050. There are 50 stillbirths. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life whereas the number of deaths within 8-28 days of life is 150. What is the Neonatal mortality rate in the population?
questions.solution:
Option B: 50

Neonatal mortality rate

  • Neonatal deaths are deaths occurring during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending 28 completed days after birth.
  • The neonatal mortality rate is the number of neonatal deaths in a given year per 1000 live births in that year.

In the given case,

  • Total neonatal deaths = Total early neonatal deaths + Total late neonatal deaths = 50 + 150 = 200
  • Total live births = Total births – Total stillbirths = 4050 – 50 = 4000
  • NMR = Neonatal death / Live births × 1000
  • Thus, the Neonatal mortality rate, NMR = 200/4000 × 1000 = 50 per 1000 live births.

Other options are incorrect

questions.text:
A patient presents to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of nasal stuffiness for the past few days. He also has had headaches and a runny nose for 3 months. On CT scan, heterogeneous opacification involving multiple sinuses along with bone erosion is noticed as shown below:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis

  • Allergic fungal rhino-sinusitis results from hypersensitivity to fungi.
  • Heterogeneous opacification in multiple sinuses with areas of central hypo-attenuation is characteristic of AFRS.
  • Erosion of the walls of the sinuses occurs that may extend to the orbits.
  • Children with allergic fungal rhinosinusitis may present with proptosis and polyposis, which is relatively prevalent in adults with CRS.
  • Areas of increased signal intensity are thought to be due to the accumulation of heavy metals such as iron, manganese, and calcium within the inspissated allergic mucin.

Option A: Acute bacterial rhinosinusitis

  • This usually follows viral upper respiratory infection due to viral damages to the cilia and epithelium.
  • The most common bacteria responsible for this are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis, and Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Clinical features include nasal obstruction and purulent rhinorrhoea. Facial pain/pressure are cardinal symptoms.
  • Therefore, it is a false statement.

Option B: Chronic bacterial rhinosinusitis

  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease of nasal and paranasal sinus mucosa where symptoms persist beyond 12 weeks.
  • Endoscopic examination of the nose may reveal:
    • Edema of nasal mucosa in the anterior or posterior ostiomeatal complex and
    • Purulent discharge.
    • Nasal endoscopy should be done first without and then with a nasal decongestant.
  • Therefore, it is a false statement.

Option D: Invasive fungal rhinosinusitis

  • It can be acute or chronic.
  • Acute invasive fungal sinusitis is a medical emergency that demands surgery.
  • It usually occurs in people who have compromised immune systems.
  • Therefore, it is a false statement.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male underwent renal transplantation (in the right iliac fossa) in 2008 for chronic interstitial nephritis-related renal failure with the mother as a donor. He was treated with triple immunosuppression (cyclosporine, prednisolone and mycophenolate mofetil). The patient was normal till 2020, when he developed dull-aching, non-radiating right lower abdominal pain. A hard tumour (about 15 cm x 10 cm) was felt under the surgical scar in the right iliac fossa. Ultrasound-guided biopsy from the mass revealed monomorphic B-cell non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. The blood's lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level was 850 U/L(normal: 140–280 units per litre). The 18FDG PET-CT was taken from the figure below. Serum creatinine was 1.10 mg/dl. It was diagnosed as a case of Post Transplant Lymphoma; it is caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: EBV

  • Nasopharyngeal cancer, or cancer of the back of the nose, and some rapidly spreading lymphomas, like Burkitt lymphoma, are made more likely by EBV infection.
  • Additionally, some occurrences of stomach cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma may be connected.

Epstein-Barr virus

  • Lymphoid Malignancy
  • Post–organ transplant lymphoma
  • Primary CNS diffuses large B cell lymphoma
  • Extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma, nasal type
  • Hodgkin’s disease
  • Although no medicine can cure an EBV infection, you can take these steps at home to ease your symptoms:
    • Get plenty of rest.
    • Drink a lot of water and other liquids to stay hydrated.

Option A: CMV

  • In some cases, infection in healthy people can cause mild illnesses that may include:
    • Fever
    • Sore throat
    • Fatigue
    • Swollen glands
  • Blood, tears, semen, saliva, urine, and breast milk are a few examples of bodily fluids through which CMV patients may spread the virus. Infected individuals can transmit CMV to others in the following ways:
    • directly in contact with saliva or urine, particularly that of infants or young children
    • via sexual interaction
  • Blood tests can diagnose adults with signs of CMV infection. Blood, however, is not the ideal fluid to test babies who have a possible CMV infection. For neonates, saliva or urine tests are suggested.
  • Antiviral drugs, particularly valganciclovir, may enhance hearing and developmental outcomes for infants who exhibit congenital CMV infection at birth.

Option C: Herpes simplex

  • There are two forms of the herpes simplex virus (HSV): HSV-1 and HSV-2. HSV-1 can cause genital herpes but is most commonly spread by oral-to-oral contact. It causes oral herpes, which includes symptoms known as cold sores. Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted disease caused by HSV-2.
  • Symptoms:
    • Cold sores around their lips, mouth or tongue. They may look crusty or like fluid-filled blisters.
    • Sores on their genitals or around their anus.
    • Tingling, itching or burning.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Viral culture. This test involves taking a tissue sample or scraping the sores for examination in the laboratory
    • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test.
    • Blood test.
  • For those with HSV infection, antiviral drugs, including acyclovir, famciclovir, and valacyclovir, are most effective (see WHO recommendations). However, they cannot treat the infection; they can only help lessen the symptoms' intensity and frequency.

Option D: H. Influenza virus

  • "Haemophilus influenzae sickness" refers to any ailment brought on by the H bacterium. influenzae.
  • Some of these illnesses are mild, like ear infections, while others are quite deadly, like bloodstream infections. H. Despite its name, influenzae does not cause the flu.
  • A doctor often diagnoses Haemophilus influenzae infection using one or more laboratory tests. A blood or spinal fluid sample is used in most diagnostic procedures.
  • The oral antibiotics trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, cefuroxime axetil, cefixime, clarithromycin, azithromycin, and fluoroquinolones all have an action against beta-lactamase-producing H influenzae.

questions.text: A 25-year-female presents with facial, leg and generalized body swelling for the last few weeks. The urine output has been decreased as well. She has no chronic medical condition and does not take any medication. Lab investigations reveal proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and high triglyceride levels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of hypercoagulation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Loss of antithrombin III (AT III)

  • Nephrotic syndrome (NS) is a glomerular disorder typically characterized by gross proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and peripheral oedema.
  • Thrombotic and thromboembolic complications are common in nephrotic syndrome due to loss of anticoagulant factor (e.g. antithrombin III, protein C and S) combined with increased platelet activation.
  • Renal vein thrombo­sis is most often a consequence of this hypercoagulative state.
  • There is also increased synthesis of fibrinogen in the liver.
  • IDA due to decreased transferrin levels.

Option B: Increase in protein S

  • Protein S is an anticoagulant factor and is generally lost in the nephrotic syndrome, leading to hypercoagulability.

Option C: Decreased metabolism of vitamin K

  • The metabolism of vitamin K is not disrupted in the nephrotic syndrome and would continue to perform its usual function normally.

Option D: Increase in Protein C

  • Loss of protein C occurs in the nephrotic syndrome leading to a hypercoagulable state.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with abdominal pain associated with vomiting and diarrhea, arthralgia with joint swelling and elevation, and red skin rashes on the lower legs and buttocks. There is pedal oedema on physical examination. The vitals are within normal limits. On urine examination, there is blood and proteins in the urine. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Henoch Schonlein purpura

  • The given clinical picture of the child with abdominal pain, arthralgia & palpable purpura suggests a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura.
  • The diagnostic criteria of the Henoch Schonlein purpura are palpable purpura with the presence of 1 or more of any sign, which includes;
    • Diffuse abdominal pain
    • Arthritis or arthralgia
    • Any biopsy showing Ig A deposition
    • Renal involvement

Option A: Kawasaki disease

  • In Kawasaki disease, there is a history of high-grade fever for more than 5 days.
  • Along with fever patient has conjunctivitis, oral cavity changes, rash, peeling of the skin and cervical lymphadenopathy.

Option C: Juvenile Idiopathic arthritis

  • It is a common type of arthritis in children below the age of 16.
  • Patient experience joint pain, stiffness and swelling.

Option D: Behcet syndrome

  • It is a rare disorder caused by inflammation of blood vessels.
  • It causes inflammation in the eyes, oral cavity ulceration, skin rashes and genital sores.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl is admitted to the pediatric ward with a history of severe diarrhea for the past five days. When she presented to the emergency department, she was clinically dehydrated, her pulse was 120 per minute, and her blood pressure was 100/60 mmHg (lying down) and 70/40 mmHg (when sitting). The electrolytes and arterial blood gases collected on admission and the following day are as follows:


	
		
			Arterial Blood Gas and Electrolyte Results
		
		
			 
			On Admission
			Next Day
		
		
			Na+
			137
			137
		
		
			K+
			2.5
			4.2
		
		
			Cl-
			118
			114
		
		
			HCO3-
			5
			15
		
		
			Creatinine
			0.31
			 
		
		
			Anion gap
			10
			8
		
		
			pH
			7.11
			7.49
		
		
			pCO2
			16
			20
		
		
			HCO3
			4.9
			14.7
		
	


What of the following abnormalities is present at the time of admission?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and hypokalaemia

  • The patient suffered from severe diarrhoea complicated with dehydration, which could have resulted in the loss of bicarbonate (due to loss of intestinal secretions), leading to metabolic acidosis (with normal anion gap), and loss of potassium, leading to hypokalemia.
  • The normal level of potassium is 3.5 to 5 mEq/L. A value of 2.5 mEq/L, as present in this patient at the time of admission, is significant for hypokalemia.
  • A pH of 7.11 (less than normal 7.35 to 7.45) indicates acidosis.
  • The next step is to identify whether the acidosis is caused by a primary metabolic disorder or primary respiratory disorder. A significantly reduced level of bicarbonate at the time of admission indicates metabolic acidosis. This is consistent with the patient history of severe diarrhoea.
  • A decreased level of PaCO2 suggests that the respiratory compensation against the primary metabolic disorder has started.
  • The normal level of chloride ranges from 96 to 106 mEq/L. At the time of admission, this patient's chloride level was increased, which indicates hyperchloremia (the chloride levels are typically elevated in normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, such as in diarrhoea, to offset the neutrality disturbance caused by loss of bicarbonate).
  • So, compiling all these findings indicates Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and hypokalaemia.

Option A: Hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis and hypokalaemia

  • The patient presented above had severe metabolic acidosis (not alkalosis) at the time of admission, shown by a pH level of less than 7.35.
  • Moreover, the chloride levels are raised, not decreased.

Option B: Hyperchloremic metabolic alkalosis and hypokalaemia

  • A pH of less than 7.35 indicates that the patient has acidosis. In metabolic alkalosis, the pH is elevated, and the bicarbonate levels are raised.

Option D: Hypochloremic metabolic acidosis and hypokalaemia

  • The laboratory findings are consistent with metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia. However, the chloride levels are raised, not decreased.
  • The chloride levels are typically elevated in normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, such as in diarrhoea, to offset the neutrality disturbance caused by loss of bicarbonate.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented in the outpatient department 7 days ago with complaints of being irritable and fretful. His mother says the boy's hair is thin and easily pluckable. On examination, the boy has dry hair, sparse hair, emaciated arms and buttocks, and staring eyes. On anthropometry, he has a low height and weight for his age. He was admitted to the pediatric ward and is under treatment. His body weight was recorded daily. The child started to gain weight initially, but in the rehabilitation phase, there was a secondary failure to respond to the treatment. Which of the following is true regarding the same?

choices.text: Failure to regain appetite by day 4
Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day for consecutive days during the rehabilitation phase
Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day by day 10

questions.solution:
Option C: Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day for consecutive days during the rehabilitation phase

  • The patient has a history of being irritable and fretful suggestive of poor psychosocial development and is also having thin, brittle hair. His examination and anthropometric findings are also suggestive of Marasmus.
  • The response to management in inpatient settings is assessed through close monitoring.
  • There can be a primary failure during phase 1 or the initial phase of management or a secondary failure.
  • Secondary failure occurs during the rehabilitation phase, i.e. when a child has a good appetite and weight gain.
  • Secondary failure to respond is indicated by failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day for consecutive days.
  • This can be due to poor neuromuscular coordination of muscles of the upper gastrointestinal tract, acute infection and refeeding syndrome.

Option A: Failure to regain appetite by day 4

  • Primary failure to respond is indicated by failure to regain appetite by day fourth.
  • The cause must be investigated and managed properly.

Option B: Presence of oedema on day 10

  • The presence of oedema on day 10th also indicates a primary failure.
  • This can increase morbidity and mortality to a significant extent.

Option D: Failure to gain at least 5 g/kg/day by day 10

  • Failure to enter the rehabilitation phase or gain at least 5g/kg/day by the 10th day of the initial phase is a primary failure

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric outpatient department by his mother due to short height. She is concerned that the child looks shorter than other children of the same age and has had no change in his voice until now. The clinician carries out a physical examination and examines the growth chart (shown below):



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the patient based on the growth chart?

choices.text: Constitutional delay in growth and puberty

questions.solution:
Option A: Constitutional delay in growth and puberty

Features

Constitutional growth delay

Height

Short

Height velocity

Normal

Family history

Delayed puberty

Bone age

Less than chronological age

Puberty

Delayed

Rate of growth

Slow from infancy

Growth hormone

Normal

Gonadotrophin level

Normal
  • The presented curve demonstrates that the child's height stays below and parallel to the 3rd percentile line throughout childhood.
  • It represents the constitutional delay in growth and puberty (the most common cause of short stature).
  • An acceleration of growth is seen during mid & late adolescence, with the final adult height attained being normal
  • Observation and careful monitoring of growth is required.
  • Important Causes of Proportionate Short Stature
    • Normal Variants
    • Intra-Uterine Causes
    • Post-Natal/ Acquired Causes
  • TALL STATURE: Height of a child > + 2 S.D. of expected according to age and sex of child.
    • Constitutional tall stature
    • Exogenous obesity
    • Endocrine causes
    • Syndromes like Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY), Fragile x syndrome, Marfan syndrome

Option B: Familial short stature

  • Familial short stature is a genetic problem that tends to follow the family's inherited short stature (shortness).
  • In familial short stature, the child’s height is less than the 3rd percentile of expected according to age and sex but is normal as per his target height.
  • It has the following features:
    • The child's height is within the third percentile of what is normal for his intended height, given his age and gender.
    • The child has typical puberty.
    • Short stature in the family.
    • Chronological age is equal to bone age.

Option C: Normal height throughout childhood

  • Children with constitutional delay in growth and puberty are born with a normal length and weight and grow normally for the first 6-12 months of life.
  • Then their growth shows a deceleration, so the height and weight fall below the 3rd centile.
  • After 3 years of age, normal height velocity is resumed, and they continue to grow just below and parallel to the 3rd centile.
  • So, there is no normal height throughout childhood.

Option D: Chronic malnutrition

  • Chronic malnutrition is usually linked to poor maternal health and low socioeconomic status.
  • It is associated with both constitutional and physical growth and developmental delays.
  • Weight is below average as well.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old patient comes to the clinic complaining of nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and nasal bleeding for the past few hours. Examination of the nasal cavity reveals a polypoidal mass arising from the right lateral nasal wall, as shown in the image below:



Biopsy reveals intraepithelial mucous cysts with invasion into the underlying connective tissue stroma forming large clefts, ribbons, and islands. Which of the following etiological agent is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: HPV

  • Diagnosis: Inverted Papilloma.
  • Important points regarding inverted papilloma:
    • Polypoidal mass arising from the lateral wall with epistaxis.
    • In growing/ inverted papilloma growing into their stroma on biopsy.

Inverted Papilloma

  • The most common site of origin is the lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus.
  • It is so named because hyperplastic papillomatous tissue grows into stroma rather than exophytic.
  • The human papillomavirus is thought to be responsible for its etiology.
  • Occasionally, inverted papilloma can undergo a malignant transformation into an aggressive form of cancer called squamous cell carcinoma.
  • The treatment approach is that an otolaryngologist resects inverted papilloma through a minimally invasive approach called Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS). through a minimally invasive approach called Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS).
  • More advanced tumors can require a combined approach between neurosurgery and otolaryngology called the expanded nasal approach.

Option A: HSV

  • HSV I causes Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup).
  • URI prodrome, slow onset, affects patients aged 6 months to 3 years, variable/minimal fever, hoarse with "barking" cough, and can develop respiratory difficulty with inspiratory stridor.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical; Radiographic "Steeple sign" on A.P. views.

Option C: CMV

  • CMV is the most common cause of congenital infections in humans, and congenital CMV is a leading cause of non-hereditary congenital sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), which can be progressive.

Option D: EBV

  • Infectious Mononucleosis: This is an acute infection caused by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV).
  • It occurs mainly in adolescence and is spread by close contact.
  • Fever, fatigue, malaise, and exudative tonsillitis are characteristic.
  • There is a characteristic picture on the blood film with the presence of atypical lymphocytes. Serological tests such as Monospot or Paul–Bunnel usually confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive man presented to the physician’s office with acute chest pain and difficulty breathing for one hour. On physical examination, the oxygen saturation is 98%, blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respiratory rate is 15/minutes. An urgent chest x-ray showed the presence of mediastinal widening. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Computed Tomography (CT) angiography

Aortic dissection

  • It occurs due to the tearing of the aortic intimal layer leading to the sudden onset of sharp interscapular pain.

  • There distal spread of dissection leads to renal pain and renal failure due to renal artery involvement (from the spread of dissected blood).

  • Abdominal pain and bowel ischemia from mesenteric artery involvement; Paraplegia from the involvement of spinal arteries, and leg pain, pallor, and loss of pulses due to iliac artery involvement.

  • The dissection may track proximally to cause signs of a stroke or transient ischemic attack from the involvement of head and neck vessels, myocardial infarction from the involvement of coronary vessels, and aortic regurgitation leading to cardiac tamponade.

  • The investigation of choice for acute aortic dissection is CT-Angiography.

  • Dissection of arterial wall forming shreds within false lumen - COB WEB SIGN

  • False lumen forms an acute angle giving BEAK SIGN in aortic dissection

Option A: Ultrasound

  • Echocardiography uses ultrasound to study cardiac anatomy.

  • However, it is preferred for aortic dissection in unstable patients only. This is because it is quickly performed, readily available (even at the bedside), and bears low costs.

Option C: Magnetic resonance (MR) angiography

  • MR-Angiography is not used in acute conditions but is helpful in chronic dissections to better delineate the true and false lumen.

Option D: Doppler

  • The echocardiography uses ultrasound waves with the doppler technique, which allows the study of blood flow velocities, assessment of blood flow, and end-diastolic and end-systolic left ventricular dimensions.

  • It is possible to measure the valvular identification and function as well as the assessment of pericardial space.

  • This technique can be used in unstable patients with transesophageal echocardiography as it is readily available, low-cost bearing and quickly performed at the bedside.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman at 32 weeks of pregnancy presents with abdominal pain and mild vaginal bleeding. On examination, her uterus is tender with size greater than expected for dates and absent fetal heart sounds. Per vaginal examination shows a small amount of fluid in the vagina and the cervix closed. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Option B: Concealed haemorrhage

  • This is a case of abruption with concealed retroplacental bleed, which makes the uterus tender and also increases the uterine size.
  • Of note that there may also be some amount of vaginal bleeding noted in concealed haemorrhage.

Placental abruption A. visible external bleeding B. concealed haemorrhage.

  • Uterine tenderness occurs because of bruising of the uterine surface.
  • With abruption, the fetal heart sounds are often not heard due to the taut abdominal wall and hypertonic uterus, even when the fetus is alive.
  • If the fetal heart rate is normal, the best management is to induce labour.
  • However, if the fetus has decreasing heart rate (e.g., category 3 FHR), immediate cesarean section is required.

​​​​​​​Option A: Hydramnios

  • Hydramnios is a condition when excessive amniotic fluid builds up during pregnancy. It is also called polyhydramnios.
  • It can occur due to various reasons, including gestational diabetes, fetal anomalies that cause impaired swallowing of amniotic fluid and fetal infection. However, in certain cases, it can be idiopathic.
  • Some common symptoms of polyhydramnios include a uterus greater than expected size, breathing difficulties in the mother due to excessive distention of the uterus and breech presentation.
