  • It does not cause uterine tenderness or difficulty in locating fetal heart

Option C: Active labour

  • Active labour is the second part of the first stage of labour which begins when the cervix is 6cm dilated.
  • Here, the cervix is closed so labour is ruled out.
  • It has an expected duration during which the cervix dilates fully to 10cm and ends with the delivery of the baby.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option D: Uterine rupture

  • Uterine rupture is an obstetrics emergency that requires an immediate cesarean section.
  • A spontaneous rupture in the uterus leads to the fetus being expelled into the peritoneal cavity.
  • It leads to rapid exsanguination and the demise of the fetus.
  • It commonly occurs along the healed scar lines in women who have had a prior cesarean section or can also occur during vaginal bleeding.
  • It may cause severe vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male known case of coronary artery disease was brought to the casualty with complaints of severe abdominal pain and abdominal distension. The patient was further evaluated and suspected to have acute mesenteric ischemia and taken up for emergency laparotomy. Type of Mesenteric ischemia best visualized by CECT:
questions.solution:
Acute mesenteric venous thrombosis is best visualized by CECT

Mesenteric ischemia

  • Insufficient perfusion of the mesentery to meet the metabolic demands of the splanchnic system
  • The four commonly identified causes of acute mesenteric ischemia include
    • Arterial embolism (AE)
    • Arterial thrombosis (AT)
    • Venous thrombosis (VT)
    • Nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia (NOMI)
  • DIAGNOSIS
    • Arterial embolism
      • Conventional clinical examination may be enough evidence to initiate therapy in cases where laparotomy is required
      • CT angiography is now the imaging modality of choice
    • Arterial thrombosis
      • CT angiography is the imaging modality of choice
    • Nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia
      • Conventional diagnostic angiography is the imaging modality of choice
    • Venous thrombosis
      • Abdominal CT with appropriate venous phase contrast is highly sensitive and specific to diagnose mesenteric venous thrombosis
  • Findings
    • Vein wall enhancement
    • Distended venous lumen
    • Noncontrast opacified thrombus

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with cystic fibrosis is planned for a single lung transplant. Twenty years ago, she was diagnosed with cystic fibrosis. She underwent a left pneumonectomy due to a huge aspergilloma in the upper lobe of the left lung five years ago. She now suffers from progressive dyspnea and recurrent respiratory infections in the single lung. The doctor decides to proceed with right lung transplantation. The operating surgeon would prefer which order of anastomosis of the structures?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pulmonary vein, bronchus, pulmonary artery

  • The order of anastomosis in lung transplant is a pulmonary vein, bronchus, and pulmonary artery.

LUNG TRANSPLANTATION

  • The most common indications for lung transplantation are
    • Interstitial lung disease (ILD),
    • Advanced chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD),
    • Cystic fibrosis (CF),
    • Emphysema due to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, and
    • Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)
    • Bronchiolitis obliterans

PROCEDURE: It is of two types:

  • Single Liver Transplantation:
    • It is performed through posterolateral thoracotomy.
    • It is done for patients with a disease affecting one lung way more than the other, or the person has one lung only/
  • Double Lung Transplantation: It is performed through bilateral thoracotomy or median sternotomy
  • After the initial skin incision and separation of all thoracic layers, the lung tissue is exposed. The lung is removed and replaced by a donor's lung. The structures are anastomosed in the following order.
  • Pulmonary vein → Bronchial Anastomosis → Pulmonary Artery
  • This allows for blood to flow without pooling in the tissue. As soon as the artery is connected, blood starts flowing through the system, and if the veins have already been anastomosed, blood will flow without causing hemorrhagic ischemia.
  • Also, anastomosing the bronchus gives enough time for the venous system to play when arteries are joined.

COMPLICATIONS OF LUNG TRANSPLANTATION:

  • Some complications from lung transplantation may include, but are not limited to, the following:
    • Bleeding.
    • Infection.
    • Blockage of the blood vessels to the new lung(s)
    • Blockage of the airways.
    • Severe pulmonary oedema (fluid in the lung)
    • Blood clots
    • Dehiscence of airway anastomosis
    • Late airway stenosis at bronchial anastomosis due to ischemia: Treated by dilatation
    • Chronic rejection

Option A: Pulmonary artery, pulmonary vein, bronchus

  • Anastomosing the artery before the veins will lead to increased blood flow through the lung tissue
  • It will lead to blood pooling and oedema.

Option C: Pulmonary vein, pulmonary artery, bronchus

  • Bronchus needs to be joined before anastomosing arteries to give time to veins.
  • If not, it will result in rapid blood flow through veins before the anastomosis is functional.

Option D: Pulmonary artery, bronchus, pulmonary vein

  • Anastomosing the artery before the veins will lead to increased blood flow through the lung tissue
  • It will lead to blood pooling and oedema

questions.text: What intermediate of the TCA cycle is depleted in patients with uncontrolled diabetes leading to it's suppression?
questions.solution:
Option D: Oxaloacetate

  • Remember diabetic condition is like fasting/starvation (catabolic state) as body tissues do not get enough glucose. Hence gluconeogenesis and lipolysis are upregulated.
  • TCA suppression in diabetes occurs due to the following reasons:
    • Excess lipolysis leads to increased beta-oxidation of fatty acids, which leads to excess NADH formation and further depletes NAD. This suppresses TCA.
    • Oxaloacetate is used up gluconeogenesis and hence is not available for TCA.
    • Acetyl CoA is diverted to ketone body synthesis.

Option A: Succinate

  • Succinate is not involved in gluconeogenesis.
  • On the other hand, succinate is formed during the catabolism of ketone bodies
  • So, during fasting the succinate will not be depleted rather get increased

Option B: Malate

  • Though malate is formed during gluconeogenesis no net malate is used for glucose synthesis.
  • So, malate concentration is not affected during diabetes.

Option C: α-Ketoglutarate

  • α-Ketoglutarate is mainly used for anabolic reactions such as synthesis of non-essential amino acids glutamate, proline and arginine etc.
  • In diabetes, anabolic reactions are suppressed in general as is also amino acid synthesis
  • So, there will not be any depletion of α-Ketoglutarate

questions.text: A primigravida came with complaints of pain abdomen at 39 weeks of pregnancy. The doctor examines and finds that there are regular contractions every half an hour and the cervix admits one finger. This stage is said to be prolonged if it lasts more than?
questions.solution:
Option D: 20 hours

  •  The stage described in the question is the latent phase of labour which starts with the onset of true Labour pains till the start of active labour (cervical dilatation of 4 cms).
  • True Labour pains here are suggested by uterine contractions occurring at intervals and associated with cervical dilatation
  • Latent phase in a Primigravida is prolonged if its more than 20 hours, multigravida if its more than 14 hours

 

Labour Pattern

Primigravida

Multigravida

Prolonged latent phase

> 20hours

>14 hr

Protracted dilatation

< 1.2 cm/hr

< 1.5 cm/hr

Protracted descent

< 1 cm/hr

< 2 cm/hr

Arrest of dilatation

No dilatation for > 2 hrs

Arrest of descent

No descent for > 1 hr

 

 

Stages of Labour

First

 

 From the onset of true labour pains to full cervical dilatation

 
Second

 

 Full cervical dilatation to delivery of the baby

 
Third

 

 Delivery of baby to delivery of the placenta

 
Fourth

 

 Stage of observation, till 1 hour after delivery of the placenta

 

 

First stage is further divided into

Latent phase

 

 Cervical dilatation ≤ 3 cm

 

 Irregular contractions
  • Tocolytics in preterm labour given only in this phase
Active phase

 

 Cervical dilatation ≥ 4 cm

 

 Tocolytics in preterm labour cannot be given in the act

 

 

Option A: 3 Hours

  •  The stage described in the question is the latent phase of labour which starts with the onset of true Labour pains till the start of active labour.
  • The true answer is 20 hours, not 3 hours

 

Option B: 8 Hours

  •  The stage described in the question is the latent phase of labour which starts with the onset of true Labour pains till the start of active Labour
  • 8 hours is not the correct option

 

Option C: 12 Hours

  • The stage described in the question is the latent phase of labour which starts with the onset of true Labour pains till the start of active labour (cervical dilatation of 4 cms).
  • True Labour pains here are suggested by uterine contractions occurring at intervals and associated with cervical dilatation

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the clinic with the complaint of primary amenorrhea. Her height is 170 cm, and her weight is 45 kg. On examination, there is absent breast development; however, the vagina is normal. Puffiness of her hands and feet is also observed. Ultrasonography reveals a hypoplastic uterus and bilateral ovaries are not visualized. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Turner’s syndrome

This patient’s symptoms are consistent with turner syndrome.

Turner syndrome (45, X) is the most common karyotypic abnormality causing gonadal failure and primary amenorrhea.

Amenorrhea is the result of accelerated atresia of the follicles. The fibrotic ovaries are called streak ovaries.

It is a chromosomal disorder which results from the partial or complete absence of one of the second sex chromosomes (45 XO).

Associated stigmata with Turner syndrome include

    • Gonadal Failure
    • Short stature
    • Webbed neck
    • Shield chest
    • Cubitus valgus
    • low hair line
    • high arched palate
    • multiple pigmented nevi
    • Short fourth metacarpals
  • Gonadal dysgenesis can cause premature ovarian failure.
  • Associated medical conditions include cardiac (30% have coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve, hypertension), renal (horseshoe kidney), autoimmune (thyroiditis), increased risk of fractures and osteoporosis.
  • Most females will require hormone replacement therapy for proper breast development and begin menstruation.
  • Turner syndrome may be diagnosed before birth or shortly after birth, but in some cases, it is diagnosed during adolescence and early adulthood.  
  • The image below portrays a few clinical features associated with Turner syndrome.

Option B: Swyer syndrome

  • Swyer syndrome is much rarer.
  • It is characterised by failed development of the sex glands, i.e. testes and ovaries. Hence uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes and upper 4/5th of the vagina are made. The urogenital sinus makes the lower 1/5th vagina.
  • It is the 46XY 'female'.
  • Since there are no working androgens, there is no masculinisation and no feminisation since there is no estrogen production because the ovaries are replaced by fibrous tissue.

Option C: Mullerian agenesis

    • It is due to embryonic growth failure resulting in the underdevelopment of the uterus and vagina. External genitalia is normal.
    • Due to the absence of a uterus, affected individuals do not menstruate.
    • These individuals have a female chromosomal pattern (46 XX) and normal ovaries, due to which they develop female sexual characteristics, i.e. normal breast development and axillary and pubic hair growth.

Option D: Androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • Androgen insensitivity is a genotypic male with functional testes. Still, the androgen made by the testes is not recognised by the end organs; hence, they reach the periphery and convert to estrogens.
  • It leads to external feminisation.

questions.text: A 26- year old gravida 3 para 2 living 2 at 40 weeks of gestational age presents in the second stage of labour. The baby's head delivers spontaneously but then retracts back against the perineum; even with downward traction, the baby's anterior shoulder fails to deliver. Which of the following is not the appropriate step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Instruct the nurse to apply fundal pressure
Instruct the nurse to flex the hip joint so that the patient's legs are up to her chest

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option A: Instruct the nurse to apply fundal pressure

Shoulder dystocia occurs when the foetal shoulders fail to deliver spontaneously after the head has been delivered due to the impaction of the anterior shoulder against the pubic bone.

Steps in the management of shoulder dystocia:

  1. Call for help
  2. Apply suprapubic pressure to disengage the anterior shoulder
  3. Flex the mother's legs over the abdomen, i.e. McRobert's manoeuvre
  4. Rotate the posterior shoulder and attempt delivery of the posterior shoulder, i.e. Wood's corkscrew manoeuvre
  5. Push the delivered foetal head back into the delivery canal in preparation for a caesarean section, i.e. Zavanelli's restitution
  6. Apply modest downward traction to the posterior shoulder (the shoulder against the maternal sacrum) or upward traction to the anterior shoulder (the shoulder against the maternal symphysis) with the patient on her hands and knees, i.e. Gaskin manoeuvre
  7. A generous episiotomy should always be made to allow manipulations
  8. There is no role for fundal pressure.

Option B: Call for help

  • Calling for help is the first and foremost step in managing complicated labour.

Option C: Cut a generous episiotomy

  • A generous episiotomy should always be made to allow manipulations.

Option D: Instruct the nurse to flex the hip joint so that the patient's legs are up to her chest

  • Flexing the mother's hip joint until her legs are up to her chest is the McRoberts manoeuvre.
  • It requires two persons, one at each leg of the patient.
  • The helpers grip and press the maternal foot cephalad, causing hyperflexion of the maternal hips and knees and minor hip abduction, resulting in a 1-2 cm superior displacement of the pubic symphysis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida, at 29 weeks of gestation, presents to the outpatient department for a regular antenatal checkup. Her pregnancy has been uneventful so far. She does not smoke and has no history of illicit drug use. She is upset because of spidery veins appearing on her face, upper chest, and arms. What will you do next?

choices.text: Do LFTs to rule out any liver disease
Refer her to a vascular surgeon to have the veins removed

questions.solution:
Option D: Reassurance is Enough

  • Spider angiomas are collections of tiny dilated blood vessels that usually radiate from a central point and resemble the legs of a spider.
  • The appearance of these blood vessels is a normal occurrence with pregnancy and usually resolves spontaneously after delivery
  • It occurs due to hormonal changes, i.e., hyperketonemia, which occurs during pregnancy.
  • Reassurance is enough, and they do not require any medical intervention.

 

 

Option A: Do LFTs to rule out any liver disease

  • This is a normal occurrence in pregnancy, and it will be a monetary burden on the patient to undergo undue testing.

Option B: Refer her to a dermatologist

  • There is no need to refer to a dermatologist because this will resolve as soon as the baby has been delivered.

Option C: Refer her to a vascular surgeon to have the veins removed

  • These will regress once the baby has been delivered and the pregnancy is over.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presented to the physician with right leg pain and swelling for 3 days. she also has a history of 3 spontaneous abortions less than 12 weeks gestation. Physical examination shows swollen tender leg. The right calf circumference is more than the left, and there is a palpable cord in the right leg. Laboratory studies show a prothrombin time of 12 seconds and an activated partial thromboplastin time of 51 seconds. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Antiphospholipid syndrome

  • Antiphospholipid syndrome is an autoimmune condition which may lead to thrombosis in various tissues.
  • During pregnancy, antiphospholipid syndrome also can result in miscarriage and stillbirth. Some people who have the syndrome have no signs or symptoms.

Clinical criteria:

  • Vascular Thrombosis
  • Recurrent pregnancy loss >=3 spontaneous abortions <10 weeks
  • Death of normal fetus > 10 weeks
  • Premature birth at <34 weeks due to pre-eclampsia or placental insufficiency

Laboratory Features:

  1. Elevated anticardiolipin antibodies (IgG or IgM)
  2. Elevated Anti-beta-2 glycoprotein -1 Antibody
  3. Presence of Lupus Anticoagulant (LA) in plasma

Option A: Chromosomal abnormality

  • Chromosomal abnormalities of the embryo are not associated with thrombotic complications in the mother.

Option B: Factor VIII deficiency

  • Factor VIII deficiency or Haemophilia A is a genetic deficiency in clotting factor VIII, which causes increased bleeding and usually affects males.
  • In most cases, it is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait, though some cases arise from spontaneous mutations.
  • Women rarely have this deficiency but are more common carriers, which implies the baby can have haemophilia for which the fetus needs to be tested.
  • This condition is not associated with thrombosis.​​​​​​​

Option D: Increased antithrombin III levels

  • Antithrombin III deficiency (and not increased antithrombin III) is an inherited thrombophilia.
  • It is one of the rare causes of venous thromboembolism in pregnancy.
  • Antithrombin III deficiency is estimated to carry a 30% risk of venous thrombotic complications during each pregnancy and postpartum.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: The obstetrician examines her patient in labor. The patient is a primigravida with a cephalic presentation at term with spontaneous labor pains. The doctor assesses the fetal head to have engaged and orders oxytocin augmentation. This finding implies which of the following?

choices.text: When the occiput has gone below the pelvic inlet
When the widest diameter of the presenting part has passed through the pelvic inlet
When the presenting part can be pushed into the pelvic cavity
Synonymous with fixation of the head

questions.solution:
Option B: When the widest diameter of the presenting part has passed through the pelvic inlet

  • Engagement - The mechanism by which the widest diameter of the presenting part, such as the biparietal diameter in an occiput presentation, passes through the pelvic inlet, per abdomen <1/5th of the head is palpable, and vaginally, the head is at the level of ischial spines.
  • Deflexed head is the most common cause of non-engagement (brow presentation), which is delivered by the caesarian section.
  •  In primis (first-time mothers), engagement typically occurs before labour.

Option A: When the occiput has gone below the pelvic inlet

  • When the occiput has gone below the pelvic inlet, it does not imply that the engaging diameter has crossed the inlet as the occiput is the leading point of the vertex.
  • Engagement is when the baby's head is even with the ischial spines. The baby is said to be "engaged" when the largest part of the head has entered the pelvis.

Option C: When the presenting part can be pushed into the pelvic cavity

  • When the presenting part can be pushed into the pelvic cavity does not imply engagement. An engaged head cannot be pushed further abdominally

Option D: Synonymous with fixation of the head

  • Engagement is not synonymous with fixation of the head, which simply means that the head has entered the pelvis and is not ballotable now

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who has been using IUCD for contraception for a year now presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge, fever and pain in the lower abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Keep the IUCD, give an antibiotic, follow up for antibiotic response, and then decide on IUCD removal.
Start antibiotics and then remove IUCD
Remove IUCD and then start antibiotics
Wait till the next menstrual cycle for any intervention

questions.solution:
Option A: Keep the IUCD, give an antibiotic, follow up for antibiotic response and then take a decision regarding IUCD removal

  • The history suggests that pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) occurred in an intrauterine copper device (IUCD) user.
  • PID generally arises within 4 weeks of insertion and is caused by an undetected vaginal infection or the tail of IUCD generating ascending infection.
  • The presence of PID in and of itself is not an indicator of IUCD removal because there might be other reasons for PID, which are normally treatable with antibiotics. Because sterile standards are maintained, it is uncommon for PID to arise due to IUCD implantation.
  • PID without abscess formation is initially treated with systemic antibiotics and then monitored for the response.
  • Actinomycosis is a frequent infection linked with IUCD. If signs or symptoms of infection appear in women harbouring Actinomyces species, the device should be removed, and antimicrobial therapy should be started. Actinomyces species are susceptible to gram-positive antimicrobials, particularly penicillins.

Option B: Start antibiotics and then remove IUCD

  • If there is no clinical improvement after 48-72 hours of starting antibiotic therapy, then the decision about the removal IUD can be made.

Option C: Remove IUCD and then start antibiotics

  • When PID is diagnosed in an IUD user, the IUD does not have to be taken out.
  • A comprehensive assessment of the literature showed that treatment results did not differ significantly between women with PID who kept the IUD and those who had the IUD removed.

Option D: Wait till the next menstrual cycle for any intervention

  • If PID develops in an IUCD user, appropriate antibiotic therapy can be started without waiting for the next menstrual cycle.
  • Antibiotic therapy can be started at the onset of symptoms, and if there is no clinical improvement after 48-72 hours of antibiotic therapy, then the decision about removing IUCD can be made.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female, gravida 3, para 2, at 20 weeks of gestation, presents to the obstetric outpatient department for her antenatal visit. She is concerned about the developing fetus's chromosomal abnormalities, such as Down's syndrome. Her history reveals no risk factor for Down's syndrome or other chromosomal anomalies, and all her children are healthy. Which of the following is an appropriate screening test for Down's syndrome in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Serum biomarkers

  • First-trimester screening at 11 to 14 weeks of gestation, using the fetal nuchal translucency measurement and serum analytes like pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) and human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) levels, has achieved Down syndrome detection rates comparable to those for second-trimester screening in women younger than 35 years.
  • Following are the serum biomarker tests for Down’s Syndrome screening:
  • Dual marker: PAPP-A + free b HCG (along with nuchal translucency)
  • Triple marker: free b HCG + alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) + unconjugated estriol
  • Quadruple marker: free b HCG + alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) + Unconjugated estriol + Inhibin A
  • Combinations of first and second-trimester screening yield down syndrome detection rates as high as 90 to 95 percent.
  • Maternal serum cell-free fetal DNA testing for trisomy 21, 18, and 13 has become available as a screening test for high-risk pregnancies, with a 98-percent detection rate and a false-positive rate of 0.5 percent.

Option A: Ultrasonography

  • Ultrasound can only pick soft tissue markers of Down syndrome, but it is not a confirmatory test.
  • Ultrasound scans can be normal in a fetus with Down syndrome.

Option C: Chorionic villus sampling

  • In Chorionic villus sampling (CVS), a placental sample is obtained by ultrasound-guided transabdominal needle, or it can be done by ultrasound-guided transcervical cannula aspiration.
  • It is a diagnostic procedure done for patients with positive screening tests or those at high risk or with a history of babies with Down's syndrome.
  • Due to its invasive nature, it is not done routinely for screening purposes

Option D: Amniocentesis

  • In amniocentesis, a sample of amniotic fluid is taken using an ultrasound-guided transabdominal needle.
  • It is generally done around 16–18 weeks of gestation.
  • It is a diagnostic procedure done for patients with positive screening tests or those at high risk or with a history of babies with Down's syndrome.
  • Due to its invasive nature, it is not done routinely for screening purposes

questions.text: A 50-year-old female who is a case of carcinoma cervix was posted for brachytherapy planned under total intravenous anaesthesia with spontaneous ventilation assessed through a Magill circuit. Which of the following is the fresh gas flow used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Equal-to-minute ventilation

  • Minute ventilation is the total sum of volume delivered over a minute, with spontaneous as well as mechanical inflations. Typical minute ventilation for term infants is 240 to 360 mL/kg/min.
  • Alveolar ventilation is calculated by subtracting dead-space ventilation from total minute ventilation. Alveolar/saccular ventilation in the absence of intrapulmonary shunts determines Paco2.
  • Neonates with respiratory distress syndrome (R.D.S.) typically breathe over 100 times a minute, with smaller tidal volumes and unchanged dead space volume resulting in decreased alveolar minute ventilation.
  • Their increased respiratory rate in a non-compliant lung is due to the lower work of breathing required with small rapid breaths rather than with larger breaths.

Option B: Equal to Tidal Volume

  • Tidal volume is the amount of air that moves in or out of the lungs with each respiratory cycle. It measures around 500 mL in an average healthy adult male and approximately 400 mL in a healthy female.
  • It is a vital clinical parameter that allows for proper ventilation to take place. When a person breathes in, oxygen from the surrounding atmosphere enters the lungs. It then diffuses across the alveolar-capillary interface to reach arterial blood.
  • At the same time, carbon dioxide continuously forms as long as metabolism takes place. Expiration occurs to expel carbon dioxide and prevent it from accumulating in the body. The volume of inspired and expired air that helps keep oxygen and carbon dioxide levels stable in the blood is what physiology refers to as tidal volume.

Option C: Equal to Residual Volume

  • Residual volume is the amount of air that remains in a person's lungs after fully exhaling. Doctors use tests to measure a person's residual air volume to help check how well the lungs are functioning. 
  • Residual volume is measured by:
    • A gas dilution test: A person breathes from a container containing a documented amount of a gas (either 100% oxygen or a certain amount of helium in the air). The test measures how the concentration of the gases in the container changes.
    • Body plethysmography: This test measures the total amount of air the lungs can hold (total lung volume). For this test, a person sits inside an airtight booth called a plethysmograph and breathes through a mouthpiece while pressure and air flow measurements are collected.

Option D: Total Lung capacity

  • Lung capacity or total lung capacity (T.L.C.) is the volume of air in the lungs upon the maximum effort of inspiration. Among healthy adults, the average lung capacity is about 6 liters.
  • Age, gender, body composition, and ethnicity are factors affecting the different ranges of lung capacity among individuals. T.L.C. rapidly increases from birth to adolescence and plateaus at around 25 years old.
  • Males tend to have a greater T.L.C. than females, while individuals with tall stature tend to have greater T.L.C. than those with short stature, and individuals with a high waist-to-hip ratio generally have a lower T.L.C.

questions.text: A young boy was scheduled for cataract surgery. Except for the development of a congenital cataract, his medical history is unremarkable. His blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and his pulse is 68/minute. Physical examination is normal. Anaesthesiologists use succinylcholine and propofol to induce anaesthesia. After 8 hours of surgery, the patient starts walking but experiences severe muscle pain. What is the most likely cause of this muscle pain?

choices.text: Due to the effects of eye surgery

questions.solution:
Option C: Succinylcholine

  • The muscle pain is due to postoperative myalgia associated with succinylcholine.
  • It is common in skeletal muscles (neck, abdomen, extremities etc.).
  • It is caused by the unsynchronised contraction of muscle fibres (fasciculation) immediately preceding paralysis.
  • Cardiovascular side effects of succinylcholine are usually common after the second dose (5 minutes after the 1st dose)
    • Sinus bradycardia
    • Junctional rhythms
    • Ventricular dysrhythmias
  • Other side effects of succinylcholine include:
    • Hyperkalemia is seen in patients with Burn, Severe abdominal infections, Metabolic acidosis, Closed head injury and Upregulation of extra-junctional acetylcholine receptors.
    • Children should not be given succinylcholine because it can cause rhabdomyolysis and sometimes severe hyperkalemia from undiagnosed muscle disorders.
    • Myoglobinuria
    • Myalgia is commonly seen in ambulatory patients after minor surgery
    • Malignant hyperthermia
    • Increase in intracranial pressure (transient)
    • Increase in cerebral blood flow
    • Increase in intragastric and lower oesophagal sphincter pressures.

Option A: Early mobilisation

  • Early mobilisation helps in post-operative recovery.
  • It is not the cause of postoperative myalgia.

Option B: Due to the effects of eye surgery

  • Ophthalmological surgery is not associated with myalgia.
  • It can lead to local complications.

Option D: Propofol

  • Propofol is commonly used for both induction and maintenance of anaesthesia.
  • It is metabolized in the liver and excreted by the kidneys. 
  • It can decrease blood pressure and respiratory rate.
  • It lowers intracranial and intraocular pressures and cerebral blood flow.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of hyperpigmentation and fever for 2 days. The doctor prescribed him medication. A few days later, he again presented with fever and hyperpigmentation, which showed a typical pattern of the double rise of temperature in 24 hours. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Kala-azar

  • This is a case of kala-azar in which the patient presents with complaints of fever and hyperpigmentation of the skin.
  • A double rise in temperature in 24 hours is seen in the case of Kala-azar.
  • L. donovani, infection of the classic kala-azar ("black sickness") or dumdum fever type, occurs in many parts of Asia, Africa, and Southeast Asia.
  • Vector: Phlebotomus
  • Infective Form→ Promastigote
  • Kala-Azar Fever: In the early stages of the disease, there is a mild irregular fever becoming intermittent at a later stage, and in 20% of cases, pyrexia shows a double rise in 24 hrs.
  • Bone marrow involvement leads to:
    • Anaemia, leucopenia, thrombocytopenia
    • Hypergammaglobulinemia
    • Fever and hyperpigmentation + hepatosplenomegaly seen
    • In HIV +ve → hepatosplenomegaly is absent (atypical presentation)

Option B: Malaria

  • The classic symptom of malaria: is a cyclical occurrence of sudden coldness followed by shivering and then fever and sweating.
  • Tertian fever: occurring every two days in P. vivax and P. ovale infections
  • Quartan fever: every three days for P. malariae.
  • P. falciparum infection can cause recurrent fever every 36–48 hours or a less pronounced and almost continuous fever.

Option C: Tuberculosis

  • Tuberculosis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • The Patient with T.B. clinically presents with symptoms of fever, productive cough, and weight loss.

Option D: Hodgkin’s lymphoma

  • Hodgkin's lymphoma: Pel-Ebstein fever pattern
  • Pel-Ebstein fever pattern: episodic fever at various times of day and in various intervals, typically consisting of a three to ten-day period of fever, followed by a three to ten-day period of apyrexia.

questions.text: What is the residual volume (RV) of the patient if 800 mL of nitrogen was collected using the wash-out method?
questions.solution:
Option C: 1000 mL

  • In all the respiratory volumes, 80% fraction is nitrogen.
  • Thus, if the total nitrogen volume in the RV is 800 mL, then RV is 1000 mL. (80% of 1000 mL is 800 mL)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with a history of trauma 2 months back now presents with fever and acute pain over the thigh, which worsens at night. His mother has been giving him painkillers at night to alleviate his pain. He also lost weight. X-ray findings are in the image below. What is the next best step in the investigation of this patient.
questions.solution:
Option D: MRI

  • Clues: In this case, diaphyseal lesion with onion peel reaction indicates Ewing’s sarcoma in the first decade.
  • The next best investigation is MRI for soft tissue involvement, marrow involvement, and micrometastasis.
  • Overall, the best investigation is a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis, but MRI is done before the biopsy to localize the best site for the biopsy.

Option A: CRP measurements

  • C reactive protein promotes the opsonization of pathogens, which leads to increased phagocytosis by macrophages.
  • Activates the complement system.
  • High sensitivity for detecting inflammation but not specific to any disease or organ.
  • Increases 6–12 hours after the inflammatory process begins.
  • Half-life is 24 hours.
  • It is not indicated here.
  • It can be used in inflammatory diseases.

Option B: Core biopsy

  • Core needle biopsy is a type of biopsy performed with a larger needle under image guidance using sonography, mammography, or MRI.
  • Indication: a preferred tool for assessing a suspicious breast mass on ultrasound or mammography.

Option C: Tc99 MDP scan

  • It is used for the evaluation of osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the office with complaints of burning pain in her hands for the past many months. He also complains of numbness, tingling, and burning. He also complains that his symptoms radiate to 3 digits and the radial ½ of the ring finger. He is a machinery worker. Examination shows the below findings. Which of the followings is not a cause for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Menorrhagia

  • Prolonged or heavy menstrual bleeding due to hormonal imbalance.
  • This condition is not related to the question
  • The image shows atrophy of thenar eminence, as seen in carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • It is due to the entrapment of the median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum.
  • Patients present with pain and paresthesia over the radial three and a half-digits.
  • There may be a weakness of thumb opposition.
  • In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted.

Carpal Tunnel Syndrome:  This is an entrapment of the median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum.

  • Etiology Idiopathic (most common)
  • Endocrinal disorders—Hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus, acromegaly
  • Hyperparathyroidism, pregnancy, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, amyloidosis, alcoholism, and sarcoidosis.
  • Injury-related—Synovitis of the tendon sheath
  • Malunited fractures (Colle's fracture)

Option A: Alcoholism

  • Alcohol causes carpal tunnel syndrome

Option B: Sarcoidosis

  • Sarcoidosis causes carpal tunnel syndrome

Option C: Gout

  • Gout causes carpal tunnel syndrome

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents in the outpatient department with complaints of fever off-and-on for the past 2 weeks, shortness of breath, and petechial spots all over the body with bleeding gums and increasing pallor for the past 1 month. Examination reveals splenomegaly 2 cm below the costal margin. Blood tests showed immature blast cells with decreased HB and white cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acute leukaemia

  • The above-given features, shortness of breath and pallor due to anaemia, are suggestive of acute leukaemia.
  • Bleeding from gums and petechial spots are suggestive of thrombocytopenia.
  • Lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly are present in acute leukaemia.
  • Blood tests showing immature blast cells are also a feature of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.

Option B: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura

  • In Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, there are no signs of anaemia.
  • Blood tests will not show blast cells; bone marrow will show megakaryocytes.
  • The presence of recurrent infections and splenomegaly goes against ITP.

Option C: Hodgkin's lymphoma

  • Hodgkin's lymphoma is ruled out as there is no mention of lymph node involvement.
  • Patients commonly present with painless, non-tender, firm, rubbery, cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy and usually some mediastinal involvement.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly is a feature but not always present.

Option D: Aplastic anaemia

  • It is a group of inherited or acquired disorders of the hematopoietic stem cells that involve one or more cell lines (erythroid, myeloid, megakaryocytic).
  • Lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are not seen in aplastic anaemia.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old baby presented to the ED with central cyanosis and respiratory distress. His heart rate is 180/min, and his respiratory rate is 60/min. The mother admits to not getting prenatal care during pregnancy. His ECG shows tall and broad P waves, a right-axis deviation, and a first-degree AV block. His chest X-ray is shown below.



What is the most probable underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option D: Ebstein’s Anomaly

  • This patient with cyanosis and features of heart failure has a characteristic box-shaped heart and a right axis deviation with typical “Himalayan P waves”, indicating Ebstein’s anomaly.
  • Downward displacement of posterior & septal leaflets of Tricuspid valve resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. It is caused by in-utero lithium exposure.
  • Huge cardiomegaly, especially of the right atrium, is seen
  • ECG:
    • Very tall & broad P waves seen due to enlarged atria.
    • These P waves look like a mountain; hence called 'Himalayan' p waves

OTHER OPTIONS

Option A: Tetralogy of Fallot

  • Most common congenital cyanotic heart disease in children
  • 4 Components:1. Large, unrestricted VSD 2. Pulmonary infundibular stenosis 3. Overriding of aorta 4. Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • X-ray shows a boot-shaped heart and pulmonary oligemia
  • ECG shows Right axis deviation and a dominant R wave in the right precordial chest leads or an RSR′ pattern.

Option B: Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome

  • It is the most common congenital heart disease causing mortality in 1st week of life
  • It includes a group of anomalies which have various degrees of underdevelopment of the left side of the heart [Eg- stenosis/ atresia of aortic/mitral valves, hypoplasia of left ventricular cavity & ascending aorta etc.]
  • It usually presents in the first few days of life with cyanosis and heart failure
  • Chest x-ray: Cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascularity
  • ECG: Prominent P waves and right ventricular hypertrophy

Option C: Coarctation of Aorta:

  • Sharp indentation involving anterior, lateral & posterior walls of the aorta; Medial wall is usually spared
  • Juxta-ductal part of the aorta is mostly involved
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Hypertension
    • Milder disease – Intermittent claudication of lower limbs
    • Severe disease – Heart failure in neonates with B/L feeble or impalpable femoral pulses
  • CXR:
    • Figure of 3 sign
    • Notching of inferior margin of 3rd – 9th ribs, usually seen in >3 years of age
  • Contrast Esophagram and Barium swallow shows E sign

questions.text: Randomized control trial is a study design that randomly assigns participants to an experimental group or a control group. All the following are true in a Randomized control trial (RCT) except?

choices.text: Baseline characteristics of intervention are similar in both arm
Investigator’s bias is minimized by double blinding
The sample size required depends on the hypothesis
The dropouts from the trial should be excluded from the analysis

questions.solution:
Option D: The dropouts from the trial should be excluded from the analysis

  • It provides information about the potential effects of treatment policy rather than on the potential effects of specific treatment.
  • Intention to treat trial (ITT): Implies that the results of an RCT are unaffected by attrition (loss to follow-up) or dropouts or changeover of study subjects from one group to another.
  • The dropouts from the trial are not excluded from the analysis.

Option A: Baseline characteristics of intervention are similar in both arm

  • Randomized control trial is a study design that randomly assigns participants into an experimental group or a control group.
  • Baseline characteristics of intervention are similar in both arms.

Option B: Investigator’s bias is minimized by double blinding

  • In a double-blind trial, the patients, as well as the investigator, are blinded i.e. they don’t know who is receiving the study drug and who is receiving a placebo. It removes subject & investigator bias. 

Option C: The sample size required depends on the hypothesis 

  • The sample size required always depends on the hypothesis.
  • The technique of randomization is the heart of randomized control trials.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the rural PHC with fever, stiffness in the neck, pain in legs, headache, and sore throat. The condition was diagnosed as poliomyelitis. Which of the following is an example of disability limitation in poliomyelitis?

choices.text: Reducing the occurrence of polio by immunization
Resting the affected limbs in neutral position

questions.solution:
Option C: Resting affected limbs in a neutral position

  • Resting limbs in a neutral position helps to prevent over-stretching of paralyzed muscles, thereby limiting further disability.
  • Its objective is to prevent or halt the transition of the disease process from impairment to handicapping.

Option A: Reducing the occurrence of polio by immunization

  • Immunization against disease is a primary level of prevention.
  • It is a protection against a specific disease.
  • It is not an example of disability limitation.

Option B: Early diagnosis 

  • Early diagnosis of poliomyelitis is a secondary level of prevention.
  • It is an action that halts the progress of the disease.

Option D: Providing calipers for walking

  • Providing calipers for walking is not an example of a disability limitation.
  • It is an example of rehabilitation.
  • Rehabilitation has been defined as the coordinated and combined use of social, medical, educational, and vocational measures for training the individual to the highest possible level of functional ability.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has thought of cutting her fingers and imagines doing it but never actually does it. She says she is not having any guilt about having such thoughts. And also says the thoughts are distressing her and she is unable to control them. The thoughts vanish either by ending with a seizure or automatically subside on their own. Which of the following is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Focal seizures can present with psychic symptoms without impairment of cognition. These may later progress to generalized seizures, usually of tonic-clonic type.
  • Forced thinking is a type of ‘psychic symptom’ in which a patient feels compelled to think about a specific topic or word again and again.
  • Another psychic symptom is ‘crowding of thoughts’ in which the patient has a feeling of racing, disorganized thoughts. In this question, the phenomenon described ends with a seizure and is consistent with the description of ‘forced thinking’.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents extreme fatigue and a dirty grey membrane on the tonsil, tonsillar pillars, and uvula. Marked lymphadenopathy is also present. He has no chronic medical complaints and takes no medications. In an attempt to remove the membrane, there is bleeding from the undersurface. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Diphtheria

  • This patient, with a dirty grey membrane on the tonsil, tonsillar pillars, and uvula, marked lymphadenopathy, and bleeding from the undersurface on an attempt to remove the membrane, most likely suffers from Diphtheria.
  • Diphtheria typically follows an incubation period of 2-5 days.
  • Infection is slower in onset with less local discomfort, often resembling a typical viral upper respiratory infection (URI)
  • A localized or coalescing pseudo membrane in Diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils onto the soft palate and is dirty grey.
  • It is characterized by the formation of a dense, gray debris layer composed of a mixture of dead cells, fibrin, RBCs, WBCs, and organisms
  • It is adherent, and its removal leaves a bleeding surface.
  • Smear and culture of throat swab will reveal Corynebacterium diphtheriae

Option A: Vincent's angina

  • It is insidious in onset with less fever and less discomfort in the throat.
  • Membrane, which usually forms over one tonsil, can be easily removed, revealing an irregular ulcer on the tonsil.
  • A throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes

Option B: Infectious mononucleosis

  • It often affects young adults.
  • Both tonsils are very much enlarged, congested, and covered with a membrane.
  • Lymph nodes are enlarged in the posterior triangle of the neck along with splenomegaly.
  • Attention to disease is attracted because the failure of the antibiotic treatment blood smear may show more than 50% lymphocytes, of which about 10% are atypical.
  • White cell count may be normal in the first week but rises in the second week.
  • Paul–Bunnell test (mono test) will show a high titer of heterophil antibodies.

Option D: Candidiasis

  • It most commonly presents with a cotton feeling in the mouth and loss of taste.
  • Whitish plaque is formed in the oral cavity that can be scraped off but leaves bleeding areas, as in Diphtheria.
  • However, it is more prevalent in immunocompromised patients and those taking inhaled corticosteroids.

questions.text: A 12-yrs-old boy presents to the physician's office with hoarseness and difficulty breathing for the past 2 days. Further examination reveals findings seen in laryngoscopy, as shown in the image below. Which of the following medications is used to prevent the recurrence of this condition after surgical excision?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cidofovir

  • The boy presents hoarseness and difficulty breathing with papillomatous lesions on the vocal cords. These findings are consistent with laryngeal papilloma.
  • Evidence suggests an association between human papillomavirus (HPV) and RRP (Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis). It came from identifying HPV DNA within laryngeal papillomas by Southern blot hybridization and the subsequent recognition in papillomas of HPV types 6 and 11.
  • Human papillomavirus is a naked, double-stranded virus with a circular supercoiled double-stranded DNA genome surrounded by an outer capsid of protein that belongs to the papovavirus family. There are over 200 known subtypes of HPV – although many vary only slightly in their DNA sequence – only types 6, 11, and rarely 16 are associated with RRP, with HPV 11 conferring a more aggressive course than HPV 6.
  • It mostly affects the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx but can also involve the subglottis, trachea, and bronchi.
  • Often presents in children with hoarseness or aphonia along with respiratory distress or even stridor.
  • Cidofovir is an acyclic nucleoside phosphonate active against a broad spectrum of DNA viruses, including cytomegalovirus, Epstein–Barr virus, and HPV. Its action is by inhibiting viral DNA polymerases essential for viral replication. Intralesional injection of cidofovir in Juvenile-onset recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (JORRP) is effective. A proposed schedule for the treatment of JORRP is based
  • on intralesional injections of cidofovir at a concentration of 1mg/mL. Injections were given at 2-weekly intervals for four treatments, and then the interval between treatments was extended by 1 week after every subsequent
  • treatment.
  • Chances of recurrence are very high in juvenile papillomatosis, so in the postoperative period, interferon-alpha and intralesional cidofovir are given, decreasing the chances of recurrence.

Option A: Radiotherapy

  • Used as an adjunctive , however, the role is controversial, with some reports of malignant transformation following the treatment.

Option B: Zinc application

  • Zinc effectively decreases the severity of disease, rate of recurrence, and the need for surgery.
  • Prolonged treatment is needed to sustain the positive effect.

Option D: Mitomycin C

  • Effective in preventing scar formation by reducing the granulation tissue and fibrosis via inhibiting fibroblasts and angiogenesis.
  • It is used to prevent the formation of postoperative glottic or subglottic stenosis following surgery.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the clinic for a wellness visit. Physical examination reveals a young male with tall and thin body habitus, loose joints, and arachnodactyly (spider fingers). Ophthalmologic examination reveals lens dislocation. The patient is most likely to have a mutation in the gene that encodes the synthesis of which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Option C: Fibrillin

  • This patient's signs and symptoms are highly consistent with Marfan syndrome.
  • Marfan syndrome is an inherited genetic disorder that affects the connective tissue.
  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene on chromosome 15, which encodes Fibrillin-1.
  • Fibrillin-1 is a Glycoprotein and is a structural component of microfibrils.
  • Microfibrils are responsible for forming elastic fibers, which assist the skin and ligaments in stretching.
  • Mutation adversely affects the bones, heart, and eyes, and elastin will also be affected.
  • Patients affected by Marfan are usually tall and thin with disproportionately long limbs.
  • Other clinical features include lens dislocation, arachnodactyly, flat feet, scoliosis, etc.
  • The main cause of death is cardiac abnormalities like aortic dissection or regurgitation.

Option A: Collagen

  • There are several disorders associated with the mutation of the gene encoding collagen.
  • Some include osteogenesis imperfect, Ehler-Danlos syndrome, Alport syndrome, etc.
  • Collagen disorders can present with vascular and tissue fragility and skin and joint manifestations.

Option B: Elastin

  • Elastin is a connective tissue protein.
  • It is responsible for tissues' extensibility and elastic recoil, e.g., arteries, lungs, tendons, skin, and ligaments.
  • Supravalvular aortic stenosis and autosomal dominant cutis laxa have been associated with the mutation of this protein.
  • Supravalvular aortic stenosis presents with chest pain, murmur, or heart failure.
  • Cutix laxa is characterized by loose, wrinkled, sagging skin, especially around the neck, arms, and torso.

Option D: Fibronectin

  • Fibronectin is a glycoprotein.
  • It is important for the process of wound healing and embryonic development.
  • It plays a vital role in cell adhesion, growth, tissue repair, migration, and differentiation.
  • It is associated with fibronectin glomerulopathy, a rare autosomal dominant disorder.
  • Patients with this disorder have mild proteinuria, hematuria, hypertension, and declining renal function.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of shortness of breath, breathing difficulty, coughing at night and chest tightness for one month. He also complains that the attacks are repetitive when exposed to the pollen. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. There is a bilateral wheeze on respiratory examinations. Which of the following experiments is used to demonstrate the hypersensitivity reaction in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Theobald smith phenomenon

  • This is a case of asthma in which the patient presents with complaints of shortness of breath, breathing difficulty, coughing at night and chest tightness for one month.
  • Asthma is an example of a type I hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Type I hypersensitivity reaction: IgE-mediated degranulation of basophils or mast cells.

Experiments to demonstrate type I hypersensitivity reaction:

  • P-K reaction

  • Schultz Dale phenomenon
  • Theobald smith phenomenon
  • Hypersensitivity: An altered state of reactivity to an antigen in a sensitized host resulting in an unexpected, exaggerated reaction that is harmful to the host leading to tissue damage, disease, or death.

Option A: Slide agglutination test

  • Agglutination: Insoluble (Particulate) antigen binds to the antibody (at optimal temperature, pH, electrolytes) to form clumps.
  • Slide agglutination tests:
    • Slide widal test
    • Serotyping
    • Blood grouping

Option B: Tube agglutination

  • Tube agglutination is routinely used for:
    • Typhoid fever (Widal test): Detects Ab against both H (flagellar) and O (somatic) Ag
    • Acute brucellosis (Standard agglutination test)

Option D: Raynaud's phenomenon

  • Raynaud phenomenon manifests as recurrent vasospasm of the fingers and toes and usually occurs in response to stress or cold exposure.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented with a complaint of petechiae. O/E, sternal tenderness is present. BM biopsy show hypercellularity and more than 20% lymphoblast. Peripheral smear show ↑↑↑ TLC and the presence of lymphoblast. On X-ray, retrosternal mass is seen. The diagnosis includes which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option D:  An immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive)

  • The above patient is most likely suffering from T-cell ALL.
  • Points in favor of the above diagnosis:
    • Peak at puberty
    • Retrosternal mass
    • More than 20% Lymphoblast (Tdt +, PAS +) in BM
    • ↑↑↑ TLC
    • Lymphoblast present in the blood
  • Less common than B cell ALL
    • Thymus ++
    • Notch gene mutation
    • Gain of function
    • Poor prognosis
    • CD1/2/5/7 positive
  • Immunophenotyping of immature T-cell phenotype: Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive

Other options

Option A: It has a good prognosis

  • ALL have poor prognoses.
  • The major prognostic factors for survival in adult ALL are:
    • Age
    • Cytogenetic abnormalities
    • Immunologic subtype
    • White blood cell (WBC) count
    • Time to achieve complete remission (CR).
  • Determination of these factors is crucial for adapting post-remission therapy in adult ALL.
  • Nearly 98% of children with ALL experience remission. With current regimens, it is anticipated that 85% of patients with newly diagnosed ALL between the ages of 1 and 18 will experience long-term event-free survival, with more than 90% still living at five years.

Option B: Adrenal involvement

  • Thymic involvement is seen in ALL.
  • The thymus, a tiny organ located in the centre of the chest in front of the trachea and behind the sternum, is frequently impacted by the T-cell subtype of ALL.
  •  An enlarged thymus can press on the trachea, leading to coughing or trouble breathing.
  • The thymus is the primary organ involved in developing T lymphocytes which orchestrate the adaptive immune response.

Option C: KDM1A mutation

  • Notch gene mutation is seen in ALL.
  • Similar to established oncogenes and tumour suppressors, established Notch receptor genes exhibit mutation frequency in established cancer cell lines.
  • In contrast to original tumours, tumour cell lines exhibit a higher prevalence of Notch mutations.
  • The KDM1A gene in humans encodes the protein known as lysine-specific histone demethylase 1A (LSD1), often referred to as lysine (K)-specific demethylase 1A (KDM1A).

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the office complaining of a swollen right pinna for two weeks. The swelling progressively worsened over time. In addition, he also complains of severe pain in the right pinna, with an intensity of 5/10, with no aggravating or relieving factors. One week previously, he had been examined in an urgent care facility and was given a 10-day course of amoxicillin for presumed acute otitis externa. However, the infection continued to worsen. There is no history of trauma to the external ear and no other significant medical history. The image of the patient is shown below. What is the correct option for the suspected condition?

choices.text: Most common organism is staphylococcus aureus

questions.solution:
Option A: The most common cause is trauma

  • The above picture shown is perichondritis.

  • The main cause is trauma, either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non-iatrogenic (laceration, hematoma). It can be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus.

  • Cauliflower Ear: Also known as perichondrial hematoma or wrestler's ear, it is a deformity of the ear caused by trauma.

  • Two factors commonly responsible for this condition are:

    • Trauma to the metal skin

    • Invasion by pathogenic organisms

  • Excessive sweating changes the pH of metal skin from acid to alkaline, favouring the growth of pathogens.
  • The aetiology of the disease is commonly seen in hot and humid climates and swimmers.

Option B: Also known as Swimmer's ear

  • Swimmer’s ear is also called “diffuse otitis externa”.

  • It is diffused inflammation of meatal skin that may involve the pinna and epidermal layer of the tympanic membrane.

Option C: Most common organism is staphylococcus aureus

  • The picture shown above is perichondritis.

    • The causative organism is Pseudomonas Aeruginosa.

Option D: Pinna is normal and painless

  • Symptoms may include red, hot, painful, and stiff pinna.

  • The shearing of the perichondrium and an attached thin underlying cartilage layer creates a potential space, the plane of cleavage within the cartilage itself, filled with blood following the rupture of small vessels.

questions.text: A 28‑year‑old female patient presented with the complaints of right ear discharge for 8 months which was scanty, purulent, foul‑smelling, occasionally bloodstained, and associated with intermittent tinnitus. Otomicroscopic examination revealed an attic perforation in the right ear and a normal tympanic membrane in the left ear. The patient was posted for right mastoid exploration under general anesthesia. On exploring the mastoid, a thick plate of bone was seen bridging the antrum. Which of the following statement is true regarding the landmark used for further mastoid drilling?

choices.text: The landmark is known as Koerner's septum
It is an anatomic boundary in the parietal bone
The persistent temporosquamous suture forms it
The persistent petro-squamous suture doesn’t forms it

questions.solution:
Option A: The landmark is known as Koerner's septum

  • This is a case of chronic supportive otitis media in which the patient presents with complaints of pain and discharge from the ear.
  • Koerner's septum is an anatomic boundary in the temporal bone formed by the continuous petro-squamous suture that separates the superficial squamous cells from the deep petrosal air cells in an embryonic phase.
  • Koerner's septum lies lateral to the antrum. It is surgically important as it may cause difficulty locating the antrum and the deeper cells (Antrum is hidden medial to Koerner's septum) and thus may lead to incomplete removal of disease at mastoidectomy.
  • Removal of mastoid cortex and exposure of antrum. The mastoid cortex is removed with a burr, or gouge and hammer. The mastoid antrum is exposed in the area of a supramental triangle (MacEwen's triangle). The antrum lies 12–15 mm from the surface in an adult. A horizontal semicircular canal is identified. Keep in mind the presence of Koerner's septum, which would need removal to explore the antrum.

  • The arrow in the image below shows Koerner's septum lateral to the Mastoid antrum.

Option B: It is an anatomic boundary in the parietal bone

  • Koerner’s septum is an anatomical structure and its anatomic boundary is the temporal bone.

Option C: The persistent temporosquamous suture forms it

  • The suture that form the above mentioned structure is a cranial suture, and it is formed between the temporal and parietal bones.

Option D: The persistent petro-squamous suture doesn’t forms it

  • Koerner's septum is an anatomic boundary in the temporal bone formed by the continuous petro-squamous suture that separates the superficial squamous cells from the deep petrosal air cells in an embryonic phase.

questions.text: A healthy 18-year-old girl presented to a local emergency room with 48hr of abdominal pain and vomiting. On physical examination. there is tenderness over the left lower abdominal quadrant with guarding. Based on the radiological and biochemical reports, a diagnosis of severe acute pancreatitis was made. All the following can be used to predict severe acute pancreatitis except :
questions.solution:
Tools for predicting the severity of Acute pancreatitis

At 48 hours

  • Ranson scoring a system-A score of 3 or more indicates a severe attack. It predicts the severity of the disease on the basis of 11 parameters obtained at the time of admission or 48 hours later. It has a low positive predictive value of 50% and a high negative predictive value (90%)
  • Glasgow scoring system-A score of 3 or more indicates the severe attack
  • Serum C- Reactive protein levels - >150 mg/dL is an indicator of severity

At admission

  • APACHE II - Based on the patient’s age, previous health status and 12 routine physiologic measurements, APACHE II provides a general measure of the severity of disease. An APACHE II score of 8 or higher defines severe pancreatitis. The main advantage is that it can be used upon admission and repeated at any time. APACHE II has a positive predictive value of 43% and a negative predictive value of 89%
  • BISAP (Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis )- Blood urea nitrogen (>25mg/dL), impaired mental status(GCS <15), presence of systemic inflammatory response syndrome, age >60 years and pleural effusion. A score of more than or equal to 3 is a predictor of severe acute pancreatitis
  • Urea at admission - >60 mmoL/L

Balthazar’s CT severity index -A score of greater than or equal to 7 is a predictor of severe pancreatitis

questions.text: A 52-year old lady presented with a 5-day history of jaundice and abdominal pain nausea and dark urine. She was nauseated and had dark urine. On initial assessment, she was deeply icteric, and her temperature was 38.2°C, but she was hemodynamically stable. Systemic examination did not reveal any other abnormalities. No organs or lymph nodes were palpable, and the abdomen was soft and non-tender. Biochemical analyses demonstrated leukocytosis. Intrahepatic duct dilatation was also noted. What is the best next step in treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Conservative management with stone removal via ERCP
Adequate hydration and IV antibiotics and then elective cholecystectomy

questions.solution:
Option B: Adequate hydration and IV antibiotics and then elective cholecystectomy

  • The diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is Acute cholangitis.
  • Acute cholangitis is a severe medical condition that can progress quickly to septic shock and death.
  • Adequate hydration and IV antibiotics should be started immediately.
  • Patients who have suffered an episode of acute cholangitis related to gallstone disease should be recommended to undergo elective cholecystectomy approximately 6 weeks after the resolution of cholangitis.

Option A: Conservative management with stone removal via ERCP

  • If the patient does not respond to medical therapy and progresses to shock, the patient requires urgent stone removal by ERCP

Option C: Emergency cholecystectomy

  • Emergency cholecystectomy is indicated for gall bladder necrosis and emphysematous gall bladder.

Option D: ERCP with sphincterotomy

  • Emergent decompression of the biliary tree is usually accomplished by ERCP and sphincterotomy.
  • Indications for emergent sphincterotomy are:
    • The common bile duct is dilated and contains multiple stones and biliary sludge.
    • When papilla is fibrosed and stenosed secondary to the passage of stones through it.

questions.text: A 61-year-old female with a history of ADPKD since 2010 was admitted with a two-month history of abdominal discomfort with rapidly progressing jaundice following nausea and weight loss. The Hepatitis virus test came out negative. MR Cholangiopancreatography revealed a bilobar polycystic liver with cysts at the porta hepatis that caused a marked narrowing at the bifurcation of the common hepatic duct. Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: Somatostatin as an initial treatment for this condition
It is not associated with hypertension

questions.solution:
Option D: Liver transplantation for progressive disease

  • These clinical features are suggestive of Polycystic liver disease.
  • It is common in patients with inherited autosomal dominant adult polycystic kidney disease.
  • Reserved for severe symptoms related to large cysts and complications includes:
    • Percutaneous aspiration with or without sclerotherapy
    • Cyst fenestration or surgical unroofing of the cyst
    • Hepatic resection
    • Orthotopic liver transplantation (for progressive disease)

Option A: Somatostatin as an initial treatment for this condition

  • Somatostatin is given for severe diseases with large cysts and complications.

Option B: It is not associated with hypertension

  • These liver cysts are associated with Polycystic kidney disease.
  • In Polycystic kidney disease, there is increased secretion of renin which is associated with high blood pressure due to vasoconstriction.

Option C: Serum calcium is low

  • Serum calcium is normal in Polycystic kidney and liver disease.

questions.text: A 10-year old boy presents to the hospital with his mother.The primary complaint is urinary incontinence from birth. " When he feels the urge to void, he has a little warning before urine starts to drain through his urethra. An ultrasound is taken, which shows mild hydronephrosis bilaterally. The patient undergoes a voiding cystourethrogram which shows a dilated posterior (proximal) urethra and some flaps of tissue that obstruct urine flow (image). Which of the following should be the probable management for this patient?

choices.text: Conservative management is enough as it spontaneously resolves with ageing.
The patient should be scheduled for Endoscopic fulguration of valves immediately as B/L hydronephrosis has developed.
Suprapubic cystostomy can be performed, and then a polyethylene feeding tube should be used to allow secondary healing.
Insert an infant feeding tube into the bladder and leave it for several days; Further management should be done according to the S.creatinine level.

questions.solution:
Option D: Insert an infant feeding tube into the bladder and leave it for several days; Further management should be done according to the S.creatine level.

  • In this case, as the patient shows posterior urethra and some flaps of tissue that obstruct urine flow along with urine incontinence, it makes the diagnosis of posterior urethral valves.
  • Posterior urethral valves are congenital malformations in which obstructive membranes develop in the urethra.
  • It is a congenital obstruction resulting from a malformation of the posterior urethra in which there are symmetrical folds of urothelium extending distally from the prostatic urethra to the external urinary sphincter.
  • It is exclusively present in male patients only.
  • It has the following types:
    • Type I: Posterior urethral folds. It arises from the caudal verumontanum and anteriorly fuses the urethra obstruction.
    • Type II: Membranes originating from the verumontanum cranially attached to the bladder neck.
    • Type III: Round membrane at the caudal verumontanum with a hole in the middle either above or below the verumontanum.
  • Type 1 is the most common, with 95% of occurrence.
  • It is associated with the following:
    • Oligohydramnios
    • Renal parenchymal dysplasia (the most important factor in overall prognosis).
    • Abnormal bladder function (25%)
    • Pulmonary hypoplasia (the most common cause of death).

Management:

  • First of all, a small polyethylene feeding tube is inserted in the bladder and left for several days. Then further management is done according to serum creatinine level.
  • If the serum creatinine level is normal, Transurethral ablation (endoscopic fulguration) of the valves is considered.
  • If the serum creatinine level shows an increased concentration than the normal range, Vesicostomy (Blockson technique is best) is considered to bypass the obstruction.

Option A: Conservative management is enough as it spontaneously resolves with ageing.

  • PUV patients require surgical interventions and medical management, and ongoing monitoring for the rest of their lives.
  • Endoscopic incision of the valves is the surgery which is considered for this cause, as it can not resolves on its own by ageing.

Option B: The patient should be scheduled for Endoscopic fulguration of valves immediately as B/L hydronephrosis has developed.

  • Before scheduling Endoscopic fulguration, serum creatinine level is measured.
  • In the case of normal serum creatinine levels, endoscopic fulguration can be scheduled.
  • But if there are abnormally high serum creatinine levels, vesicostomy, which is surgery to create a small opening in the bladder made through the abdomen in order to help the flow of urine, is considered

Option C: Suprapubic cystostomy can be performed, and then a polyethylene feeding tube should be used to allow secondary healing.

  • ​​​​​​​If the child is stable, a vesicostomy can be performed.
  • In rare cases in which hypertrophy of the bladder neck is seen in patients, a urethral catheter cannot be placed. Such patients require cystoscopy for catheter placement, suprapubic tube placement, or primary vesicostomy under anaesthesia

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented to your clinic with complaints of abdominal pain radiating to the back, early satiety, and fullness. During his workup, an incidental adrenal mass was found on the abdominal CT scan. Which of the following is an indication for adrenalectomy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

Indications of surgery in Incidentaloma:

  • Suspicious imaging characteristics (irregular margins)
  • Size >5 cm
  • Bilateral adrenal metastasis
  • Functional tumor
  • Young age
  • Interval tumor growth
  • Patient preference
  • Patients with worsening hypertension, abnormal glucose tolerance, or osteoporosis

Adrenal incidentalomas:

  • Adrenal lesions discovered during imaging performed for unrelated reasons are referred to as incidentalomas
  • The incidence of these lesions identified by CT scans ranges from 0.4 to 4.4%

  • Arrow points towards non-functioning adrenal adenocarcinoma.

Option A: Size >5 cm

  • Incidental adrenal masses with a size > 5 cm have a high risk of being malignant. Therefore, adrenalectomy is indicated in such masses. 

Option B: Bilateral adrenal metastasis

  • Bilateral adrenal metastasis indicates malignancy; therefore, adrenalectomy is indicated in such cases.

Option C: Functional tumor

  • Functional incidental adrenal tumors produce troublesome symptoms; therefore, adrenalectomy is indicated in such cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain upon exertion for one week. The pain is associated with palpitations and sweating and is not relieved with rest. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes controlled with metformin, and asthma, for which he occasionally uses a salbutamol inhaler.His ECG is shown in the image below; his cardiac enzymes were within normal limits. He was admitted to the CCU for further evaluation. Therapy with a maximal tolerable dose of amiodarone was only partially successful. Which of the following drugs could be useful in treating the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ivabradine

  • The ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia with no visible P waves is diagnostic of supraventricular tachycardia. This increase in heart rate is the main cause of the patient's symptoms, e.g. chest pain and palpitations.
  • Calcium channel blockers and beta blockers are commonly used in the treatment of angina; however, as the patient is asthmatic, beta blockers are contraindicated. And since the maximum tolerable dose of amiodarone was not effective, ivabradine is the next most suitable option.
  • Ivabradine selectively blocks Na+ channels that open during the early part of phase 4 depolarization and reduces HR by inhibiting the hyperpolarization-activated Na+ channel in the SA node.
  • Reducing the heart rate decreases cardiac oxygen demand and prolongs diastole, which improves myocardial perfusion and oxygen supply.

Option A: Propranolol

  • Although beta blockers are routinely used in the treatment of unstable angina and NSTEMI, they are contradicted in asthmatics.
  • When used, cardioselective blockers, e.g., atenolol, and metoprolol, are preferred over non-selective blockers, e.g., propranolol, as the latter may worsen angina by unopposed alpha-mediated coronary vasoconstriction.

Option C: Digoxin

  • Digoxin is a positive inotropic agent that causes a dose-dependent increase in cardiac contraction.
  • It is indicated in the treatment of certain supraventricular tachycardias, e.g., chronic atrial flutter and atrial fibrillation, when accompanied by heart failure.
  • CCBs, beta blockers and ivabradine are safer, much more effective options.

Option D: Aspirin

  • Aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX1 and COX2 decreasing the formation of thromboxane A2- a potent vasoconstrictor and platelet aggregator. Acts as an antiplatelet agent. Other uses include analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antipyretic.
  • It is contraindicated in asthma, bleeding, renal disease and peptic ulcers.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male in the emergency department complains of hematemesis and epigastric pain. He's been using NSAIDs for rheumatoid arthritis, with a history of esophageal varices. Octreotide, a costly short-acting somatostatin analogue, is being increasingly employed for which approved conditions?
questions.solution:
Option B: Secretory diarrhoea

  • In this case, the patient presents with pain epigastrium and hematemesis for the last few hours. He has a history of oesophagal varices a few months ago. Octreotide is given, which is a synthetic analogue of somatostatin. It has a short duration of action and has multiple effects on many secretory systems.
  • Octreotide, given subcutaneously every 8 hours. It reduces symptoms caused by a variety of hormone-secreting tumours.
  • Acromegaly, carcinoid syndrome, gastrinoma, glucagonoma, watery diarrhoea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WADHA) syndrome.
  • It reduces hepatic blood flow and helps to stop oesophagal variceal bleeding. It reduces secretory diarrhoea associated with carcinoid, AIDS, and cancer chemotherapy.
  • Disadvantages and adverse effects of Octreotide include; high cost, steatorrhea leading to fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, and choledocholithiasis.

Option A:  Stimulates growth hormone

  • Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue. It does not stimulate growth hormones. It inhibits growth hormone secretions.
  • It is used in the treatment of acromegaly.

Option C:  Protein-energy malnutrition

  • Octreotide treats acromegaly, carcinoid tumours, secretory diarrhoea, and gastrinoma.
  • It does not promote growth and metabolism.

Option D: Steatorrhea

  • Steatorrhea is an adverse effect of octreotide.
  • It leads to fat-soluble vitamin deficiency and choledocholithiasis.

questions.text: A 48 years old chronic alcoholic patient presents in the outdoor department with a complaint of swelling in the groin for one year. On examination, the patient has a swelling in the inguinoscrotal region with positive cough impulse, which is reducible. The deep ring occlusion test is positive. The patient is admitted for hernioplasty. After two days of admission to the surgical ward, there is a complaint of nausea, vomiting, irritability, insomnia, and hallucinations. A psychiatrist's opinion was obtained, and the patient was under treatment. The patient belongs to which ASA class?
questions.solution:
Option C: III

  • The patient has alcohol dependence, and he belongs to ASA class III.
  • A patient with the severe systemic disease is categorised as ASA class 3.
  • In adults, substantive functional limitations like one or more moderate to severe diseases are under ASA 3. Poorly controlled DM or HTN, COPD, morbid obesity (BMI ≥40), active hepatitis, alcohol dependence or abuse, implanted pacemaker, moderate reduction of ejection fraction, ESRD undergoing regularly scheduled dialysis, history (> 3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents.
  • In the pediatric population, uncorrected stable congenital cardiac abnormality, asthma with exacerbation, poorly controlled epilepsy, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, morbid obesity, malnutrition, severe OSA, oncologic state, renal failure, muscular dystrophy, cystic fibrosis and history of organ transplantation is under ASA 3.

Option A: I

  • Normal healthy patient.
  • Healthy, nonsmoking, no or minimal alcohol use, and normal BMI percentile for age.

Option B: II

  • A patient with mild systemic disease.
  • Mild diseases only without substantive functional limitations.

Option D: IV

  • A patient with severe systemic disease that constantly threatens life is categorised as ASA class 4.
  • For example, recent (<3 months) MI, CVA, TIA or CAD/stents, ongoing cardiac ischemia or severe valve dysfunction, severe reduction of ejection fraction, shock, sepsis, DIC, ARDS or ESRD not undergoing regularly scheduled dialysis.
