questions.text: A 3-day-old infant is brought to the OPD by his parents with complaints of abdominal bloating and persistent projectile non-bilious vomiting since birth. The baby is full term and born by normal vaginal delivery. They also report refusal of feeds. On examination, the baby looks lethargic and irritable, along with abdominal distension. His clinical features and investigation findings are suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which signs can be elicited in this condition on a radiograph?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

  • All of the above mentioned signs are seen in Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis 
  • Target sign
  • Antral nipple sign
  • Cervix sign

questions.text: A full-term neonate born by Normal Spontaneous Vaginal Delivery was diagnosed with dysmorphic facial features. MRI head is performed, and it shows a Racing car sign. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Agenesis of the corpus callosum

  • Racing car sign/Moose head sign/Viking Helmet Sign is seen in Agenesis of Corpus Callosum on MRI.

  • Probst bundles denote white matter fibres normally destined to cross the corpus callosum that instead parallel the interhemispheric fissure in patients with agenesis of the corpus callosum.

  • These lead to widely spaced lateral ventricles forming the characteristic racing car sign.

  • High-riding 3rd ventricle is also seen in CC agenesis.

  • Bracket calcification is seen in the lipoma of the corpus callosum.

Option A: Lipoma of the corpus callosum

  • Lipoma of the corpus callosum is a congenital disorder which probably arises due to poor differentiation of the meningeal tissue.

  • Agenesis of the corpus callosum is a type of cerebral dysraphism in which the neural tube does not close properly.

  • Intracranial lipomas are mostly congenital and form because of abnormal differentiation of the meninx primitive.

  • The clinical manifestations of lipomas are nonspecific and depend on their location.

  • Epilepsy is the most common symptom of supratentorial lipomas and occurs in about 50% of cases of callosal lipomas.

Option C: Necrosis of corpus callosum

  • MBD is a rare disorder characterized by demyelination and necrosis of the corpus callosum.

  • The corpus callosum is affected in almost a pathognomonic way. Clinical presentation is based on cognitive impairment, gait disturbance, seizures, and coma.

  • Especially seen in patients with alcohol abuse disorder.

  • Marchiafava-Bignami disease is a rare affliction characterized by primary degeneration of the corpus callosum associated with chronic ethanol consumption.

  • The disease may occasionally occur in patients who are not alcoholics but are chronically malnourished.

Option D: Degeneration of corpus callosum

  • The major cause of atrophy of the corpus callosum may be axonal degeneration from damage to cortical neurons.

  • In addition, severe cytoskeletal abnormality in the cerebral white matter might accentuate the degree of callosal atrophy.

  • Since each hemisphere controls the opposite side of the body, the brain must coordinate movements with both sides.

  • The corpus callosum mediates this coordination. Signals cannot pass from one hemisphere to the other if the corpus callosum is damaged.

  • This can lead to serious coordination problems.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented to the outpatient department with complaints of bleeding during defecation. She also had pigmentation of the lips and buccal mucosa. Her sister had the same clinical features. The colonic examination showed multiple polyps in the jejunum. There was no hemorrhoidal mass visible. No history of recent weight loss or family history of carcinoma was revealed. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Peutz-jegher’s syndrome

  • The patient presented with the typical features of Peutz-jegher’s syndrome, such as bleeding per rectum and pigmentation of lips and buccal mucosa. The pigmentation on the buccal mucosa usually appears in the first few years and remains throughout life.
  • The colonoscopic examination revealed multiple polyps in the colon.
  • The patient had no recent weight loss and no family history of carcinoma because it is a benign condition having no metastatic potential. It is also called hamartoma polyps having no cancer risk.
  • As it is an autosomal dominant genetic disease that runs in families, her sister also had the same clinical features.
  • 90-100% of patients with this clinical features have a mutation in the STK11/LKB1 gene.   

Option A: Carcinoid tumour

  • The most common appendicular tumour usually presents with reddish-blue cyanosis and asthmatic attack.  

Option B: Familial adenomatous polyps

  • FAP is usually associated with a family history of cancer.

Option C: Juvenile polyps

  • It is the polyps of infant age, not present in older age.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a dark red mass on his left thumb. The lesion has rapidly increased in size over the past 2 months. It is not painful, but the lesion bled profusely once when he accidentally bumped his hand on a desk. About 6 months ago, his cat scratched him on the left thumb. He has asthma well controlled with inhaled beclomethasone and albuterol. He is otherwise healthy and receives no other medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left upper extremity shows a solitary 2 cm lesion on the interphalangeal joint of the thumb; a photograph of the lesion is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pyogenic granuloma

  • Reddish, firm swelling, which bleeds on touch in a 16-year-old male suggestive of pyogenic granuloma.
  • Pyogenic granuloma
    • It is a misnomer for an exuberant outburst of highly vascular granulation tissue at the site of previous relatively trivial trauma.
    • These lesions are friable, bleed easily, and may grow rapidly.
    • PG typically manifests as a painless, red papule or nodule and often develops at sites of skin injury on the face or hands, as seen here. The exact cause is unknown. Young men and pregnant women are commonly affected.
    • Diagnosis is based on clinical findings.
    • Surgical excision is the preferred treatment method because it reduces the recurrence rate. Other treatment methods include laser therapy, cryotherapy, intralesional steroid injections, and topical therapies (e.g., beta-blockers).

Option A: Cherry hemangioma

  • A cherry hemangioma can manifest as a painless, red lesion that may bleed profusely after trauma.
  • However, cherry hemangiomas are usually seen in adults older than 30 and rarely occur on the hands.
  • Moreover, multiple, smaller (0.1–0.4 cm) lesions rather than a single nodule are typically seen.

Option B: Glomus tumour

  • A glomus tumour can manifest as a red-purple nodule on the fingers. However, glomus tumours are typically located on the nail bed or the palm and are associated with severe paroxysmal pain, tenderness, and cold sensitivity.
  • Furthermore, a glomus tumour does not usually bleed following minor trauma or develop at the site of an injury.

Option D: Bacillary angiomatosis

  • Cat scratches typically transmit bacillary angiomatosis, and patients can present with a solitary, red nodule that bleeds easily.
  • However, patients with bacillary angiomatosis usually present with constitutional symptoms, such as fever, chills, and malaise.
  • Moreover, bacillary angiomatosis is characteristically seen in immunocompromised patients (especially patients with HIV infection and a CD4 count < 100 cells/μL).

questions.text: A 54-year-old male came to the emergency department with an altered state of consciousness for the the last  6 hours. The patient complained of severe headache associated with vomiting earlier before getting tired and confused. He has a history of hypertension. On examination, his blood pressure is 180/110 mmHg, and his heart rate is 90 beats per minute. His GCS score is 10/15. The neurologist orders a plain CT brain and a CT angiogram of the brain, which reveals a ruptured cerebral aneurysm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Sub-Arachnoid Hemorrhage

  • Based on the history of severe headaches associated with vomiting and then altered state of consciousness and the finding of a ruptured cerebral aneurysm in the CT angiogram report, the most likely diagnosis is subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage is an extravasation of blood into the subarachnoid space between the pia and arachnoid membrane.
  • SAH on CT scan is shown below:

  • Signs and symptoms occur before the rupture of the cerebral aneurysm. The most common symptoms and signs are as follows:
    • Headache
    • Dizziness
    • Orbital pain
    • Diplopia
    • Visual loss
    • Seizures
  • A negative non-contrast CT scan followed by CT angiography of the brain rules out SAH with great sensitivity.
  • The treatment of subarachnoid hemorrhage from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm includes strict blood pressure control, restriction of fluid and anti-hypertensive medication.
  • Rebleeding is the most common early complication of SAH.
  • Surgical treatment to prevent rebleeding is by clipping the ruptured berry aneurysm.
  • Oral nimodipine is the calcium channel blocker to prevent vasospasm after SAH.
  • An early CSF drainage via a ventricular drain may lessen the chance of vasospasm.
  • Treatment for symptomatic vasospasm involves the induction of hypertension, hypervolemia, hemodilution, or triple H therapy. This therapy should be reserved for patients with aneurysms secured by surgical clipping or endovascular techniques to lessen the chances of rebleeding.

Option A: Hemorrhagic Stroke

  • In hemorrhagic stroke, bleeding occurs directly into the brain parenchyma.
  • Patients with hemorrhagic stroke may present with focal neurologic deficits similar to those of ischemic stroke but are usually more ill.
  • Non-contrast computed tomography scan or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain is the investigation of choice.

Option B: Ischemic Stroke

  • Acute ischemic stroke occurs due to thrombotic or embolic occlusion of a cerebral artery and is more frequent than hemorrhagic stroke.
  • Non-contrast CT scan is the most commonly used in the acute evaluation of patients with suspected acute stroke. MRI with magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) can also be used, but it is not readily available in emergencies.

Option D: Subdural Hematoma

  • A subdural hematoma is a collection of blood underneath the inner layer of the dura but outside the brain and arachnoid membrane.
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head is generally performed when a patient presents with suspected acute subdural hematoma.

questions.text: A young girl presents with neuropsychiatry symptoms and has a habit of licking paint on walls. Blood investigation reveals microcytic hypochromic anemia (Refer to the picture below). Symptoms are due to inhibition of.......?
questions.solution:
Option A: ALA dehydratase

  • It is a case of lead poisoning.
  • Specifically, lead decreases heme biosynthesis by inhibiting Aminolevulinic Acid Dehydratase (ALAD) and Ferrochelatase.

Option B/C/D: ALA synthase/ Heme oxygenase/ CPG oxidase

  • The above mechanisms are not seen in Lead poisoning.

questions.text: The body of a 45-year-old man was brought in for an autopsy. The previous night, the man had got into an argument with another person at a bar over political opinions. The heated argument had turned violent and ended with the other person shooting at the victim with his unlicensed rifle. To avoid being exposed, that person and the bar owner had taken the victim to a doctor who had accepted to remove the bullet and suture the wound in private. The victim had unfortunately succumbed to the injuries in the early hours of this morning. While performing the autopsy, the forensic doctor faced difficulty in determining the entry and exit of the bullet wound. This phenomenon is known as?
questions.solution:
Option D: Kennedy phenomenon 

  • Iatrogenic alteration of a gunshot wound.  
  • There is Difficulty in range determination.

Option A: Formication phenomenon

  • Formication is the perception of what appears to be tiny insects crawling on (or under) the skin but is actually nothing.

Option B: Gordon phenomenon

  • The Gordon phenomenon is the degradation of cerebellar Purkinje cells following intracerebral injection of eosinophil granulocytes or their preparations.

Option C: Rayalaseema phenomenon

  • After the stabbing, the bullet is put inside the wound. 
  • This is the Rayalaseema phenomenon.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was examined by the team doctor after he sustained an injury to his knees and shin during an ongoing cricket match. He had attempted a difficult fielding where he had instinctively dived and skidded on his knees for a short distance on the rough unkempt school playground. Examination of his legs revealed multiple parallel and longitudinal scratches that had some avulsed skin gathered at the edge of the wound near the apex of the patella. The doctor identified them to be graze wounds which is a type of?
questions.solution:
Option B: Abrasion

  • Abrasion is the removal of the superficial epithelial layer of the skin, usually the epidermis and papillary dermis, by friction against a rough surface.
  • Graze abrasion is also known as sliding, scrape, or grinding abrasion.
  • Grazes (gravel rash) are caused by horizontal or tangential friction between the skin and the hard rough surface. They show uneven, longitudinal parallel lines, which indicate the direction in which the force was applied (epidermis being heaped up at the opposite end).

Option A: Contusion 

  • When a blunt force acts on the skin, blood vessels rupture resulting in accumulation/extravasation of blood under the skin(not in the epidermis) is known as a Contusion/Bruise.
  • Graze wounds are not a type of contusion.

Option C: Lacerated wound

  • Lacere means to tear.
  • In laceration wounds, there are irregular margins with contused edges.
  • Graze wounds are not a type of laceration.

Option D: Incised wound

  • It is also known as Cut injury/Slash injury/Slice injury.
  • Produced by light-cutting weapons with sharp edges. eg. surgical blades
  • Graze is not a type of incised wound.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, chills, abdominal pain, headache, nausea and vomiting for 1 week. On taking further history, the patient added that he drinks raw milk without boiling it every day. He gives no history of any chronic illnesses. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. After further investigations and examinations, the condition was diagnosed as Q-fever by the physician. Which of the following organism is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Option B: Coxiella burnetti

  • This is a case of Q-fever in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, chills, abdominal pain, headache, nausea and vomiting for 1 week.
  • Q-fever is caused by Coxiella burnetti.

Query fever| Q fever

  • The infection results from inhalation of spore-like cell variant or contact with contaminated milk, urine or faeces.

  • The incubation period of Q fever is 10-40 days.
  • The diagnosis of this disease is based on serology.
  • The treatment of this disease is done by antibiotics.
  • Caused by Coxiella burnetti.
  • Contaminates of milk are killed by the flash method of pasteurization.
  • Mode of transmission → Aerosol transmission [no arthropod transmission].
  • No Rash occurs.

Option A: Rochalimaea Quintana

  • Rochalimaea Quintana is a gram-negative bacterium.
  • It is known to cause louse-borne epidemic typhus.
  • It is also known to cause trench fever in Africa.

Option C: Mycoplasma hominis

  • Mycoplasma hominis is known to cause:
    • Bacterial vaginosis
    • Pelvic inflammatory disease
    • Sexually transmitted disease

Option D: None of the above

  • Q-fever is caused by Coxiella burnetti.
  • So, we cannot choose this option according to this case.

questions.text: National urban health mission established the Primary Urban Health Centre for the delivery of health care services. Primary urban health care should be for a population of?
questions.solution:
Option B: 50,000

  • Primary urban health Centre (PUHC): 1 PUHC/UHC per 50,000 of the population.

URBAN HEALTH CARE DELIVERY MODEL

  • Community level: Community outreach services.
  • Sub–primary level: Swasthya chowki
    • 1 Swasthya chowki per 10,000 population.
    • 1 ANM + 1 Community health worker.
  • Primary level: 1 Primary urban health Centre (PUHC)
    • 1 PUHC/UHC per 50,000 (1 per 25000-30000 in slums).
  • Referral level: Public or empanelled secondary/tertiary care providers.
  • Secondary level Urban Health Centre (U-CHC) - Metros- 1 per 5,00,000; Non-metros - 1 per 2,50,000.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents with complaints of a 2-month history of persistent fever, night sweats, and weight loss. His past medical history is unremarkable. On a physical examination, he is noted to have painless bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy and axillary lymphadenopathy with the largest palpable node of about 4 cm. His labs show low haemoglobin, raised eosinophils, and LDH of 374IU/L. His immunohistochemistry confirms the ALK gene on chromosome 2p23. He is referred for an excisional lymph node biopsy, which shows large anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and voluminous cytoplasm. Histological presence of these cells is seen in which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anaplastic large cell lymphoma

  • Painless generalized lymphadenopathy with B symptoms at a young age and ALK-positive large anaplastic cells suggest anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL), a peripheral T-cell lymphoma (PTCL).
  • It is typically composed of large anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and voluminous cytoplasm, also known as hallmark cells.
  • The ALK detection on chromosome 2p23 in tumour lymphocytes is a reliable indicator of an ALK gene rearrangement.
  • ALK+ tumours usually express CD30, a member of the TNF family.
  • ALK+ ALCL occurs in children and young adults frequently. It shows an overall male predominance.
  • ALCL patients present with variable symptoms, including peripheral or abdominal lymphadenopathy, B symptoms (persistent fever, weight loss, profuse night sweats), and bone marrow involvement.
  • It carries a very good prognosis, unlike other peripheral T-cell neoplasms. The cure rate with chemotherapy is 75%-80%.

Option B: Follicular lymphoma

  • Follicular lymphoma is an indolent NHL associated with 14;18 translocations. These tumours express pan-B cell markers CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6.
  • Histologically, small lymphoid cells with irregular or cleaved nuclear outlines (centrocytes) mixed with a population of larger cells with nucleoli (centroblasts) are found.
  • It mainly occurs in adults older than 50 and usually manifests as painless, generalized lymphadenopathy and easy fatigability. It usually involves lymph nodes, bone marrow, and spleen.

Option C: Burkitt lymphoma

  • Burkitt lymphoma is an aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) that commonly occurs in adolescents and young adults with characteristic jaw lymphadenopathy.
  • A translocation involving the MYC gene on chromosome 8 is commonly seen in Burkitt lymphoma.
  • The tumour cells are intermediate in size with round or oval nuclei. Numerous tissue macrophages are also present, surrounded by the clear space creating a ‘starry sky pattern’.

Option D: Hodgkin lymphoma

  • Hodgkin lymphoma is a rare monoclonal lymphoid neoplasm characterized by the presence of a tumour giant cell called Reed-Sternberg cell.
  • It usually presents in young adults manifesting ass painless lymphadenopathy and B symptoms (persistent fever, weight loss, profuse night sweats).
  • It arises in a single node or chain of nodes and spreads first to anatomically adjacent lymphoid tissues.

questions.text: Which amino acid issue causes kidney stones with oxalic and glyoxylic acid buildup?
questions.solution:
Option D: Glycine

  • Glycine is metabolized by three pathways:
    • The first pathway is glycine's conversion to serine by adding a hydroxymethyl group.
    • The second pathway is glycine's oxidative cleavage to CO2, NH4, and a CH2 group.
    • The third pathway is glycine's conversion to glyoxylate in the presence of D-amino acid oxidase, which is subsequently converted to oxalate in the presence of lactate dehydrogenase and NAD+ or can be converted to glycine or formic acid in the presence of transaminase
  • D-amino acid oxidase has higher concentrations in kidneys, so excessive glyoxylate is formed in this setting.
  • In the absence/deficiency of transaminase, excess glyoxylate cannot be converted to formate or glycine, so the only possible pathway is conversion to oxalate.
  • Thus this leads to excessive oxalate accumulation in the kidney, which subsequently forms calcium oxalate crystals and kidney stone formation.
  • This condition is called Primary Hyperoxaluria Type l

Option A: Phenylalanine

  • Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid; it does not convert to oxalate at any step of its metabolism.
  • Enzymatic defects in phenylalanine metabolism result in phenylketonuria – characterized by neurological manifestations instead of renal stones.

Option B: Tyrosine

  • Tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid endogenously produced as the first product of phenylalanine metabolism.
  • Tyrosine's metabolism ultimately leads to the production of catecholamines, melanin, fumarate, and acetoacetate.
  • Enzymatic defects in this pathway lead to Alkaptonuria & Albinism.

Option C: Isoleucine

  • Isoleucine is both a ketogenic and glucogenic amino acid as its metabolism leads to the production of acetyl CoA and propionyl CoA. This pathway has nothing to do with oxalate formation or deposition.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male athlete training for a marathon race is advised by his coach to increase his carbohydrate intake after the workout. The carbohydrate uptake will help to build up glycogen stores in the muscles. Glycogen synthase is the main enzyme involved in glycogen synthesis in the muscles. Which of the following acts as an activator of muscle glycogen synthase?
questions.solution:
Option C: Insulin

  • Glycogen synthesis (glycogenesis) in the resting muscle is an anabolic process.
  • Insulin is an anabolic hormone and therefore increases the rate of the anabolic pathways.
  • Insulin increases the activity of muscle glycogen synthase after the intake of carbohydrates & increases glycogen reserves in the liver & muscles.
  • It acts by cAMP-mediated dephosphorylation of glycogen synthase 
  • Simultaneously, it also decreases glycogen phosphorylase activity, thereby decreasing glycogenolysis.

Option A: Epinephrine

  • Epinephrine is a catabolic hormone.
  • It is released in the fasting state.
  • It will decrease glycogen synthesis by inhibiting glycogen synthase.
  • It will increase glycogenolysis.

Option B: Glucagon

  • Glucagon also is a catabolic hormone.
  • It is released mainly in the fasting state to promote glycogenolysis and suppress glycogenesis

Option D: cAMP

  • Phosphorylation of anabolic enzymes such as glycogen synthase and fatty acid synthase is carried out by cAMP.
  • The phosphorylated state of glycogen synthase is inactive, and glycogen formation is suppressed.

questions.text: A 21-year-old white woman was referred to a hospital after exposure to CO from a faulty furnace. She developed acute weakness, dyspnea, nausea, and vomiting. An ECG revealed sinus tachycardia, non-specific ST-T wave abnormalities, and a prolonged QTc interval. The chest X-ray revealed pulmonary edema and the 2-D echo revealed decreased LV systolic function with an EF of 25%. The treatment for this woman, among the following, would be?
questions.solution:
Option C: 100% Oxygen

  • Maintain patent airway, fresh air, and orthobaric oxygen (high-flow or 100% oxygen at atmospheric pressure) Oxygen therapy is started if COHb > 10% and should be given for 4–6 hours.

Incorrect options

Option A: Ascorbic acid

  • It is given as an antidote for poisoning caused by a fatal dose of mercury

Option B: Intravenous methylene blue

  • It is given as a treatment for cyanide poisoning

questions.text: Which drug, acting by binding to viral envelope glycoprotein to inhibit the required conformational change for viral and cellular membrane fusion, is prescribed to the 19-year-old male with persistently high viral load and no improvement in CD-4 count after 2 months of first-line HAART for HIV-1?
questions.solution:
Option C: Enfuvirtide

  • Enfuvirtide belongs to a new class of drugs named fusion inhibitors that is useful in treating HIV infections.
  • It is used as a second-line agent in patients not responding to the initial antiretroviral therapy.
  • It binds to HIV-1 envelope transmembrane glycoprotein (gp41), which is involved in the fusion of viral and cellular membranes.
  • It has high viral target specificity.
  • Enfuvirtide is not active against HIV-2 because HIV-2 is intrinsically resistant to enfuvirtide.

 

Option A: Abacavir

  • Abacavir is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTIs).
  • It works by inhibiting the HIV reverse transcriptase enzyme and acts as a chain terminator of DNA synthesis.

Option B: Indinavir

  • Indinavir is a protease inhibitor.
  • It binds to the protease active site and inhibits the enzyme's activity.

Option D: Oseltamivir

  • Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor and works against influenza
  • It works by inhibiting the activity of the viral neuraminidase enzyme found on the surface of the virus, which prevents budding from the host cell, viral replication, and infectivity.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of redness of the eyes, frequent urinary tract infections and mild joint pain for two weeks. The patient further gives a history of dysuria and pelvic pain. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. For further examination of the eyes, the doctor had to pick cycloplegic drops to ensure that the patient did not develop posterior synechiae; which of the following difference between hyoscine and atropine must the doctor remember well?

choices.text: Hyoscine exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses
Hyoscine exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye
Hyoscine has weaker anti-motion sickness activity

questions.solution:
Option A: Hyoscine exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses

  • This is a case of reactive arthritis in which the patient presents with complaints of redness of the eyes, frequent urinary tract infections and mild joint pain for two weeks. The patient further gives a history of dysuria and pelvic pain. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • The above-mentioned clinical feature suggests reactive arthritis.
  • The diagnosis of reactive arthritis is usually made clinically.
  • For further examination of the eye, the doctor had to use cycloplegic drops.
  • To ensure the patient doesn't develop posterior synechia, the doctor must know that hyoscine exerts a depressant effect on the CNS at relatively low doses.

Option B: Hyoscine exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye

  • Hyoscine doesn’t exert more potent effects on the heart than on the eye.
  • It has a more potent effect on the eye and the secretory glands.

Option C: Hyoscine is longer acting

  • Hyoscine is a very short-acting drug.
  • Atropine is a long-acting drug.

Option D: Hyoscine has weaker anti-motion sickness activity

  • Hyoscine has a strong anti-motion sickness activity.
  • It is most commonly used to prevent motion sickness.
  • It can also be used for the reduction of saliva in the mouth.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology OPD with a complaint of gradual painless loss of vision in the right eye. On examination, the visual acuity of the right eye is 3/60. The fundus is not visible. The image of the affected eye is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Mature senile cataract

  • This 70-year-old male with decreased visual acuity and non-visible fundus likely has a senile cataract in the right eye, as shown in the image.
  • As the cataract matures, it leads to increased opacification of the lens, which presents as a cloudy lens.
  • There is a gradual loss of vision.
  • The fundus is not visible because of the opacification.

Option A: Retinoblastoma

  • Retinoblastoma usually presents in children.
  • The common presenting features are white reflex and squint.
  • The loss of vision is gradual, but it is usually painful.
  • In advanced stages, there is proptosis and exophytic growth.

Option B: Phacomorphic glaucoma

  • This is due to secondary angle closure by an intumescent cataract.
  • There will be a cloudy lens due to the presence of the cataract.
  • There is a sudden loss of vision.
  • The patient presents with severe pain and redness of the eye.

Option C: Cystoid macular edema

  • It is seen in diabetic retinopathy and retinal vascular disorders.
  • There is cystoid degeneration of the macula and retinal edema.
  • The loss of vision is gradual and painless.
  • There is no opacity in the lens.

questions.text: A 49-year-old human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-positive patient with no history of diabetes, hypertension, or renal disease visited the clinic for his regular check-up. His routine labs show creatinine of 4.5mg/dl. The physician suspects HIV-induced nephropathy (HIVAN). Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Shrunken kidneys

  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-associated nephropathy is a serious disorder that can cause lifelong kidney damage.
  • It can cause thrombotic microangiopathy and HIV-immune-complex kidney disease. It mostly affects the glomerulus.
  • The injury is distinguished by significant podocyte foot process effacement caused by direct HIV infection of renal epithelial cells, intrarenal viral gene expression, and host gene dysregulation.
  • Histology may reveal collapsing glomerulopathy and accompanying tubulointerstitial illness, including tubular microcysts and interstitial inflammation.
  • Proteinuria is a defining feature of this illness. A sonogram shows larger, hyperechogenic kidneys.
  • Renal biopsy provides a reliable diagnosis. Patients with HIV-associated nephropathy should be treated for their HIV infection regardless of CD4+ T cell level, along with ACE inhibitors and prednisone.
  • A shrunken kidney is not a feature of HIV-induced nephropathy.

Option A: Proteinuria

  • HIV-associated nephropathy classically presents a swift decline in GFR and proteinuria in the nephrotic range.
  • Other manifestations of nephropathy, such as peripheral oedema of the lower extremities and hypertension, are uncommon in this population.

Option C: 15% of cases show mesangial proliferation

  • Renal biopsy and Light microscopy of HIV nephropathy patients usually reveal different degrees of capillary collapse (collapsing glomerulopathy) and enlarged mesangial matrix, suggesting that mesangial hypercellularity is a feature of this condition.

Option D: Develops when CD4 < 200 cells/cu.mm

  • HIVAN is frequently associated with advanced HIV-1 infection. 
  • Patients usually present with high viral load, low CD4 count, and heavy proteinuria.
  • 80%-90% of HIVAN patients have a CD4-positive T-cell count of 200 cells/mm.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of fever, altered sensorium and purpuric rash for two days. On examination, the patient is found stuporous. He has a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and extensive palpable purpura over the legs. Which of the following would be the most appropriate initial choice of antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ceftriaxone

  • The clinical features are suggestive of Meningococcal sepsis.
  • Usually, asymptomatic nasopharyngeal colonisation
  • Early symptoms
    • Fever, headache and myalgia accompanied by vomiting and abdominal pain.
    • Non-blanching rash (>80%), if present, may appear to be early in the course until petechiae or purpuric lesions develop.
    • Purpura fulminans occur in severe cases with multiple large purpuric lesions and signs of peripheral ischemia.
  • Late symptoms
    • Meningitis (30% -50%)
    • Septicemia (20%)
  • Empirical antibiotic therapy for suspected Meningococcal disease consists of a third-generation cephalosporin such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime.

Option A: Vancomycin

  • Vancomycin can be used to treat penicillin- and cephalosporin-resistant S. pneumonia.

Option B: Penicillin G

  • Ceftriaxone and cefotaxime are the best initial antibiotics for meningococcal meningitis.
  • Penicillin G is the antibiotic of choice for susceptible strains of meningococcal meningitis.

Option C: Ciprofloxacin

  • Fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin are not adequate to treat meningococcal meningitis

questions.text: A 6-year-old presented to the clinic with scaly patches on the scalp. The hair was fluoresced under Wood's light. Primary smears of skin and hair demonstrated septate hyphae. Growth of the pathogen on a slope of modified Leonian’s agar shows yellow feathery colonies. Spindle-shaped multicellular macroconidia and small single-celled microconidia were seen. On speaking with the parent, it was found that there were several pets in the household. Which of the following is the most likely agent?
questions.solution:
Option C: Microsporum canis

  • Microsporum canis is a zoophilic dermatophyte.
  • It is a causal agent for tinea capitis in humans, children in particular.
  • Pets such as dogs and cats are the reservoirs of this fungus.
  • Growth in a culture medium shows yellow colonies due to the metabolites secreted by the fungus.
  • It forms spindle-shaped, multicelled macroconidia and small, single-celled microconidia.
  • Examination of the infected tissue under Wood’s lamp shows septate hyphae and fluoresce bright green.

Option A: Epidermophyton floccosum

  • Epidermophyton floccosum is an anthropophillic dermatophyte.
  • This species is found more commonly in tropical and subtropical areas.
  • Colonies of epidermophyton floccosum grown on Sabouraud agar forms white pleomorphic tufts. Its colonies also produce reddish-brown pigment.
  • They form smooth, thin-walled and club-shaped macroconidia. This specie does not form microconidia.
  • It most commonly causes tinea pedis and tinea cruris but less commonly tinea capitis because it cannot perforate hair follicles.

Option B: Microsporum audouinii

  • Microsporum audouinii is a geophilic dermatophyte.
  • It causes tinea capitis mostly in prepubescent children (starting at 6 months) and rarely in adults.
  • Microscopy of the infected tissues shows spindle-shaped macroconidia and few microconidia.
  • Racquet-shaped hyphae are characteristic of Microsporum audouinii.
  • On potato dextrose agar, Microsporum audouinii form colonies with a silky texture and a peach-coloured underside.

Option D: Trichophyton rubrum

  • Trichophyton rubrum is an anthropophilic dermatophyte.
  • It causes athlete’s foot, fungal infection of nails, and jock itch. It very rarely causes tinea capitis.
  • It thrives on the dead layer of tissues.
  • Trichophyton rubrum grows slowly on culture medium and forms tear-drop or peg-shaped microconidia.
  • It forms greenish colonies on Littman Oxgall agar.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of precocious puberty in girls??
questions.solution:
Option A: Idiopathic

  • Pubertal changes before 8 years in girls and boys before 9 years are considered precocious puberty.
  • The clinical features include early sexual development.
  • GnRH agonist is the most effective treatment for precocious puberty treatment.

The most common cause of precocious puberty in girls → Idiopathic

Others causes:

  • Congenital lesions of the hypothalamus-pituitary.
  • Acquired lesions
    •  infection
    • neoplasm : ovarian, adrenal, pituitary
  • Part of a specific syndrome—McCune Albright (5%), von Recklinghausen’s neurofibromatosis.
  • Endocrine/metabolic disorders.

Option B: Gonadal tumours

  • Gonadal tumors secreting sex hormones may lead to precocious puberty in both girls and boys.
  • However these are not common causes.

Option C: McCune-Albright syndrome

  • It is caused by the mosaic mutation in G-protein to cause the continuous stimulation of endocrine function.
  • It causes precocious puberty, polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and café-au-lait spots.
  • However it is not the most common cause of precocious puberty.

Option D: Hypothyroidism

  • It causes the deficiency of thyroid hormones T3 and T4.
  • It causes fatigue, cold intolerance, bradycardia, and weight gain.
  • It causes delayed puberty until the 12-13 years of age of epiphyseal maturation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old comes to the gynecologist for a routine check-up. The patient is vitally stable, and other physical examinations are unremarkable. The patient was on the 24th day of her cycle. The ultrasound shows an incidental finding of a small thick-walled right ovarian cyst with peripheral vascularity. A follow-up scan is done days post menstruation and shows no such cyst. What is the most probable mechanism involved in resolving the structure involved in the patient’s pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: Decreased levels of LH

  • This is a case of a corpus luteal cyst.

  • The ultrasound finding of the thick-walled cyst with peripheral vascularity in the premenstrual period suggests a corpus luteal cyst that spontaneously resolves post menstruation in the absence of pregnancy.

  • Continued corpus luteum function depends on continued LH production.

  • Without this stimulation, the corpus luteum will invariably regress after 12 to16 days and form scar-like Corpora Albicans.

  • In the absence of pregnancy, the corpus luteum regresses, and estrogen and progesterone levels wane.

  • If pregnancy occurs, HCG from the placenta will mimic LH action, and the corpus luteum continues to secrete progesterone.

Option A: Increased levels of progesterone

  • Post-menstruation, there is a drop in the levels of progesterone, which subsequently increases again after ovulation as progesterone is released from the corpus luteum.

Option B: Increased levels of estrogen

  • Post-menstruation, estrogen increases gradually as it is produced from the ovarian follicles, which FSH recruits. This increase is responsible for the inhibition of FSH and not for the resolution of the corpus luteum.

Option D: Decreased levels of FSH

  • FSH levels are high in the early proliferative phase, and levels are inhibited by estrogen that is produced from the follicular development.

  • Drop in FSH does not cause corpus luteal cyst resolution.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with pain in the epigastrium and difficulty breathing for 6 hours. On examination, his heart rate was 56 beats per minute, and his blood pressure was 106/60 mmHg. Chest examination was normal. The patient has been taking omeprazole for gastroesophageal reflux for the last six months. What is the best initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Option A: An ECG

  • The patient has bradycardia and hypotension and is an older adult. A risk factor for coronary artery disease in this patient is age. Chest pain might be deceiving. The presence of bradycardia, hypotension and shortness of breath suggest myocardial infarction.
  • So an electrocardiogram (ECG) should be performed as part of the initial evaluation at the presentation.
  • In inferior wall myocardial infarction, a second-degree heart block (intermittent atrioventricular block) may manifest as a temporary anomaly.
  • Even though many patients within the first hour of myocardial infarction have normal blood pressure and pulse rates, up to one-half of patients with inferior infarction exhibit parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and hypotension) and about one-fourth of patients with anterior infarction do.

Option B: An upper GI endoscopy

  • An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is a very invasive and expensive procedure. It can be performed after initial evaluation if a peptic ulcer, gastric cancer, or oesophageal pathology is suspected.
  • Endoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for evaluating gastric ulcers.

Option C: Urgent ultrasound of the abdomen

  • Ultrasound of the abdomen is indicated if pancreatitis or cholecystitis is suspected.
  • In this patient, bradycardia and hypotension point towards a cardiac origin of epigastric pain.
  • Nonetheless, in patients with coronary disease risk factors, ECG should be prioritized over ultrasound.

Option D: An X-ray chest

  • An X-ray of the chest is indicated chest pain if spontaneous pneumothorax is suspected.
  • It is also the best initial investigation into the perforation of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • This patient has been complying with his regimen of proton-pump inhibitors, and signs of peritonitis, such as rebound tenderness and guarding, are absent in this patient.

questions.text: When does progesterone level rise to its highest point during the female hormonal cycle?

choices.text: Between ovulation and just before menstruation
When the blood concentration of LH is at its highest point
When 12 primary follicles are developing to the antral Stage

questions.solution:
Option A: Between Ovulation and the beginning of menstruation

  • The corpus luteum is the only source of progesterone production, except for minute quantities secreted from the follicle before Ovulation.
  • The corpus luteum is functional between Ovulation and the beginning of menstruation, during which time the concentration of LH is suppressed below the level achieved during the preovulatory LH surge.

Stage

Progesterone level (ng/mL)

Pre-ovulation

<0.89

Ovulation

≤12

Post-ovulation

1.8-24

First trimester

11-44

Second trimester

25-83

Third trimester

58-214
  • Progesterone is one of two female sex hormones, the other being estrogen.
  • Its main functions are regulating menstruation and supporting pregnancy in the female body.
  • In the middle of a menstrual cycle, levels of to Ovulation increase.
  • Ovulation refers to the release of an egg from one of the two ovaries.
  • Once the egg is released, the corpus luteum forms and produces progesterone.
  • Progesterone helps to prepare the body for pregnancy by stimulating glandular development and the development of new blood vessels.
  • This provides a good environment for implantation by a fertilized egg.
  • If the egg isn't fertilized, the corpus luteum breaks down, leading to a drop in progesterone levels.
  • This decrease causes the endometrium to break down, causing the beginning of a menstrual period endometrium to break down, causing the beginning of a menstrual period.

Option B: Immediately before Ovulation

  • Ovulation leads to the formation of the corpus luteum.
  • This produces progesterone.
  • Therefore, progesterone levels are very low before Ovulation.

Option C: When the blood concentration of LH is at its highest point

  • The blood concentration of LH is highest between 12-14 days.
  • LH has nothing to do with the progesterone level.
  • Rather, LH surge causes Ovulation.

Option D: When 12 primary follicles are developing to the antral Stage

  • Follicles are not a source of progesterone.
  • It is produced by the corpus luteum and is highest on the 21st day of the cycle.

questions.text: After being involved in a car accident, a patient is hospitalized. His Glasgow Coma Scale score is 8/15, and he has major blunt injuries to his head, chest, and abdomen. His oxygen saturations are subpar, at 89%, using a rebreathing mask and 15 L of oxygen. You observe bruises around his eyes and blood-stained fluid oozing from his left ear, which creates concentric circles when spilt on a white sheet. In order to promote oxygenation, you want to assist his airway. The first choice of airway adjunct would be
questions.solution:
Option A: Oropharyngeal airway

  • This patient has sustained a significant head injury which complicates the choice of airway.
  • A patient with a GCS score of 8 may still gag on the Guedel airway, although with a patient thus obtunded, it may be tolerated without sedation.
  • An endotracheal tube may be required later in the resuscitation because this patient has a severe head injury; however, endotracheal intubation requires an anaesthetist and significant time.
  • Guedel airway placement should still be considered the first choice adjunct as it is quick, allowing further assessment of the patient to continue and acting as a bridge to intubation.
  • With nasopharyngeal tube placement contraindicated, the first option in this patient would be Guedel oropharyngeal airway placement.

Option B: Nasopharyngeal tube

  • A nasopharyngeal airway device (NPA) is a hollow tube made of plastic or soft rubber that a healthcare professional can use to help patients breathe more easily when using a bag-mask ventilation system.
  • Any suspicion of a basal skull fracture is an absolute contraindication to nasopharyngeal airway and nasogastric tube insertion.
  • This is because of the risk of penetrating through the damaged cribriform plate and damaging the brain.
  • Basal skull fractures include:
  • periorbital ecchymosis (panda eyes/raccoon eyes),
  • Retroauricular ecchymosis (battle sign),
  • CSF leakage from the nose or ears
  • Situations when oropharyngeal airways cannot be used, such as oral injuries or trismus, can sometimes be treated with nasopharyngeal airways (restriction of mouth opening including spasm of muscles of mastication). Additionally, nasal airways might make bag-valve-mask ventilation easier.

Option C: Laryngeal mask

  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA) are supraglottic airway devices.
  • They may be used as a quick method to maintain an open airway during the administration of anaesthesia or as an immediate life-saving measure in a difficult or failed airway patient.
  • Indications for Laryngeal Mask Airway: Apnea, severe respiratory failure, or impending respiratory arrest in which endotracheal intubation cannot be accomplished.
  • The advantages of the laryngeal mask airway include anaesthetic management, induction, maintenance, and emergence.
  • The placement of the LMA can be accomplished without muscle relaxants and laryngoscopy.

Option D: Intubation

  • Intubation occurs when a medical professional inserts a tube into a patient's trachea (airway/windpipe) from the mouth or nose.
  • The tube maintains the trachea's opening, allowing air to pass through.
  • The tube may be attached to a device that disperses air or oxygen.
  • When the airway is clogged or injured, or a person cannot breathe independently, intubation is required.
  • Airway obstruction is one of the frequent conditions that might result in intubation (something caught in the airway, blocking the flow of air). Heart arrest (sudden loss of heart function).

questions.text: A 20-year-old previously healthy swimmer is admitted for new-onset severe fatigue and left upper abdominal pain. She was treated two days ago in hospital for presumed typhoid fever with cefotaxime. Her family or past medical history is insignificant except for recurrent typhoid fever. She is a non-alcoholic and non-smoker. Her blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, and her heart rate is 120 bpm. Physical examination reveals a palpable spleen. The stool is negative for heme. Lab investigations show haemoglobin of 5 g/dL with normal total lymphocyte count (TLC) and platelets. A peripheral blood smear reveals IgG antibodies and an excess of spherocytes. Which of the following do not cause a similar type of condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Infectious mononucleosis

This patient’s recent medication history with the lab values mostly suggests autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) due to the development of warm immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies as a consequence of cefotaxime exposure.

Autoimmune haemolytic anaemia (AIHA):

  • It is idiopathic normocytic anaemia, where the body’s immune system produces autoantibodies directed against its own RBC that attack and destroy RBC.
  • These autoantibodies bind to RBC cell surface antigens and cause them to clump
  • A warm antibody (IgG) hemolytic anaemia is the most common form of AIHA.
  • Another form of AIHA is cold (IgM) antibody hemolytic anaemia.
  • Infectious mononucleosis is associated with cold (IgM) AIHA.
  • Autoantibodies generally react at temperatures > 37° C.
  • Hemolysis occurs primarily in the spleen, resulting in splenomegaly.
  • The autoantibodies production may occur due to:
    • Spontaneously
    • SLE, lymphoma, CLL
    • Drug exposure: alpha-methyldopa, high-dose penicillin, cephalosporins, quinidine.
  • Coombs test is the best investigation to diagnose AIHA.

Option A: SLE

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease that is associated with AIHA.

Option B: α-Methyldopa ingestion

  • This drug can also cause the development of autoantibodies to RBC, resulting in AIHA.

Option C: Quinidine

  • Quinidine exposure can also cause AIHA by producing antibodies against RBC.

questions.text: Which of the following membranes has the tips of the outer hair cells embedded in it?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: Tectorial membrane

  • The cochlea is a system of coiled tubes. These tubes include scala vestibuli, scala media, and scala tympani.
  • The scala vestibuli and media are separated by Reissner's (vestibular)membrane.
  • The basilar membrane separates the scala media and scala tympani.
  • The organ of Corti lies on the basilar membrane.
  • The organ of Corti contains inner and outer hair cells.
  • 3500 inner hair cells and 12000 outer hair cells are arranged in four rows, one row of inner hair cells, and three rows of outer hair cells.
  • The bases and sides of the hair cells synapse with a network of cochlear nerve endings.
  • Minute hairs called stereocilia project upward from the hair cells and are embedded in the tectorial membrane.
  • Stereocilia of outer hair cells are embedded in the tectorial membrane.
  • Stereocilia of inner hair cells just touch the tectorial membrane.
  • The outer ends of the hair cells are fixed tightly in a rigid structure composed of a flat plate called the reticular lamina.

Option A: Basilar membrane

  • The basilar membrane separates scala media and scala tympani.
  • It forms the base of hair cells.

Option B: Reissner’s membrane

  • Reissner’s membrane separates scala vestibuli and scala media.
  • It does not have stereocilia of hair cells embedded in it.

Option D: Tympanic membrane

  • The tympanic membrane is a membrane that separates the outer ear from the middle ear.
  • It is also called the ear drum.

questions.text: The lawyer who is defending the suspect has fought the initial trial, for the suspect to be excused under IPC 84, which was derived from McNaughton RULES. What is the basis of the argument and request for excuse according to the section appealed under?
questions.solution:
Option A: Criminal responsibility of insane

  • Section 84 IPC: Criminal responsibility of insane.
  • According to this section, nothing is an offence done by a person who is incapable of knowing that what he is doing is wrong due to mental illness.

Option B: Criminal responsibility of drunken person

  • Section 86 IPC: Criminal responsibility of voluntary intoxication

Option C: Criminal responsibility of intoxicated person

  • Section 85 IPC: Offence caused after involuntary intoxication 

Option D: Criminal responsibility of child

  • Section 82 IPC: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child < 7 years of age.
  • Section 83 IPC: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child between 7-12 years seven years of age who has not attained sufficient maturity to judge the nature of the act.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman with hypertension presents with complaints of morning stiffness & painful joints of the hands. Initial investigations were done, which showed a raised ESR and positive RF.CBC report is as follows:

Hb=9.8g/dl, MCV=88fl,  MCH=30pg, MCHC=35g/dl

 X-ray of the hands showed joint space loss and subchondral erosion. The Peripheral smear is given in the image below. Which type of anemia is usually seen in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option A: Normocytic, normochromic

  • The above clinical history & features are suggestive of Rheumatoid Arthritis.
  • Anaemia of chronic illness traditionally encompassed any long-standing inflammatory, infectious, or malignant disease.
  • Including rheumatoid arthritis, severe trauma, heart disease, or diabetes mellitus.
  • There is primarily a decreased availability of iron, relatively decreased levels of erythropoietin, and a mild decrease in the lifespan of RBCs to 70-80 days.
  • Early-onset rheumatoid arthritis with positive rheumatoid factor is more likely to have normocytic normochromic anaemia.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune condition that causes synovial cell proliferation and pannus formation, which damages cartilage and soft tissue and erodes bone over time.
  • Radiological features of RA include periarticular erosions, soft tissue swelling, osteopenia, joint effusions, and loss of joint space in advanced cases; the arrow shows periarticular erosions.
  • RA causes bilateral involvement of the wrist, metacarpophalangeal and PIP joints. DIP joints are spared.
  • Joint involvement will always be in a symmetrical pattern.
  • The radiological features of RA can be remembered using the mnemonic LESS: loss of joint space, erosions, soft tissue swelling, and soft bones (osteopenia).

Option B: Macrocytic, normochromic

  • Megaloblastic anaemia is a side effect of MTX used to treat RA.
  • However, the smear doesn't show any megaloblasts or hypersegmented neutrophils, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

Option C: Normocytic, hypochromic

  • Hyperchromasia is unlikely as central pallor is less than 1/3rd of the RBC surface area.

Option D: Microcytic hypochromic

  • Usually seen in thalassemia, iron deficiency, lead poisoning and sideroblastic anaemia.
  • MCV would be below 80fl

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with the complaint of rash for the past 3 days. She denies any fever or drug intake. On examination, flaccid bullae over the skin and oral cavity are noted. Nikolsky sign and Bullae Spread sign were present. The histopathological image is shown below:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pemphigus

  • It is an Autoimmune condition.
  • IgG Antibodies are formed against Desmoglein [Desmosomal protein], present within the epidermis resulting in Intra-epidermal bullae.
  • Nikolsky sign and Bullae Spread sign are positive.
  • Earliest changes: Intercellular edema + disappearance of intercellular bridges in the lowermost epidermis.
  • Loss of coherence between epidermal cells (acantholysis) → formation of clefts → bullae in the suprabasal zone.
  • Basal cells remain attached to the dermis, producing a “tombstone” appearance.
  • Acantholytic cells are present in the bulla cavity.
  • Scanty perivascular inflammatory infiltrate composed of lymphocytes, histiocytes, and occasional eosinophils, neutrophils, and plasma cells are present.

Option A: Irritant dermatitis

  • Develop exposure to detergents/vegetables.
  • Most commonly seen in housewives. Thus, known as housewives' eczema.
  • It may occurs on 1st exposure.
  • Memory T cells are formed.
  • Nikolsky sign sign and bulla spread sign is negative.
  • Moreover, immunofluorescence is negative in irritant dermatitis.

Option C: Pemphigoid

  • It is an Autoimmune disorder.
  • IgG Antibodies are formed against BP Ag 2 [BP 180] > BP Ag 1 [BP 230] sub-epidermal bullae leading to. [BP: Bullous Pemphigoid]
  • Clinical feature
    • Tense bullae with peri-lesional erythema [redness around lesion] are seen, which heals with Milia formation [Milia = small keratin cysts. Sometimes seen Denovo over face]
  • Nikolsky sign is negative, but the Bullae Spread sign is positive.

Option D: Herpes zoster

  • In a child with healed chicken pox, the virus may remain dormant in nerves/ ganglia, which can reactivate later in life.
  • This reactivation of Varicella zoster virus Herpes causes zoster.
  • Clinical features
    • Lesions are distributed along the route of the nerve.
    • Thus, it presents as Unilateral, grouped painful vesicles along a dermatome.
  • Treatment
    • Drug of choice is Acyclovir 800 mg 5 times/day x 7 days.
  • Nikolsky sign is seen in pemphigus patient.
  • Moreover, immunoflurescene is also positive in pemphigus not in herpes zoster.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady is presenting to the ophthalmology outpatient department with complaints of pain, redness in the eye and increased sensitivity to light. On examination, cells are seen in the eye's anterior chamber. Detailed history revealed that she took a drug for treatment for a condition and that all her symptoms seemed to exacerbate after taking the medication. Which of the below medicines will cause the patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Brimonidine

  • In this case, the patient is presenting with pain, redness in the eye and increased sensitivity to light which is suggestive of anterior Uveitis. These symptoms can be exacerbated by some drugs, including brimonidine, cidofovir, rifabutin, and others.
  • Brimonidine is an α2 adrenergic agonist that leads to vasoconstriction of blood vessels resulting in an acute reduction in aqueous humor flow, and it relaxes the ciliary muscle and increases uveoscleral outflow via increased prostaglandin release due to α adrenergic stimulation, which worsens the symptoms of anterior Uveitis.
  • It is used to treat open-angle glaucoma, ocular hypertension, and rosacea.
  • When used in the eyes, common side effects include itchiness, redness, and a dry mouth.
  • When used on the skin, common side effects include redness, burning, and headaches.

Option A: Captopril

  • It is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor used to treat hypertension and some types of congestive heart failure.
  • Adverse effects of captopril include cough due to an increase in the plasma levels of bradykinin, angioedema, agranulocytosis, proteinuria, hyperkalemia, taste alteration, teratogenicity, postural hypotension, acute renal failure, leukopenia.

Option B: Methotrexate

  • A chemotherapy agent and immune-system suppressant.
  • It is used in cancer, autoimmune diseases, and ectopic pregnancies.
  • Common side effects include nausea, feeling tired, fever, increased risk of infection, low white blood cell counts, and breakdown of the skin inside the mouth.

Option C: Chloroquine

  • Chloroquine generally does not cause anterior Uveitis.
  • It is used in malaria from Plasmodium vivax, P. ovale, and P. malaria
  • Side effects include nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, diarrhoea, swelling legs/ankles, shortness of breath, pale lips/nails/skin, muscle weakness, easy bruising/bleeding, and hearing and mental problems.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presents to the clinic and complains of blood in urine, nausea, weakness and swelling of both legs and puffiness of the face. Her blood pressure is 150/110 mmHg, and her pulse is 80 beats/min. She does not recall getting sick in the recent past. Urine analysis is done, which shows nonselective proteinuria and red cell casts. Her BUN and creatinine are 70 mg/dl and 3.0 mg/dl, respectively. Renal biopsy showed glomerular crescents. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis

  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is an inflammatory condition causing rapid destruction of glomeruli, leading to end-stage renal disease.
  • It is characterised by hematuria and nephritic range proteinuria ( <3.5g/day)
  • Patients can rapidly progress to renal failure leading to anuria and anasarca.
  • Crescents on renal biopsy are an affirmative sign of RPGN.
  • It can be treated with steroids and cyclophosphamide.

Option A: Membranous Nephropathy

  • Membranous nephropathy is the most common nephrotic syndrome in adults.
  • It is characterised by nonselective proteinuria ( > 3.5g/day), which can manifest as oedema, a prothrombotic state, and increased susceptibility to infections.
  • It is usually associated with autoimmune conditions (e.g. SLE), infections (e.g. hepatitis B, hepatitis C) or solid organ malignancies (e.g. lung, breast, etc.)
  • It does not cause hematuria.

Option B: Minimal Change Disease

  • Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common nephrotic syndrome in children and presents with selective proteinuria.
  • The patient presents with hyperlipidemia and oedema.
  • It is usually idiopathic but can be caused by secondary conditions, including immunisations, infections, and malignancies.
  • It can be treated with steroids.

Option D: Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis

  • Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN) usually occurs 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or skin infection.
  • PSGN will have nephritic range proteinuria, deformed RBCs, and RBC casts in urine.
  • The diagnosis can be confirmed by looking for evidence of streptococcal infection (ASO titers, throat culture for pharyngitis, wound culture for skin infection) and complement levels.
  • However, this patient does not mention any recent illnesses in history, making this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old patient with a history of poorly controlled hypertension presents to the emergency department with a severe headache for the last hour. On physical examination, blood pressure is 210/120 mm Hg, the pulse is 106/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. On a CT scan, the doctor finds a hyperintense region in the temporal lobe and the affected area is labeled in the image below:



The damage to this area can result in which one of the following?

choices.text: Failure of comprehension of spoken or written words

questions.solution:
Option D: Failure of comprehension of spoken or written words

  • The area represented in the image is Wernicke’s area. Damage to this area can result in receptive aphasia, and the patient fails to comprehend spoken and written words

  • The two areas concerned with language and speech are:
  • Wernicke’s area (the sensory area for speech): It is in the superior temporal lobe.
  • Broca’s area (the motor area for speech): It is in the inferior frontal lobe.

​​​​​​​

  • Wernicke’s area involves understanding and comprehending spoken or written words.
  • After understanding and comprehending the word, Wernicke’s area decides the words to be spoken.
  • The impulses are sent via arcuate fasciculus and then to the Broca’s area.
  • The Broca’s area signals to the motor cortex of the brain, which sends this information to the vocal cords and tongue to bring about the phenomenon of correct speech.
  • When there is damage to Wernicke’s area, speech production is normal (since the motor area that finally produces actual words is not damaged). However, patients talk excessively; what they say is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense.
  • The patient fails to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words. This is called fluent aphasia.​​​​​​​

Option A: Global aphasia

  • Global aphasia involves the lesion in Wernicke’s area as well as in Broca’s area.
  • The patient is neither able to comprehend spoken or written words nor is he able to deliver the speech.

Option B: Non-fluent aphasia

  • Non-fluent aphasia results from a lesion in the Broca’s area.
  • The patient can comprehend written or spoken words, but he cannot bring about the phenomenon of speech.

Option C: Conduction aphasia

  • Conduction aphasia results from a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus.
  • Arcuate fasciculus is the connection between Wernicke’s and Broca’s areas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male comes to the clinic complaining of shortness of breath and fatigue for the last 6 months. Physical examination is unremarkable except for conjunctival pallor. Laboratory test results are awaited. The peripheral blood smear of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on this patient's peripheral blood smear findings?
questions.solution:
Option A: Megaloblastic Anaemia

Cabot Rings:

  • This patient presenting with shortness of breath and fatigue most likely has anaemia.
  • The peripheral blood smear showing Cabot rings points towards the diagnosis of megaloblastic anaemia.
  • Megaloblastic anaemia is caused by the deficiency of vitamin B12 or folic acid → defective DNA synthesis, → megaloblasts.
  • Cabot rings are thin, thread-like, red to violet, loop or figure-of-eight shaped inclusions seen in reticulocytes or sometimes in megaloblasts.
  • These rings are composed of nuclear material and are considered the remnants of mitotic spindles which were mishandled during abnormal cell division.
  • Some investigators suggest the absence of DNA and spindle filaments in Cabot rings and have found them to be composed of arginine-rich histone and non-haemoglobin iron.

Option B: Sickle Cell Disease

  • Sickle cell disease is an inherited red blood disorder caused by a mutation in the haemoglobin beta gene.
  • The peripheral blood smear shows sickle cells (crescent-shaped) caused by the polymerisation of haemoglobin S.

Option C: Iron Deficiency Anaemia

  • Iron deficiency anaemia is caused by decreased production of haemoglobin due to decreased availability of iron.
  • The peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic red blood cells rather than the Cabot rings seen on this patient's blood smear.

Option D: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anaemia

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia is caused by autoantibodies reacting against red blood cells.
  • The peripheral smear usually shows micro spherocytes, and a high reticulocyte count instead of the Cabot rings seen in this case.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man with a known case of moderate persistent asthma presents with an inability to speak in complete sentences, progressive worsening of shortness of breathing, wheezing, and cough over 5 days, followed by a history of recent respiratory infection. On examination, increased respiratory rate, tachycardia, and cyanosis are noted. ABG shows hypoxemia and low PaCo2. In PFT, there is a marked fall in FEV1 and PEFR. Which of the following is given in the maintenance of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Long-acting beta 2 agonist

  • The given clinical features and investigatory findings show there is severe persistent asthma.
  • LABAs improve asthma control and reduce exacerbations when added to ICS, which allows asthma to be controlled at lower doses of corticosteroids.
  • Management of chronic asthma :

Step-wise Therapy 

  1. Mild, intermittent asthma - SABA is all that is required.
  2. If symptoms are not controlled, a LABA should be added which is most conveniently given by switching to a combination inhaler.
  3. In patients with severe asthma, low-dose oral theophylline is also helpful.
  4. If asthma is not controlled despite the maximal recommended dose of inhaled therapy, it is important to check adherence and inhaler technique.
  5. In these patients maintenance treatment with an OCS may be needed.
  6. Occasionally, omalizumab and anti-IL-5 may be tried in steroid-dependent asthmatics who are not well controlled.

Option A: Oral Steroid

  • Short courses of oral prednisone are indicated in acute asthma exacerbations (eg, wheezing) and cases of poorly controlled symptoms. 
  • Chronic use of oral prednisone is not recommended due to significant adverse effects (eg, glucose intolerance, osteopenia, adrenal suppression).

Option B: Leukotriene agonists

  • Leukotriene agonists are not in the treatment of asthma maintenance therapy, as they induce bronchoconstriction and exacerbate asthma symptoms.
  • Leukotriene antagonist can use in controlling the allergic asthma e.g montelukast.

Option C: Ipratropium bromide

  • Long-acting antimuscarinic agents (eg, tiotropium) are indicated for step-up therapy in patients with poorly controlled persistent asthma despite scheduled high-dose ICS-formoterol.
  • Hence adding an antimuscarinic agent would not be the next step in therapy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male is admitted to the emergency department due to severe chest pain and shortness of breath that started 1 hour ago. The patient had a past medical history of myocardial infarction 10 years ago and uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago. The patient has been non-compliant with his medications. His blood pressure is 80/45 mmHg, his pulse is 50/min, his respiratory rate is 26/minute, and his temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F). His urine output is decreased. The electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals bradycardia and ST-segment elevation in inferior leads. Chest radiography shows clear pulmonary fields. In addition to myocardial infarction treatment, which of the following should be done?

choices.text: Non-invasive ventilation with tight-fitting face mask

questions.solution:
Option B: Intubation with mechanical ventilation

  • This patient with risk factors for MI and ST-elevation in inferior leads suffers from acute myocardial infarction leading to hypo-perfusion and shock.
  • Patients with shock develop type IV respiratory failure.
  • Type IV respiratory failure occurs due to hypo-perfusion of respiratory muscles.
  • Normally, respiratory muscles consume <5% of total cardiac output and oxygen delivery.
  • Patients in shock may have as much as 40% of cardiac output distributed to respiratory muscles.
  • Intubation and ventilator-assisted breathing will allow re-distribution of cardiac output.
  • This will off-load the respiratory system and decrease oxygen consumption.

Option A: Non-invasive ventilation with tight-fitting face mask

  • Non-invasive ventilation (NIV) with a tight-fitting face mask is used to manage type 2 Respiratory failure, e.g., in acute exacerbations of COPD.
  • Utilising a mask or similar device, non-invasive ventilation (NIV) refers to the delivery of ventilatory assistance through the patient's upper airway.
  • This method differs from invasive methods since they use a tracheal tube, laryngeal mask, or tracheostomy to bypass the upper airway.
  • NIV may increase the right ventricular afterload.
  • Lung damage brought on by the ventilator and discomfort/muscle overload due to poor patient-ventilator interactions is potential negative physiological effects of NIV. 

Option C: Continuous positive pressure ventilation

  • A form of positive airway pressure ventilation known as continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) involves continually applying pressure greater than atmospheric pressure to a person's upper respiratory tract.
  • A continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machine may be suggested to stop snoring and avoid sleep apnea.
  • It keeps airway openings clear, reducing breathing pauses and promoting deeper sleep.

 

Option D: High-frequency jet ventilation

  • High-frequency jet ventilation describes high-frequency ventilation (HFV) administered via a gas jet. It begins when a small (14 to 16-gauge) cannula connected to a specialist ventilator is inserted into the endotracheal tube's lumen.
  • Trans-tracheal jet ventilation is an invasive method for oxygenation and ventilation in treating a difficult airway.
  • In the operating theatre, jet ventilation using a rigid bronchoscope is frequently employed for interventional pulmonology operations and laryngeal surgery.

questions.text: What is the false regarding difference in between Upper motor neuron lesion and Lower motor neuron lesion?
questions.solution:
Option D: Paralysis is Flaccid in UMNL

  • This statement is incorrect
  • Paralysis is spastic in UMNL

Other options

​​​​​​​Option A: Tone is increased in UMNL

  • Tone is increased in UMNL is true

Option B: Babinski sign positive in UMNL

  • Babinski sign positive in UMNL is true

Option C: Clonus present in UMNL

  • Clonus present in UMNL is true

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to a worsening headache for 3 hours. She describes the headache as unlike anything, she has experienced before. She denies any nausea, vomiting, or visual or auditory deficits. She defines it as the ‘worst headache of her life. She has had a history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney for 3 years. Vital signs appear to be within normal limits. Examination reveals a GCS of 13/15 with equally reactive pupils. A non-contrast computed tomography (CT) brain shows. Which of the following is not associated with this patient’s condition?

choices.text: An analysis of the cerebrospinal fluid reveals xanthochromia.
Electrocardiography reveals a prolonged Q-T interval.
The most common cause of death in this condition is re-bleeding.
The drug of choice for management is nimodipine.

questions.solution:
Option C: The most common cause of death in this condition is re-bleeding.

  • The female presents with ‘the worst headache of her life, also known as a thunderclap headache.
  • This symptom, along with the decreased GCS and a history of polycystic kidney disease, is highly suggestive of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH). 
  • Subarachnoid haemorrhage is bleeding in the subarachnoid space (shown above).
  • Risk factors leading to subarachnoid haemorrhage are hypertension, smoking, alcoholism, cocaine use and a family history of subarachnoid haemorrhage.
  • The clinical features include acute severe headache, vomiting, reduced level of consciousness, and seizures occasionally.
  • Physical examination reveals neck stiffness.
  • A non-contrast CT scan and lumbar puncture are required for its diagnosis.
  • The CT scan shows the bleeding in the subarachnoid space, usually within 6 hours.
  • Lumbar puncture and CSF analysis showed elevated red blood cells (equal number in all the bottles) and xanthochromia (yellow appearance of centrifuged fluid due to breakdown of haemoglobin).
  • ECG changes commonly occur in SAH, including J (Osborn) and Q-T prolongation.
  • Treatment measures include stabilization of the patient, monitoring of the vitals, reducing blood pressure with labetalol or nicardipine, clipping of an aneurysm if present and preventing vasospasm with nimodipine.
  • There are four causes of delayed neurological deficit in subarachnoid haemorrhage. 
    • Re-rupture 
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Delayed cerebral ischemia (vasospasm): Following subarachnoid haemorrhage, narrowing of arteries at the base of the brain may occur. This causes symptomatic ischemia and infarction in about 30% of patients and is the major cause of delayed morbidity and mortality. Signs of delayed cerebral ischemia appear 4–14 days after the haemorrhage, most often at 7 days. 
    • Hyponatremia

Option A: An analysis of the cerebrospinal fluid reveals xanthochromia

  • In subarachnoid haemorrhage, lysis of the red blood cells occurs, which causes the conversion of haemoglobin to bilirubin.
  • Bilirubin stains the spinal fluid yellow within 6–12 h, referred to as xanthochromia.
  • The xanthochromic CSF peaks in intensity at 48 h and lasts for 1–4 weeks, depending on the amount of subarachnoid blood.

Option B: Electrocardiography reveals a prolonged Q-T interval.

  • ECG changes also occur in subarachnoid haemorrhage.
  • The most frequent abnormalities include S-T segment depression, Q-T interval prolongation, Osborn waves, deep T-wave inversions, and prominent U waves.

Option D: The drug of choice for management is nimodipine.

  • Management of subarachnoid haemorrhage involves treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine: 60 mg per oral every 4 hours improves outcome, perhaps by preventing ischemic injury and reducing the risk of vasospasm.

questions.text: A seminar is being conducted about the importance of serum electrolytes. It is explained that  K+ and Na+ are essential for life. Molecular pumps that pull K+ into cells and push Na+ out create a chemical battery that drives the transmission of signals along nerves and powers the contraction of muscles. K+ and Na+ help the kidneys work properly. They are important for energy production and fluid balance. All of the following statements are correct about potassium balance, except?

choices.text: Most of the K+ is intracellular
3/4th of the total body potassium is found in skeletal muscle
Intracellular K+ is released into extracellular space in response to severe injury
Acidosis leads to movement of K+ from ECF to ICF

questions.solution:
Option D: Acidosis leads to movement of K+ from ECF to ICF

  • In acidosis, H+ is pumped into the cells. And, to maintain electroneutrality, K+ moves out of the cells, causing hyperkalemia.
  • Sodium and potassium ions are transported across the cell membrane by means of a common carrier protein called sodium-potassium (Na+-K+) pump. It is also called Na+-K+ ATPase pump or Na+-K+ ATPase. This pump transports sodium from inside to outside the cell and potassium from outside to inside the cell. This pump is present in all the cells of the body. Na+-K+ pump is responsible for distributing sodium and potassium ions across the cell membrane and developing resting membrane potential.
  • In acidosis, K+ moves out of the cells, causing hyperkalemia.

In alkalosis, H+ ions move out of cells into plasma, and K+ moves from plasma into cells, resulting in hypokalemia.

Option A: Most of the K+ is intracellular

  • 98% of the total K+ is located intracellularly.

Option B: 3/4th of the total body potassium is found in skeletal muscle

  • 3/4th of the total body potassium is found in skeletal muscle.

Option C: Intracellular K+ is released into extracellular space in response to severe injury

  • When cell injury occurs, intracellular K+ is released into the ECF– hyperkalemia. E.g., burns, tumor lysis syndrome, rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with silvery scales on the elbow and knee, which bled on removal. There is mild itching at the lesion. The patient has used several emollients and moisturizers on the affected area but the lesion didn’t change. The lesion on the knee is shown in the image below. Which of the following is NOT a histopathologic feature of the condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pautrier’s microabscesses

  • Pautrier's microabscesses are intraepidermal neoplastic cell aggregates of atypical CD4+ cells with “cerebriform nuclei”.
