They are present in mycosis fungoides, which is characterized by skin patches and plaques. It is a neoplasm of mature T cells and it may progress to Sezary syndrome (T-cell leukemia).
  • This patient presented with silvery scales on his elbow and knee (extensor surfaces), which bleed on removal, known as Auspitz sign. This is a characteristic feature of Psoriasis.
  • Psoriasis is treated with topical steroids and vitamin D analogues. It is not affected by applying topical emollients and moisturizers, hence explaining its ineffectiveness in this patient.

HISTOPATHOLOGY OF PSORIASIS

  • Parakeratosis (preservation of nuclei in stratum corneum)
  • Munro's microabscess formation (sterile neutrophilic infiltrate in stratum corneum)
  • Stratum granulosum is absent or decreased in thickness.
  • Spongiform pustules of Kogoj in the Malpighian layer (Stratum basale + Stratum spinosum)
  • Elongation of the rete ridges.
  • Dilation of dermal vessels
  • Dermal papillae are enlarged
  • Suprapapillary epidermal thinning & Acanthosis.
  • Epidermal turnover time = 4 days

Option B: Enlarged dermal papillae

  • Enlarged dermal papillae are a characteristic feature of Psoriasis.

Option C: Suprapapillary epidermal thinning

  • Suprapapillary epidermal thinning is one of the features of Psoriasis.

Option D: Parakeratosis

  • Parakeratosis is the preservation of nuclei in the stratum corneum and it is a histopathological feature present in psoriasis.

questions.text: During the treatment of septic shock, a 28-year-old male remains hypotensive despite adequate volume replacement. When dopamine is started, ventricular tachycardia develops, and this is unresponsive to lidocaine. The V-tach converts back to sinus rhythm once the dopamine is stopped. At this point, which of the following treatment options is most appropriate for this hypotensive patient?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option D: Phenylephrine

  • Catecholamines are the vasopressors used most often for the treatment of septic shock, with norepinephrine being the first line agent, followed by epinephrine.
  • In this case, dopamine given has caused ventricular tachycardia due to its action on the β1 receptor.
  • The patient is hypotensive, and hence amrinone and dobutamine cannot be given as they both decrease peripheral vascular resistance and cause a further decrease in blood pressure.
  • Similar to dopamine, epinephrine is associated with severe arrhythmias, and this is due to increased myocardial workload and oxygen demand; hence this also cannot be given.
  • Phenylephrine is a selective α1agonist and hence is a potent vasoconstrictor. Phenylephrine and hence can be used in the treatment of septic shock in this case.
  • Vasodilatory or septic shock is the result of dysfunction of the endothelium and Vasculature secondary to circulating inflammatory mediators and cells or as a response to prolonged and severe hypoperfusion. It is characterised by peripheral vasodilation with resultant hypotension and is resistant to treatment with vasopressors.
  • Dopamine stimulates receptorsα1(vasoconstriction), β1receptors (cardiac stimulation) and β2receptors (vasodilation), with its effects on β receptors predominating at lower doses. Thus at normally employed doses, it raises cardiac output and systolic blood pressure with little effect on diastolic blood pressure. It may cause ventricular tachycardia, arrhythmia and increased peripheral resistance.

Other options

Option A: Amrinone

  • Phosphodiesterase inhibitors like amrinone and milrinone are not adrenergic agonists, but they behave similarly to dobutamine and increase contractility but also promote vasodilation resulting in hypotension and significant arrhythmia.

Option B: Dobutamine

  • Dobutamine primarily stimulates cardiac β1 receptors to increase cardiac output but may also vasodilate peripheral vascular beds, lower total peripheral resistance and lower systemic blood pressure through effects on β2 receptors. Hence adequate preload and intravascular volume are essential before administering dobutamine.

Option C: Epinephrine

  • Similar to dopamine, epinephrine is associated with severe arrhythmias, and this is due to increased myocardial workload and oxygen demand; hence this also cannot be given.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to recurrent syncopal attacks for 2 weeks. It is not associated with dizziness, sweating, chest pain or shortness of breath. He has no medical disorder and does not take any medications. His brother passed away 2 years ago with similar complaints. The ECG reveals a 'saddle back' pattern in leads V1-V2, confirming the diagnosis of Brugada syndrome. Which of the following is not associated with the Brugada syndrome?

choices.text: The treatment of choice is a pacemaker

questions.solution:
Option D: The treatment of choice is a pacemaker

  • Brugada syndrome is a genetic disorder.
  • It occurs due to abnormal channelopathy, which results in diminished inward sodium current in the right ventricular outflow tract epicardium region.
  • A loss of the action potential dome in the right ventricular epicardium due to unopposed transient potassium outward current results in dramatic shortening of the action potential.
  • The sizeable potential difference between the normal endocardium and rapidly depolarized right ventricular outflow epicardium gives rise to S-T segment elevation in V1-V3 in sinus rhythm and predisposes to local ventricular reentry.

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, the arrhythmia syndrome is most common in young male patients (-75%) and is thought to be responsible for the Sudden Unexpected Nocturnal Death Syndrome (SUDS)
  • For patients with syncopal attacks, ICD implantable cardioverter defibrillator is used as it can deliver a DC shock to terminate the arrhythmia developing in these patients and not a pacemaker.

Option A: SCN5A defect

  • SCN5A defect leads to defective Na+ influx
  • Due to a sodium channel defect, a voltage gradient is created between the right ventricular epicardium & normal heart.

Option B: Asymptomatic S-T segment elevation

  • In Brugada syndrome, the enormous potential difference between the normal endocardium and rapidly depolarized right ventricular outflow epicardium gives rise to S-T segment elevation in V1-V3 in sinus rhythm and predisposes to local ventricular reentry.

Option C: Sudden death

  • Brugada syndrome has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern; the arrhythmia syndrome is most common in young male patients (-75%) and is thought to be responsible for the Sudden Unexpected Nocturnal Death Syndrome (SUDS)
  • Sudden death in a sibling is seen.
  • It is the leading cause of sudden nocturnal death in Southeast Asian males.

questions.text: Following was the data obtained from a patient:- Arterial BP = 90 mm Hg, cardiac output = 5.4 L/min. How much is the peripheral resistance?
questions.solution:
• By Ohm’s law:
    • Cardiac output (Q) = Arterial BP/ Peripheral resistance (R). Q=P/R.
  • Therefore, R = BP/CO
  • The unit for peripheral resistance is PRU.
  • 1 PRU = 1 mm Hg/mL/sec. That is, 1 PRU is 1 mm Hg when flow at the root of the aorta is 1 mL/sec. Thus, the unit for cardiac output will have to be converted to mL/sec.
  • 5.4 L/min = 90 mL/sec.
  • Peripheral resistance (PRU) = 90 mm Hg/90 mL per sec. = 1 R.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with loss of consciousness 20 minutes ago. He regains consciousness in the ER, and GCS on admission is 12/15. CNS examination is normal, and auscultation reveals a narrow split S2 and clear lungs. ECG is shown below:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Subarachnoid hemorrhage with T wave inversion

questions.solution:
Option A: Left outflow tract obstruction

  • The ECG shows a heart rate of 60/min with a left axis deviation
  • SV1+RV5> 35 mm is suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy (SV1 = 20mm and RV5= 30mm)
  • Narrow split S2 indicates outflow tract obstruction
  • Considering the age, the patient either suffers from HOCM or valvular aortic stenosis. Low cardiac output can lead to exertional syncope.

Option B: Right outflow tract obstruction

  • Right outflow tract obstruction will lead to RVH → R wave more than 7mm in V1 (R ≥ S wave), usually with right axis deviation

Option C: Atrial fibrillation with cerebral embolism

  • Atrial Fibrillation is characterized by Irregularly irregular heart rate, Absent P waves (replaced by fibrillating f wave), Baseline vibration

Option D: Subarachnoid haemorrhage with T wave inversion

  • T wave inversion in the anterior lead can be due to:
    1. Subarachnoid haemorrhage
    2. Pericarditis
    3. Pulmonary embolism
    4. Electrolyte abnormalities
    5. HOCM
    6. Pancreatitis
    7. Takotsubo CM

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of floaters and painless vision loss in the left eye. The patient described the sensation that a curtain was coming up over his affected eye, and this curtain is now affecting his central vision. The patient stated that nine days prior, he was struck in the face by shrapnel from an explosion at his workplace, for which he did not seek medical attention at that time as there were no hospitals nearby. After a detailed evaluation by the ophthalmologist, he was diagnosed with rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. Which of the following is the risk factor for Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Aphakia

  • Aphakia can lead to the development of Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment.
  • Aphakia is when a person doesn't have a lens in one or both eyes. It can be congenital or acquired at any stage of life after surgery or injury. The complications are uncommon, but they can lead to RRD's development.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Blurred vision.
    • Farsightedness (hyperopia).
    • Difficult focusing on objects.
    • Decreasing focus when the distance from an object changes.
    • The colors seem faded.
  • A rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD) occurs when a tear in the retina leads to fluid accumulation with a separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. This is the most common type of retinal detachment.
  • Features:
    • Visual field defect.
    • Floaters.
    • Loss of central vision.
  • Risk factors for RRD:
    • Myopia (especially high myopia).
    • Previous intra-ocular surgery.
    • Aphakia, Pseudophakia.
    • Family History of Retinal Detachment.
    • Trauma.
    • Inflammation.
    • Retinal Necrosis - Acute Retinal Necrosis, CMV Retinitis.
    • Drugs – Pilocarpine.

Option B: Toxaemia of pregnancy

  • Preeclampsia is defined as systolic blood pressure more than or equal to 140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure more than or equal to 90 mm Hg or higher, on two occasions at least 4 hours apart in a previously normotensive patient. In addition to this criterion, proteinuria of more than 0.3 gms in a 24-hour urine specimen or a PCR ratio of 0.3 or greater is required to diagnose preeclampsia.
  • The patient may present with retinal involvement as well.
  • Exudative retinal detachment can be found in 1-2% of the cases with preeclampsia/eclampsia.

Option C: Malignant Hypertension

  • Hypertension is a risk factor for many systemic conditions that can progress to end-organ damage. Specifically, hypertension may lead to multiple adverse effects on the CNS, Heart, Kidneys and Eyes.
  • Hypertension predisposes patients to many retinal vascular diseases, including central or branch retinal artery occlusion, central or branches retinal vein occlusion and retinal arterial macro aneurysms.
  • Ischemia secondary to vascular occlusions can cause neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage, epiretinal membrane formation, and exudative retinal detachment.

Option D: Posterior scleritis

  • It's a painful inflammation of the sclera posterior to the ora Serrata.
  • Posterior scleritis represents approximately 10 percent of all cases of scleritis, half of which can be associated with Rheumatoid Arthritis but sometimes with systemic lupus erythematous and granulomatous polyangiitis as well.
  • The main presenting symptom of posterior scleritis is moderate to severe pain. It can manifest as rarely exudative retinal detachment, choroidal folds, or both.

questions.text: A 70-year-old hypertensive patient presented to the outpatient department complaining of sudden onset of palpitations, dizziness and loss of consciousness. On examination, his heart rate was 72 beats/minute, and his Blood pressure was 150/100 mmHg. ECG was done, which showed the following findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Atrial flutter

  • The common right atrial flutter (also called cavotricuspid isthmus dependent atrial flutter) occurs due to a circuit around the tricuspid valve annulus, bounded anteriorly by the annulus and posteriorly by the functional conduction block in the crista terminalis. The wavefront passes between the inferior venacava and the tricuspid valve annulus, known as the cavotricuspid isthmus.
  • It is associated with atrial fibrillation and often with an atrial scar from senescence or prior cardiac surgery.
  • ECG in the lead II, III and aVF shows the presence of flutter waves (Negative saw tooth pattern).
  • 3-4 flutter waves before every narrow QRS complex.
  • The positive p wave is visible in the lead V1.
  • Since the ventricular rate is 75 bpm (RR interval), the atrial rate shall be obtained by multiplying the ventricular rate by 4, which is 300 bpm (240-350 bpm)
  • The presence of risk factors for hypertension also gives a clue to the diagnosis of atrial flutter.

Option B: Atrial fibrillation

  • Atrial fibrillation's atrial rate is around 300 to 600 beats per minute.
  • Because the arterial rate is high, the action potential produced is low amplitude.
  • In patients with Atrial fibrillation, P wave will not be seen
  • Irregular R-R interval

Option C: Multifocal atrial tachycardia

  • The transient rhythm between atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter
  • ECG findings include
    1. Irregular R-R interval
    2. Variable P wave morphology: ≥ 3 different P wave morphology
    3. Variable P-R interval: Usually variable P-R interval is seen with Brady arrhythmias
    4. Right axis deviation will be present

Option D: PSVT

  • Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia
  • ECG findings of PSVT
    1. Narrow QRS complex
    2. R-R interval decreased
    3. Hidden P waves due to the merging of P and the T waves
  • ST segment depression: Because of the mismatch between demand and supply of oxygen the will be some magnitude of ST-segment depression

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever and severe productive cough producing thick bloody sputum resembling a "currant-jelly" appearance. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The culture was performed using MacConkey agar, revealing pink colonies with large mucoid colonies on routine laboratory media. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: Klebsiella pneumoniae

  • This is a case of pneumonia in which the patient presents with complaints of fever and severe productive cough producing thick bloody sputum resembling a "currant-jelly" appearance.
  • Klebsiella pneumonia is most likely responsible for this patient's pneumonia.
  • Patients with K. pneumonia infections usually have predisposing conditions such as alcoholism, advanced age, chronic respiratory disease, and diabetes.
  • The upper lobes of the lungs are predominantly affected.The "currant-jelly" sputum distinguishes K. pneumoniae from the other
  • organisms.
  • K. pneumoniae is lactose fermenting (pink colonies on MacConkey agar), and due to its thick capsule, the colonies have a mucoid appearance (Refer to the image below).

Option A: Enterobacter cloacae

  • Enterobacter cloacae are present in the gut of the human.
  • It is a member of normal gut flora.

Option B: Escherichia coli

  • Escherichia is a gram-negative bacteria.
  • It can cause:
    • Diarrhoea
    • Urinary tract infection.

Option D: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an aerobic gram-negative bacteria.
  • It is a non-spore-forming rod.
  • It usually causes infections in immunocompromised patients.
